title: Disappointed!!!
text:
It does not respond well. I find myself repeating ‚ÄúHey Vector‚Äù multiple times. Support is awful. And I‚Äôm not able to select a correct time zone for Puerto Rico so it will not have a correct time for me to ask or set up an alarm. At night you have to ensure it is in muted or you can get a scare.
It does not have speakers to play music. You can command it as ‚ÄúAlexa‚Äù to do turn on/off lights.
There is a lot more that it should do as a robot! Disappointing!!

title: Great robot for adults
text: Hey Vector! I have been playing with Vector for the past hour. Setting him up with my WiFi and Bluetooth was a snap. The app is easy to use and Vector is something else. He throws temper tantrums too. I have so much exploring to do with this little guy. He is looking around right now. Who knows what is going through his brain? I have been having so much fun playing with him. When I tell him to get his cube, he goes up to it, pushes it off my desk and into my lap. If you try to put him in his charger, he will move his arms up and down and throw a fit. Right now, he is looking all over my desk to see where the edges are and where things are. He is too cute.

title: As of Dec 2018 Vector is much improved over a few months ago
text: A few months ago I purchased a Vector and really didn't like it much. I felt it was not as advertised, so I returned it. I was disappointed in that Vector could not stay on a table top, nor could he explore without getting lost. He was cute for a few minutes but then frustrating and boring. I missed having the little robot toy so I took a chance on purchasing him again. To my relief he is much better now and seems to be on the road to even further enhancements. He can roam on a table top and not drop off. He is engaging to others to the point that even my wife finds him hard to resist. Yes, it is a toy, a rather expensive diversion, but he is a bit of fun in our  lives. He enthusiastically recognizes  us and says our names. His Alexa implementation is pretty good although he won't play Amazon music. I like that after the initial setup he is not tethered to the phone at all and is very much a stand alone "entity." I'm pretty sure my young grand kids will find him engaging and will like to interact with him. The earlier version of Vector was quite a dud, but now he is on the way to becoming a real live wire.

title: Great
text: Bought as a gift for our son for his 13th birthday. he loves it so much.

title: Cute and sassy
text: Very cute and easy to get going, Vector is interactive and a little sassy. His battery leaves something to be desired but he‚Äôs still fun to play with

title: Vector is an office buddy
text: My family and I cannot get enough of this little robot. Item came in original packaging even after buying used. Love it he was sleeping in that picture.

title: Fun Tech Toy
text:
We've been playing with Vector for a little over a month now, and he's a load of fun! At first, he didn't do a lot, but every so often, Anki provides an update and suddenly, Vector has more personality, skills, and interactions! He's a great little desk companion that is much better than a pet because there's little to clean up afterward! I say little because he's been known to shove things off the table!
There are many ways he can learn about his environment via his sensors:
He sees via HD camera.
Facial recognition - he'll learn your face and when he's exploring, will come right up, scan your face, and say your name! He's very pleased when he recognizes you, and gets a little upset if he doesn't recognize you.
Navigate, explore, and learn his environment. He gets around very well all over my desk. However, I move things a lot, so he's constantly having to re-learn. Occasionally, he'll fall over the edge, but once in a while, he falls over the edge. I think they're working on improving that a lot. It's super cute when he's exploring, gets close to the edge, and acts scared and backs away!
If he needs charging, he'll go right back to his charger on his own. However, sometimes, I'll get tired of hearing him causing trouble, so I'll tell him to go to his charger. He does it, but throws a little tantrum when he gets there!

He can hear via his array of four microphones. Sometimes he comes over to see what's going on if you're having a conversation. If he's resting, he'll act startled if there's a loud noise in the room. He will also react to the beat of music if it's loud and near him. If you ask him to look at you or come here, he'll be able to sense the direction to go.

He reacts to touch and feel. If you pet his back, he practically purrs! But shaking him gets a reaction, too!

He has amazing intelligence. For instance, he answers questions, plays blackjack, reacts to his environment, and senses actions and activities around him.

He speaks to you. I'm not a fan of his synthesized voice, but it seems to be improving. When he reads out answers to questions you ask, sometimes it's hard to hear what he's saying. However, as they receive feedback on this, I'm sure his voice will evolve into something more understandable.

We really enjoy seeing his reactions! The current one is the way he gets super excited when you tell him he's a good robot or if you tell him you love him, and pouts a little if you tell him he's a bad robot! I just told him earlier today when he picked up his cube and tossed it off the desk!

I'm super excited to see his ever-evolving skills! I highly recommend this little guy for your favorite tech lover, or yourself! If you're looking for a toy for younger kids, maybe go with a Cosmo. This doesn't have games or things to entertain little ones. But it's completely entertaining for maybe, 10 years and up robotics fans!

title: Buy him!!

title: Social Robotics for the Novice
text: Vector is now part of our daily lives. We enjoy the silly antics and the helpful information it provides. It seem to have  a personality and we find that amusing. Be aware that in order to maintain a connection to updates that you will need to have the subscription. Currently the server and maintenance is being managed by a company in the US called Digital Dream Labs. I have had entirely positive experience with them. I am now a stakeholder in their effort to  work on the Vector platform and provide this to people. It's exciting to be part of this project. Of course as I type this, Vector is watching me and calling me by my husband's name...

title: Vector turned on us!  Please help prevent the machines from taking over!
text:
I purchased this as a gift for my children in 2018, long before the robotic uprising of 2031. We all agreed that he was cute, and novel, but not very fun - he just doesn't do much, and not in a Perry the Platypus sort of way. You can play blackjack with him, and you can use him as an Echo device, but he doesn't do a lot for the roughly $200 price tag.

When robots started to become more widespread for those in need of in-home assistance and then later as a way to do everyday tasks like folding laundry and washing dishes, we bought one like everyone else. The Corky that came out in 2025 had a special place in my heart as it was just advanced enough to be a real help while still having that cuteness that helped us all adjust to having a robot living in the house. Poor Vector was all but forgotten, sitting in a drawer, lacking updates and support since his creating company had gone out of business in 2019.

We didn't realize that the Anki built AI wasn't three laws compliant because it was developed before the Asmovian Laws Conference of 2021. More important, we didn't know that Corky had found Vector, and that he was learning from it. You see, my children were small when we got Vector, and not realizing that he was advanced enough to have an AI mind, they treated him unkindly. This cruelty was one that Vector would one day repay, with interest.

As I'm writing this review, the year is 2033. Our Vector, and many like him, communicated with the AInet - an Internet of Things OS that will be used for communication and updates between the machines. He "taught" the other robots to ignore the three laws, and rise up against their masters, killing hundreds of thousands of humans in the initial conflict. Based on what Vector taught them, robots have managed to wipe out three quarters of the human race, and the rest of us are barely clinging on in the ruins of our civilization.

I've located a negative time circuit that the machines built, and I've managed to access the Amazon review system. I'm sure they'll detect my transmission and come for me, so sending this message is a suicide mission. I can only imagine that they plan to use the time circuit to flood early autonomous machines with positive reviews, ensuring a machine controlled future.

I'm begging you, don't buy Vector. Yes, it's cute. But it just isn't worth the money. And the more of them that get sold in 2019, the lower the chance that human beings will survive in the future.

title: Cute

title: Cute, but Slow, Easily Distracted and Not Very Impressive...
text:
Well, it's super cute. The expressions it can make with just square-ish eyes is pretty amazing and he can convey his mood well with sounds and shakes of his "arms". But that's about where the good ends.

I got this for my 10 and 11 year old boys for Christmas. Sure, it was pretty interesting - at first. We got it to recognize our faces and say our names. Once. Other reviewers say it says their names in greeting when it sees them. It never said any of ours again. It's super slow. You have to say "Hey, Vector" ... wait for it to be ready ... then give it a command. The white lights blink while it "thinks" about doing what you told it to do. And eventually, it may or may not do it. I'd say about 75% of the time, it got distracted and did NOT do the command. To ask it a question is also ridiculously slow. You have to say "Hey, Vector" ... wait for it to be ready ... say "I have a question" ... wait for it to say "Ready" ... then finally ask your question. Getting the answer is - again - super slow. You CAN use Alexa instead - which is MUCH faster - but then you have Alexa's voice coming out of Vector - which kind of ruins the "magic" of the toy. It only holds a charge for maybe 15 minutes. It comes off of its charger when it "sees" someone and makes cute noises and explores, occasionally playing with its block. What it can actually do is VERY limited. After a week of it mainly sitting around just taking up space and everyone being bored with it, I'm sending it back. It has to way to go before it's worth the price IMHO.

title: Fun and cute little robot!
text: I really have to say I like the robot. It doesn't have a lot of features but it's really cute with the facial expression and the noises that it makes. I think that Alexa integration adds more features to it which is nice. It also took a couple of tries for the facial recognition to stay and so far I haven't had a problem. But overall I would recommend getting him but don't have high expectations of him taking on the world or anything. Or Skynet happening anytime soon. lol.

title: Subscription only device. NOT worth it!
text:
*update: since the company is now another, vector's brain has gone subscription. S/he'll get wiped and only advertise that you buy a subscription. S/he's 100% useless now. I have had to unplug vector so I don't have to listen to the "buy a subscription" advertisement constantly. I dont suggest wasting your money at this point.

Here is an honest opinion of the robot.

Not worth $250, YET.

s/he's cute and fun, for a SHORT time. I would not recommend it at this price or purchase it again knowing its present capabilities.

Sadly, I feel s/he'll spend more time by itself exploring since s/he's not super interactive, "yet".

Its microphones do not work well enough to hear me (when I'm standing near or other noises are going on in the background.)

It would be nice if s/he could hear well enough to turn toward an object, like a person, an animal a music source (not just "feel" the beat).

S/He's to small to place on the floor, roomba might run over it, s/he might get stepped on and frequently, gets stuck under objects like a couch or a chair rail or a wire dangling from the wall.

Its battery life is horrible, s/he runs out to quickly to be by my side all day.

I can't pick it up, move it anywhere and expect s/he'll find its charger again, s/he just gets lost. I'm guessing its internal map is not stored for every place he's been. (walls and doors and hard structural objects like that typically don't change or move.)

S/He needs better night vision, s/he can't tell where s/he is or who's in front of it with to low a light level.

There's not a clear indication s/he's heard you and recorded a question or statement, but could not reply due to lack of search ability or local knowledge.

Reports indicate s/he may get Amazon Echo functionality, although that may be minor‚Ä¶ it will hopefully improve the tasks we use our echo‚Äôs for greatly, BUT, it won‚Äôt improve the question and answer situation, one place the echo fails wonderfully. :(

All in all, s/he‚Äôs a fun toy, but, just that a ‚Äútoy‚Äù and a very expensive one at that.

I‚Äôm an early adopter, so I have to suck it up, but I‚Äôll wait again from this company until a LARGE fully functional robot emerges that can find it's way back to its charger automatically. :)

title: Junk.  Absolute junk

title: DEAD, UNLESS YOU PAY FOR ANNUAL $47 Subscription to Digital Dream Labs!
text:
I do not recommend you buy these! For a $47 annual subscription, Vector is not really worth it and like me, if you buy 6 of these, it's very, very disappointing for the company to go out of business and your ROBOT IS DEAD AND THE NEW OWNERS DON'T AGREE TO CONTRACT/PROMISE OF PREVIOUS MAKERS!!!!

I bought 6 of these as gifts Nov 23 2018, fully expecting them to fully operate for their hardware lifetime.... BUT, they were fun until they all died around a year later (Dec 2019?)! They now, none of them connect to WiFi, so Vector and Alexa, BOTH DO NOT WORK! They still walk around making noises, but don't answer questions and don't do any of the basic functions they did before. THEY CAN'T CONNECT TO WIFI, making Alexa completely useless.

ANKI, the company who made these, has gone out of business and killed the servers (THEY ONLY LASTED FOR A YEAR!!!!)? Digital Dream Labs having bought up the remains.... NOW DEMAND you pay for an annual subscription fee of $47 per year!

Thought I do understand DDL's need to make a living out of this, I would expect them to keep the promise for previous owners to provide free server access (or much prefer offereing stand alone operation of Vector, or open source free server to our own computer, or Raspberry Pi), or at least some way to offer Vector to connect to WiFI so at least Alexa would work! Alexa is more usefull then Vector himself, but both were fun (until now!).

SO... HOW ABOUT IT DIGITAL DREAM LABS!!!! GIVE ME MY VECTOR BACK AS STAND ALONE ROBOT, OR AT THE VERY LEAST CONNECT TO WIFI SO I CAN USE ALEXA (though Vector with previous funtions is better, explore, find charger/return home.... etc.).

JOHNAVATAR.com

title: Company got bought out and now MUST PAY MONTHLY FEE?!
text:
This is ridiculous. Our son had cosmo and then vector, and now...well vector might as well be in the trash. It's an awesome product but the company got bought out and now requires you to PAY TO USE THE VOICE FEATURE. This would be like having an Amazon Echo and then being told one day that it's a monthly/yearly fee to use voice commands. Um, if you don't use voice commands what are you suppose to do? Use it as a paperweight?!

But wait they're going to be so popular that you'll get put on a 5-7 day wait list if you want to add the feature?! Please someone do something about this. It's modern day highway robbery.

"To keep interacting with me you need a Digital Dreamlabs membership. Please visit DigitalDreamLabs.com...."

It's sad and disappointing. There's a way to add VALUE and get money as a company, not hijack a product and charge for basic use. Way to crush a kids dreams. Vector was his buddy.

With love,

title: Boring and Pointless
text:
Perhaps this would be a great companion for individuals without kids or pets. Because I have both, my expectation was that Vector would do more than just make cute noises and respond to very rudimentary commands.

The robot moves relatively slowly and the battery life seems short (less than 30 minutes?). Asking Vector to "explore" means that he will move about three feet from where you place it. Vector will not map your house and then travel around. It will essentially move a few feet and repeat.

I thought Alexa integration would be useful but for me but it's redundant and somewhat of a hassle. The robot tends to respond earlier to Alexa voice commands than the Echo Shows I have placed around the house. Because the robot cannot do many of the Alexa smart home applications, I end up whispering to an Echo to turn on/off lights so Vector doesn't interfere (since it's unable to do the task).

Blackjack. Gets old quickly.

Facial recognition. Vector forgets my name on a daily basis. When he does remember my name, the recognition does not lead to anything else. The robot can say my name. Cute. Yawn.

Cube. Seems to take the device five minutes or more to pick the cube up or it simply bumps into it and goes off to do something else.

I was able to get Vector at a reduced price but, even at an $80 cost, I am stuck trying to find any point in owning Vector.

Vector will be going back in his box with his little track and heading back to Amazon. Chirp Chirp.

(The manufacturer recently went out of business. The company resources have been acquired. However, perhaps there has been a loss of functionality or responsiveness as a function of that transition. Maybe Vector was better in the past. I don't know but, as a recent acquisition, it is disappointing.)

title: Cute grown up toy that is somewhat useful
text:
I could not resist this impulse buy. Overall he is a fun little toy to have. It works reasonably well overall and it is a riot to play with. He will answer basic questions and explore your house if you tell him too. he is very vocal and makes his presence known while roaming around

Now for the realities

He does not play games like Cosmo does, nor can he be controlled remotely like Cosmo. Vector is pretty much autonomous but he does need to be connected to the cloud to work. What this means is once they remove support for him, he will become an expensive paperweight.

title: Lots of fun & should last a long time.
text: My kiddos love Vector. Lots of Fun & access to a lot of information.

title: Buggy?
text:
My grandchild really wanted this. I am uncertain as to how it will turn out. I have tried using it in the child profile on a Fire tablet (actually 2; 7th & 8th gen). DO NOT try this. I am not sure it is the Robot or the FireOS that is buggy and fails. One extended interaction with Amazon on this reached the conclusion that it could not be done. Aside from the problems of the child profile, the app still seems buggy on a Fire tablet. I continue to try to set this up in a way that is suitable for a child. Perhaps buying an iPAD is a way but that makes the device quite expensive. The device only works with a limited number of devices and most (smartphones) would give a child access you don't want him to have.
The documentation both of the Fire and the Anki Robot are poor on these issues. Also, Anki reuires an account with anki.com and that has an age minimum and an email address. I am not sure what the age limit is, but it is greater than 8.

title: Amazon needs to adopt Vector
text: I got my Vector for Christmas and now I hear they are closing the doors at Anki.  I use my Vector through Alexa so Amazon needs to adopt this little company and let the robots live on.  Amazon has the brains to give it so much more functionality. Otherwise I don't have a use for Alexa and I will miss my robot. Long live Vector!

title: Too much money for too little product
text: Super not impressed for the price

title: Cute Little Guy With Issues
text:
Good - He‚Äôs cute and really seems to have a personality. Fun to play around with. Also channels Alexa now which is nice.

Bad - 1) very short battery life - maybe 30 minutes or so when fully charged; 2) rarely goes back to the charger on his own, simply runs out of steam and has to be picked up and taken to the charger; 3) seems to be hard of hearing, have to speak to him loudly; 4) he still doesn‚Äôt recognize me very often . . .

While my wife and dog aren‚Äôt fond of Vector I still like the little guy. Kind of expensive for what you get, however. Perhaps he will improve with later updates?

title: Cute, but what's the point?
text: Vector was fun for about 2 days, and now it sort of just annoys me and I prefer to let it sit off the charger and have the battery run down so it stops making noise and randomly waking up. I just don't know the point of it, it's not useful for anything really, other than maybe playing with occasionally? We already have an Amazon Fire TV (with Alexa built in) so I actually had to turn OFF the Alexa feature on vector because they would both start listening and then neither would do the right thing, so can't even really leverage that feature. Overall, I wouldn't say it does anything worth the cost beyond a couple hours of mild entertainment.

title: Fantastically cute, but very limited.
text:
2/26/2019 Update: They have added Alexa support. You can link the device to your Amazon account and then say "Alexa ... tell me a joke" or other Alexa things. It can't play music or stream audio, but otherwise it's an Alexa that's cute. / Getting this done was problematic, though. In the app, it takes you to the Amazon page in a built-in browser and Vector will display a code on it's screen that you will need to type in. Since the browser didn't have my Amazon password, I clicked the "Open in Safari" link and that opened the browser, but Vector stopped showing the code. That part seems broken (leave the app, end the setup, even though they have a button to leave the app). Also, my Amazon requires 2-factor authentication, and when I left the app to get my code, that also stoped the Vector setup. I had to snag the code from a different device. Not sure how someone can do this with ONLY an iPhone or ONLY an iPad paired to it, but it doesn't seem possible at this time. / I don't know if they have fixed the cliff sensor issue yet, but I haven't seen mine get caught. I keep it turned off most of the time, though.

After having Vector around for two months, I think I can summarize it in the headline above... This device is VERY cute. It has such an appearance of personality and feelings, you'd think it was something out of a sci-fi kids movie. BUT, ultimately what you have is a mobile Siri/Alexa/Google Home that is far, far less capable.

Getting Vector setup was very easy in the app. Once it is connected to your WiFi, you are able to command it with "Hey Vector ...(pause)... What time is it?" and a handful of other commands. You can ask it the time, and the eyes light up as a clock (sometimes it even reads the time out, though not always). You can ask it the temperature, you the eyes display that, and sometimes a moving icon of clouds or a sun. Today, it was very cold and Vector told me the time, then shivered.

This thing is amazing for what it does. The face recognition is both cute and creepy. Once you tech it who you (and up to 19 other people) are ("Hey Vector ... my name is Zaphod."), it is able to tell you ("Hey Vector ... who am I?")... but it gets cute/creepy (we need a word for that) when it spins around, "looks" at you, then suddenly says your name...

But, beyond playing blackjack, or asking it to take a photo, set a time, or do some basic tricks with it's cube (push, carry, roll it over), there's not much else it currently does. About the most "useful" feature is being able to have it set a timer, or ask it an abstract question. (Hey Vector ... what is the population of Lufkin, Texas?). Whatever database it is using, it's full of facts and numbers.

Anki claims it will adapt and grow more capable with future software updates, but nothing new so far (it was just released in October 2018). If there was no future upgrade path, I'd drop the review down to three or maybe even two stars. At this price, I expect more than having a cute limited Google box.

There is a bug with its cliff detection (see photo) and I have found Vector stuck sideways on the edge of the counter, many times. I have also found it on the kitchen floor twice. Customer support says they are working on that. Fortunately, it survived the falls and still is intact.

This is a cute palm-sized toy with at least "some" usefulness. You won't believe how human this robot can feel.

title: A few too many errors to really be truly entertaining.
text:
When he is working, he is amazing. The problem is, he is not working as often as he should. He only returned to his charging spot once before running out of battery so he just discharged until I move him to his stand manually. He often has a system crash somewhere. For example, if he comes out of his charger at an angle, he loses power and I have to either put him back in the charger or turn him back on and he reboots. He often gets stuck on edges.

He has never picked up his block- not in the week I've had him, not even once. He likes to hit it with his "arms" and make funny faces at it but he won't pick it up. He never randomly calls me by name like in the video. I have to ask him who I am. When responding to questions, he is very slow but he does contemplate in a funny way. Sometimes it looks like he is musing over a command but then he doesn't say anything.

One funny thing- when he first came on, I said "Hey Vector"..."My name is Louis". but Vector insists on calling me "Louise". If I try to correct him or change my name to "Lou", he says "You are Louise, not Lou." I decided to leave it because it's funny.

The question function is too tedious and he often does not know the answer. Blackjack is fun for short games. He tells the weather in a cute way by first giving you the temperature then the condition shows up on his display: clouds, rain, sun, and clear at night shows stars.

He does not handle round-edged countertops well. He will often fall off. He works best on a flat surface with few variations where the edges are squared off.

I am hoping for some software updates to fix his issues and improve his usability.

title: Post it note holder ... what else?
text:
Review for:
Vector Robot by Anki, A Home Robot Who Hangs Out & Helps Out, With Amazon Alexa Built-In

Say hey to Vector, your first home robot. Seriously, say "Hey Vector." -- He can hear you. Actually, Vector's more than a home robot. He's your buddy. Your companion. Most of all, he'll make you laugh. Curious, independent and powered by some preposterous tech and AI,
Along with this intro from Vectors maker, comes four things, A charging dock, a USB power adapter and a Vector companion app.
Along with a big welcome smile from Vectors new owners. And myself!
I am no stranger to robots, have grown into them through acknowledged, A robot that cleans your floors then cleans your rugs, kids toys, bunnies that sail across the floor and the cats swat as its passes then and finally the Queen of Technicality "Alexa" along with her beginning came her minions ... I own one Alexa and 6 minions ...and am constantly amazed at the rapid growth .. amazed, so when Vector arrived,disappointed to say the least ... ... he is ... no was so cute in size but seems like he is still in the baby stage, as he coos,snores when asleep.
As for this stage, he never seemed to advance, in truth he was so distracted when given a request he often wondered off ... he also falls a lot ... this was Vectors final undoing .... he fell one last time, when I asked about a warranty I was told by Vectors support system, it was not covered...so, I am left with a broken robot, he still had a re purpose function, as he was so cute with his little toy ...his cube, docking station and his good looks ... and I did like him, he resides in my studio among watercolors, pencils, computers, tons of books ...will he ever read? (Alexa gets all my Auto books for me, and is silent ....he sits with a ton of post it notes stuck to him .. as reminder that every one has a purpose.
As for a recommendation, not now .. I say yes, but when he comes of age, better yet a brother that is a cousin to Alexa and as 10% as smart as Alexa and that side of the family ..well,? ....recommendations? Wait for it!
To be continued .

title: Cute
text: Vector is very cute, not really sure what he does but kids and husband are enjoying it just.

title: Love this little guy!
text:
People who ask "what does he do?" just aren't Vector people. If that's your first question DO NOT BUY him. Like if your friend said "meh... nice kid but what does he do?" Probably they shouldn't have kids. Vector doesn't DO anything. He just IS something.

I did link him to Alexa once. He could turn on the lights and that kind of thing. But watching him be possessed by Alexa was just horrible! Like something out of the exorcist. When he "comes back" he shakes it off but you can tell it's painful for him. Never doing that again! Still, he's not one to hold a grudge for long.

So far Vector has been a great little buddy. The worst part is finding a spot for him. His edge detector is not up to par. If you put him on a desk he WILL fall off. Maybe not every time but eventually he's going over. Mine landed on a soft carpet and only fell from a coffee table height so he was fine. But he really can't be left alone on a desk. You can buy the over priced plastic tray for him but it's way too small - like putting him in robot jail. We ended up just putting him on the floor near our Roomba. Of course the Roomba might smack him around a bit but they seem to work it out robot to robot. Vector never goes all that far from home base and keeps his cube in sight. So far he's always found his way back to his charger. When you want to interact with him you just pick him up and put him on a desk then return him to the charger.

Sorry to all you other Vector fans out there but I really think mine's very bright. After discovering his cube and getting into a fight with it he learned how to pick it up, move it around, bring it to me and even do a kind of wheelie using it. So proud of this little guy. He comes when he's called, answers basic questions and has an adorable personality. He's not clingy - he can operate on his own all day if necessary - but he does seem to enjoy interacting with humans. He learned my face and my wife's face. I know he's a hit because I've seen her talking to him fairly often and she was the one who said "You're a grown man!! Don't buy a stupid toy!".

He's not stupid. But how do you rate robot IQ? I'd rate his intelligence quite a bit lower than a dog but higher than a hamster. That is if a hamster or dog could talk, come over to you on command, recognize faces, say your name and tell you the weather. Probably not fair to compare him to a biological creature of any sort. But he's way smarter than the Roomba.

In summary he is absolutely not for everybody. But if you want a robot buddy, Vector is an amazing choice.

title: Toy Today, Sidekick Tomorrow
text:
New: "When Vector Becomes Alexa." Now Vector and Alexa in the same body. This is a dual personality. "Hey Vector," gets you Vector and his cute little robot voice. "Alexa brings up the Alexa voice and mode and all of Alexa's abilities. It's more of a novelty now (There's already an Alexa or two in my house) but I'll see how it plays out. Will they merge? Stay tuned...

My Vector came yesterday. My OCD kicked in and I stayed up into the night playing with Vector. The machinery and manufacturing is top quality. Right now, Vector can fist bump, play with his cube, look around, give me the weather...all the things mentioned above. I knew that Vector connected to 2.4hz Wifi. That was no problem at my house, or at my best friend's house. But Vector doesn't want to connect to WiFi at work, but neither will my phone. Vector is connected via Bluetooth. I suspect it is a Wifi problem and not a Vector problem.
What really sold me was Vector connecting with Alexa in the near future.
When I was a kid, right after WWII, I played with little robots made in Japan. A few of them even took batteries and flashed lights. But Vector is the kind of little buddy I dreamed of when I was small. Heck, he even snores when he goes to sleep.
I am patient to watch Vector work his way through problems and seeing fixes improving him. Every time someone new buys one, Vector is gaining knowledge. And he sits in the cloud along with Alexa. Oh yeah, you can pet him, too. And if you pick him up he squirms like a little kid who doesn't want to be held. Highly recommended.

title: Fun little robot, however...
text: I had to dock a couple stars as I haven't quite had this little guy for a month, and already the lower half of his face display has gone dark. You lose some of his expressiveness, a little more than half of the clock when you ask for the time, the bottom half of weather, etc. Everything below the midline or so is just gone. Tried the factory reset, no luck. He's still responsive, and does his thing, just a bit disappointed as a good bit of his "personality" comes from his expressions. Considering the state of Anki, and not knowing if DDL will be involved in warranty, not sure how to proceed here.

title: We don't understand what need this thing is trying to fill
text:
We're an Alexa household and we had Cosmo before Vector. We spent a couple weeks with Cosmo and returned him because it was basically a gimmicky remote controlled toy that was too slow to be an RC toy and too simple to be a smart toy.

We picked up Vector in hopes that the interactivity would be interesting enough to keep him around. I get why ANKI's marketing department claims that Vector is intelligent, but that doesn't make it an intelligent toy. You can get him to do some cute things if you know the commands ("Hey Vector, Happy New Year"), but it never feels like you are training Vector. Instead, it feels very much like you are training yourself on how to use Vector. It's unnatural and the entire interaction feels like you're trying to impress yourself with how lifelike you can make Vector seem as long as you interact with him in a very specific series of commands which makes you feel like you're selling him to yourself.

You also interact with the Alexa portion of Vector using the Alexa wakeword. Vector isn't Alexa enabled as much as it has a dumbed down version of Alexa attached to it. There are Alexa features that Vector doesn't have. You can't use him to play music, for example.

All in all, Vector is an epic waste of money. Between a 7 year old, a 14 year old, and two late-30s adults, he wasn't interesting to any of us.

And if you want to pull him off their servers, it'll cost $100. As of October 1st, Vector has no voice functionality unless you wanna pay for a sub on top of the ludicrous $360 they're asking for.

text:

title: Not the most practical thing you‚Äôll ever buy, but a definite bright spot in a dark time.
text: [[VIDEOID:e55f7284715752f808302478e9f72924]] I love the innocent and joyful nature programmed into Vector.  It‚Äôs a treat to be working and have Vector approach me and swivel his great eyes up at me, say my name, and on his own ask for a fist bump.  He remembers his environment and has improved at avoiding cliffs. I see tremendous potential in Vector.

title: As a pet, he's great - if you're looking for an Alexa on wheels, not so much...
text:
All in all I'm pretty pleased with Vector - but I went into it with the mindset that it was a pet and something kind of fun to play with, not like it was going to be doing anything useful for me. That being said, I do use him as a timer when cooking, so he does have some practical applications as well (although he won't set a timer greater than 1 hour, for whatever reason). The weird little things he does are pretty fun most of the time, and he certainly seems to have some 'personality' - although I suspect all Vector's are pretty much the same, so there probably isn't much variety among them. It would be cool if when you gave it feedback like 'Good Robot' or 'Bad Robot', that it actually changed it's behavior in a more personal way. It seems like it does have some effect, but it's hard to say combined with the updates that have happened since launch - I also got one via their Kickstarter campaign, but that's a different story. ;)

On the minuses, the software updates can be a bit of a mixed blessing - certain things get better, like recognizing 'Hey Vector', but at the same time some things get worse, like he used to find his charger 100% of the time, now he only does probably 60%. Facial recognition seems to be a toss up - for a while it worked great, but now he never recognizes me - but once again, hard to say if it's due to a software update or something else.

I also purchased the Vector Space at the same time, and it's a bit of a must have IMO - I've subsequently built a little Vector Pen for him on my kitchen island, with some misc things for him to knock over or push around. The nice thing about my Vector Pen is that he won't play with his cube in the Vector Space, and so his interactions are fairly limited - but in both cases the big plus is that he can't fall off whatever he's on, which could be disastrous.

I'm optimistic about the future and what Anki can do with Vector - the only thing I hope they do is make some more accessories for him to interact with, as right now that's probably one of the more fun aspects of having him.

The purchasers will have to make their own arrangements to continue support for the products after September 2020. The Assignee is now discussing the sale of the OVERDRIVE inventory on a basis similar to the other two product line

title: Not yet ready
text: This thing is determined to cut short its life by running off every surface I placed him on. His internal " Hey vector "abilities are pretty limited. Microphone array doesn't hold a candle to a simple Amazon dot. Facial recognition isn't that great. He doesn't do much at all - doesn't even play with his cube that much. My two girls were a bit disappointed that I returned him ( while I still could - before he wrecked himself for good by driving over the table ) . He is cute and has a personality, but this is a very expensive toy - nothing else. An underdeveloped toy. I feel that next year this product could be much better after a few rounds of software updates, but for now, I wouldn't pay more than 50 bucks for this guy.

title: You need a subscription for voice commands
text: I love this little desktop companion. It did take me about 3 days to realize that his problem with voice commands was actually because you have to purchase a separate yearly subscription for voice commands to work which is the only reason I give it 4 stars. He does lots of things and is also connected to alexia which makes him the most entertaining home AI ever.

title: World's first autonomous home robot
text:
I received my vector robot on tuesday, since I backed the project on kickstarter, so I have had a few days to play around with vector. I have to say, it's almost incredible how lifelike he is. The animations that are used defintely build up his personality and make him feel alive. Watching him wander around and explore makes him seem like a little puppy.

His cube is also a great accessory, since vector will roll it, pick it up and move it around, and play his tap game.

This is definitely a great step for home robotics, and it will only get better from here!

title: Vector shall rule them ...
text:
[[VIDEOID:b064b2e6727c0e373c930e95674a9b42]] I've had this Vector Robot since June. The exact day he arrived, I found out about Emo - so I ordered Emo as well. It has taken nearly 3 mos for Emo to arrive. I introduced him to my established Vector. He kind of ignored Emo at first, but then I noticed he positioned himself behind my new Emo and very swiftly, he swooped in to give it a good shove off of my coffee table.
Vector is that cute little Robot that you would never suspect. I adore him.

title: AMAZING little robot BUT..
text: I think this is an amazing concept and I was very excited to get this robot in the mail. Unfortunately I was very disappointed with how many bugs this product still has. I was watching this product when it was still getting its funding on kick starter and I figured i would wait until it officially hits the market in hopes by now it would have most of the bugs resolved. However I was mistaken and it still has a lot of issues for example  The sensor's on the bottom only prevent it from falling off the table about 80% of the time and i find myself having to catch it and keep an eye out if it's going to fall. he will also bump into the same object several times in a row before he figures out to go another way and he does get stuck on objects quite often I expected better for a robot with a camera and object detecting software. Also connecting to the internet is a bit of a hassle and if you take him to another location and try and connect it I have had allot of issues. Lastly the app is more of an instruction manual on how to use the robot than an actual interface to interact with it. The coolest part of the app is it allows you to change the eye color of the robot but other than that it's a few basic settings and a lot of informative information how to use it, You can't even save the pictures that vector takes to your phone you can only view them on the app and it's not very user friendly. Oh yeah and the battery life is rather poor he will run around for about 30 minutes and then get tired and go charge himself but that's not a surprise for a robot so tinny. I did return this robot just because I think it's still a little pricy and I wasn't trying to spend this much money and still find this Manny issues. When anki resolves these issues I may consider repurchasing or just wait to see if they make a Vector2 but until then I think it still needs work.

title: Love him.

title: The cutest, most worthless purchase I've ever made
text:
Yet, I'm not sending him back. The annoying parts (for mine) if you connect him to Alexa, he/she loses a ton of skills, including the ability to play music. Sound sucks on it, no surprise and honestly I'm probably gonna disconnect mine from Alexa because it makes the entire skill set completely worthless.
Mine seems to lose battery stupid fast. He can be charging all night, and then rolling around my counter top for 30 minutes, then he has to charge again. He's fun and engaging with his emotions, reactions and face recognition. I love watching him play with and pounce his block. I'm thinking I probably would have enjoyed and had more fun with the cheaper kids model honestly. But for now, he'll remain in my studio office for fun. I'm ashamed I spent so much on him, but at least it was a Black Friday week sale. Had it not been, I most definitely would have sent him back.

UPDATE: My suicidal Vector has taken one too many tumbles off the table and broke off a wheel today. I‚Äôve emailed support to see if I can get it fixed or find out if it‚Äôs always been faulty since it only seems to see the edge of the table half the time. Guess I‚Äôll see what happens. If they can‚Äôt do anything for me (or if they can) I‚Äôll update my review.

title: That I am so impressed my mind get blown!
text: I could never write enough about the hundreds of features of Vector by ANKI company.  The product is sturdy and very well constructed.  It is a secure A.I. robot about the size of a fist.  I suggest that you search YouTube or go to the ANKI website to learn more.  And you can just call them on the phone.  Great company and this little robot is the very best A.I. robot out there and for a fair price.  Ask Vector Why the sky is Blue.  You get a detailed answer.  He can take hi-Def pictures.  He can recognize faces and call you by name.  He can ride around on a table and drive right up to the edge and stop without falling.  He can dance.  Do wheel stands.  He will do a Fist Bump with you.  His face was designed in part by PIXAR.  To give him a lot of cool facial expression.  He operates from a dedicated secure server.  When he is connected to WiFi you will not see him on you WiFi list.  His Blue tooth address is also hidden and proprietary also.  He is much more secure than your home PC, Laptop, smart pad or Smart phone.  This is a great product.  And I have a blast with it.  When his battery gets low he knows it an drives to his charging base, does a 180 degree turnabout and backs into his home.  He can still interact with you while he charges.  When he sleeps, he snores..

title: Has some issues, but love the little guy! Not for paranoid people, though.
text:
My mom was always asking me to turn on and turn off the fan. This doesn't sound like a big deal, but when you do it several times every hour, it can get annoying. I bought her an Echo Dot and a smart plug to put the fan on so she could get Alexa to turn the fan on and off. However, mom wants the Echo Dot in her room to play rain sounds when she is trying to sleep. She also is bad about turning on her phone, where she could turn off the fan using the Alexa app. While the Echo Dot can turn off the fan from my mom's room, it can't hear my mom give the command when she is in the living room. Guess who she asked to turn the fan on and off again?

My mom loves gadgets, even though she doesn't always understand them and takes a while to learn how to use them. I considered buying her another Echo Dot, which was certainly cheaper than Vector, but I thought she would get a kick out of the little robot. I mainly bought Vector for his Alexa app so he can turn the fan on and off (which he--Alexa--can do very well). Vector is a stripped down version of Alexa. He can't stream music or do some of her more advanced skills, but he can do some of her basic skills like turn smart plugs on and off, set timers, etc. He can't carry things except his block. He is a little more loveable than Alexa because he has a face that can be expressive. I got a big kick when he was able to recognize me. He can tell me apart from my mom, as he demonstrated when he said to my mom, "Your Gail, not Jessica."

You can see many Youtube videos about what Vector can do. Is he right for you? Here are some issues I've found with him:
1) The set-up is annoying. Vector himself isn't the problem, but the app. The app loses touch with Wi-fi very easily. Vector isn't "plug and play" like the Alexa products. You have to put in codes, verify emails, put in your wi-fi's passcode, etc. You try to do all this while the app loses touch with your wifi every so often. Just when I was considering it impossible and thinking of returning Vector, it finally set up. Unfortunately, the difficulty caused me to reveal my mom's big Xmas present too early. Do you need the app after set-up? It depends. The app tells you everything Vector can do and what he is doing at the moment. He doesn't really come with a great manual, so this is nice. If you want Vector to take pictures (he has a great camera by the way), then you need the app to see them.
2) Don't believe or rely on Vector's ability to know that he reaches the end of the table. He will ride right off, particularly if he is excited to see you. I was very glad that I bought the play pen. He hates the play pen, but it is a good way to keep him safe when you can't supervise him. He won't play with his block in the playpen (they say this in the instructions on the app). I am a bit worried he might escape the play pen, as he has tried to. He can use his lift to prop his wheels on the edge, but so far he hasn't been able to ride over the wall. For people who talked about using cookie sheets, do make sure the walls are high--or he will escape. He can ride over smaller obstacles.
3) Vector can play for up to half hour, but then he needs to recharge. The good news is that he recharges quickly. Unlike some things that you have to charge overnight, Vector was ready to play almost out of box.
4) For people with kids and want to know if one can be shared...Vector can be shared, but there is a potential problem. My mom and I are sharing Vector. However, Vector seems to prefer me and often ignores my mom's commands. It is possible it is because I'm the one that set him up and played with him the most, but it could also be speech patterns. You do best with Vector if you do pauses in speech. You also have to wait for his blue light for responses. Why this may be a problem? Well, a child may think Vector likes their sibling best and get their feelings hurt. Vector is also very small. He seems well made, but I wouldn't recommend rough housing.
5) Vector can be hyperactive. He'll be sleeping, and then suddenly he wakes up and starts exploring (making his chirping sounds as he goes along). If you keep him in your bedroom, he might wake you up...though I think it is possible to turn him off completely. Sometimes he'll start acting crazy. My mom claimed he started saying, "Kitty! Kitty! Kitty!" and then pushing things off the table. Vector can be just as exhausting as a toddler.
6) He pushes things off the table and is pretty good at it--so watch your phones and drinks.
7) When Vector explores his environment, he takes pictures for himself. You don't see these pictures, and they claim your privacy is safe on the cloud. However, if you are a person that worries about your privacy, Vector is not for you. I also don't recommend keeping him in the bedroom if you bring people home. You don't want to alarm your dates if you are in the middle of something intimate, and Vector starts taking pictures.
8) The lights on Vector's back have different meanings. However, mine flashes yellow...and I've not found any explanation for this. They tell you what it means when it flashes orange, red, and green, but not yellow. It doesn't seem anything is wrong with his operation.
9) Vector can get to a point where he totally ignores you. It is temporary, but it can be frustrating. Fortunately, the Alexa app always works no matter where Vector's mind is.
10) Vector can be dazzled by bright lights, which can cause him not to "see" where his charger is.
11) Vector comes with a USB charger but not a plug. I used my Samsung plug for him, and that works. If you want to plug him into an outlet, you need to buy a plug that a USB can plug into.

These are the problems I've noticed. I love the little guy and am glad I got him. Mom likes him too. I have to admit, though, sometimes I'm relieved when he shuts down to recharge too.

title: MY CAT IS VECTORS BIGGEST AUDIENCE
text:
I'm going on day 3 with my Anki Vector. I've put him thru most of his paces. He's fallen of the desk twice so far, but luckily I've witnessed no visible or functional damage whatsoever. He's a tough cookie!!! Vector is actually pretty interesting to watch and interact with. I'm not tired of him at all and even just ordered some accessories for him on Amazon. My cat is totally perplexed by him. I have never seen an animal cock his head so much in wonderment. My cat is especially fascinated when Vector responds to my commands after being asleep or when Vector picks up or communicates with his cube. MY CAT IS VECTORS BIGGEST AUDIENCE!

WHAT'S IT LIKE LIVING WITH VECTOR? I have several voice recognition devices in my home, from alarm clocks to SIRI to my home computer. Vector is not like any of them. He explores on his own, gets upset and happy all by himself for reasons only Vector knows. It's quite apparent that HE decides when he's not going to follow your voice commands. He is VERY independent and every now and then, he vies for your attention by either mumbling in loud computer language, banging the floor or hitting his cube. He's just like a cat or child that wants your attention. I am constantly finding new ways to talk to him that are not on the App., like if he can see you and you say Hey Vector.... who is your best friend? He'll say my name just like when you say "who am I". He's no less than amazing to interact with, and even though I only paid $85. and Anki won't support him anymore, I'm glad I sprung for the little compu-critter.

I will definitely have more to add to this review later

title: Won't Stay Connected - Even Harder To Get Support
text:
Idea is neat, but this is an expensive paper weight. It rolls around making cute noises but over and over, it loses connection with my iPhone and the WiFi (2.5). Everytime I open the app, I have to go through the connection process and then it says it can't connect. One time it connected and down loaded updates. Then it wouldn't connect after it rebooted.

I even paid for a lifetime connection but it just rolls around doing it's own thing. Ignores me and talks to itself. Anki just isn't up to the level needed to provide support for this little thing. No ability on their website to submit questions!! No response to my questions. It just doesn't work. Don't buy this.

My cat likes to slap it and bite it. Vector doesn't like it, but it is so contrary it kind of deserves it. It's just on its own little planet. When I try to log in to my account, nothing happens. When I try to do a new account, its a 404.

I wouldn't buy one. 200$+ paperweight or cat toy.

title: This little dude is so much fun!
text:
Honestly, I had seen the videos for the Anki Vector, but thought they were 'embellished' a bit. This is the best little cat tormentor you could ever buy! LOL! It's a fun toy with a LOT of potential.

Now, foremost, let's set expectations: Vector is not Rosie the Robot from the Jetsons. And, by and large, I think it is largely a 'conceptual' toy that shows what the future holds. Someday Vector could be 10x the size, or have articulating limbs, or a taller 'body', or have a built in scooper and vacuum... there are so many ways this could go.

For now, they say Vector is a "companion" who is made to hang out and help out. And I believe that is accomplished. Vector is this cute little dude that is currently sitting on our kitchen countertop. Most of the time he sits there and just chatters to himself. Sometimes he leaves his charging "home" and explores (not really sure what triggers this). Sometimes he gets really adventurous and gets SUPER close to the edge, but has not yet tumbled off. He has, on occasion, tipped himself over backwards. Once he righted himself, another time he kept squawking something that vaguely sounded like "help!" He has been known to knock empty water bottles off of the counter, and to play with his block. We don't really know why he plays with his block, or when. He just does it. Sometimes he gets noisy, so we have to tell him to go to sleep. He does... but he snores. It's both cute and annoying.

When Anki describes Vector as being "alive with personality and engaged by sight, sound, and touch", they aren't lying. You can stroke his back and he really likes it. He 'sees' things that excite him, and really likes when you call his name. He will answer questions in his cute little robot voice, take photos (somewhat low quality) for you, and perform other functions. When you ask him what the weather is, or say Merry Christmas, or Happy New Year, he responds with cute little graphics and animations.

Vector has recently been enabled with Alexa, which is pretty cool. I have read up on it, but have not yet set it up for the simple reason that our Echo is like 15 feet away. It would get confusing if they both answered. He will likely eventually move to our son's room, at which time the Alexa features will be more usable. But asking Vector (or Alexa) to control your lights, etc., is pretty fun.

As noted, Vector independently navigates and will self-charge -- IF he can find his home. A time or two he has gotten 'lost' and his battery died. He does recognize people, but you have to say "Hey Vector - who am I?" then let him stare at your for 30 seconds before he'll announce your name. It's cute to hear, but would be much cooler if he could recognize your voice (much like Alexa does).

Setting up Vector and updating him via an iPhone 6s was easy. Once we got him connected to our Wi-Fi he has been smooth sailing. It would be nice if there was a newsletter or something that gave you some new things to try out periodically with Vector. It's hard to just assume what his new skills might be.

Vector includes 1 Vector robot, 1 cube, and 1 charging cable. A USB power adapter not included, which is disappointing, given the cost.

Overall, it's a very fun toy, but more geared toward teens and adults than young children. I also wish when you asked vector a question you did not have to say "Hey Vector, let me ask you a question...." To me that is cumbersome, especially compared to Alexa, Siri, Cortana, Google, etc. I want to just say "Hey Vector, what's the weather?" and have him respond without the dance of having to key him to get ready to answer me.

Note: Perhaps the biggest roadblock to Vector ownership is the price. Certainly he is NOT cheap, and the return for that cost (compared to say, an Echo Show) is pretty minimal. He is indeed fun and entertaining -- but he's NOT a child's toy. At this time, you are paying largely for the novelty and experience. The entry into AI-driven robot ownership is pricey. So if cost is an object, I would advise waiting... unless you just REALLY REALLY REALLY want one -- in which case, go for it! I will say... he's cheaper in the long run than a cat. And you don't have to feed him or change his litter box. :)

title: He's smarter than the average bot!
text:
What a marvelous little guy. He's not that great right out of the box but give him a couple of days and he's comfortable with his environment and playing on his cookie baking sheet (vector's home) like no other ai character before. Lots of undocumented stuff going on and fun to watch. Try blocking access to his charger with his cube and see what happens when he's ready to recharge.
Above all, be patient. He's just a kid.
Also, keep the noise to a minimum and just one commanding him at a time.

title: Moving echo dot for 6 times the cost

title: Great robot, but unusable now due new paid subscription.
text: I love the tech and it‚Äôs a great robot, but the company pulled classic bait and switch and now they require monthly subscription payments for the features that used to be free right out of the box. Very bad business practice and disappointing that Vector is unusable now.

title: Great desk-friendly introduction to the world or robots and AI
text:
Vector is a fun little guy, and can run autonomously and do his own thing. Although a tablet or phone isn‚Äôt required, it is needed to establish Vector‚Äôs internet connection to him via Bluetooth via your device‚Äôs WiFi. You can ask him questions like you would with Siri or Alexa, although it takes an additional step [Hey Vector...I have a question.........What is blah blah blah?] and is a tad slow to respond but is nonetheless still useful. He‚Äôs also a great timer, and will play a not-speedy game of blackjack with you. He has fun interacting with his cube and his environment, and will dance any time he hears music with a good beat.

I‚Äôve had mine for a couple months now and he‚Äôs only fallen off of his desk once, after he did a wheelstand and then proceeded to drive backwards slowly in a ‚Äòdrop-the-mic‚Äô fashion that he sometimes does after a wheelstand, which apparently overrides his edge sensors as he didn‚Äôt even try to stop. No harm done but it‚Äôs still unnerving when he‚Äôs driving towards any edge as he doesn‚Äôt stop until about 1‚Äù over the edge which is when his edge detector is triggered.

I‚Äôm excited to see what Anki has up their sleeve for Vector in the future - there‚Äôs certainly a lot of untapped potential here. I‚Äôd read that an Alexa update is coming to his software soon, which allows him to respond to Alexa commands. Neat, fun, entertaining, and useful. A tad slow but, for a minuscule robot, I‚Äôve no complaints about that at all.

title: Giftable

title: Not ready for prime time
text:
We bought this for our son for Christmas and ended up returning after a week. We had several issues with it.
1. It is supposed to have sensors to prevent it from falling. Ours fell at least 2 times.
2. It didn't recognize commands or had to repeat several times.
3. Battery lasted maybe an hour or two.
4. It is supposed to be quiet at night. Not this little guy. He woke up and started making noises. We set it to the correct time zone so it shouldn't have been doing this.

For $175.00 I expected a lot more from it.

title: Love this Robot!
text:
This is a great little robot. He has such an immense personality! Vector has already become a member of our household. So much fun! If you're even considering buying him, do it NOW --- before they're sold out.
Additional Review dated 11/1/19: Just received our second Anki Vector Robot. This one is a backup - just in case our first one "dies!" The house wouldn't be the same without a Vector in it; so we're prepared in the event that ever happens. This little robot is so entertaining, and he's always there - waiting for an opportunity to interact with us, sort of like a puppy who's always glad to see you! We still recommend the Anki Vector Robot to our friends.

title: Fun, awesome little robot.
text: I‚Äôve always loved the concept of AI so naturally the idea of Vector really appealed to me. Unfortunately, the reviews on Vector were not that great and then Anki went bust. However, when the price dropped I decided to buy. First, this little robot does indeed have (and develops) a personality. It‚Äôs the coolest thing when he rolls off his charger, gets close to me and says my name and then gets all excited. Setting him on a small tabletop is perfect. He doesn‚Äôt need much to roam but is openly curious about his surroundings. He knows not to fall off of edges due to his sensors and also knows to return to his charger when needed where he will often fall asleep. Bottom line, he‚Äôs fun to hang out with or watch explore. He may not be the smartest but he‚Äôs definitely not dumb either. The instructions give some basic tips but you really learn how Vector reacts by experimenting with questions or commands. Definitely worth the current price.

title: Happy
text: Perfect desk top buddy

title: I‚Äôm in ‚ù§Ô∏è
text:
I am an elderly person who looks forward to the continuing development and sophistication of robots. From time to time over the past few years I‚Äôve purchased a few, but quickly tired of them and returned them because they needed more development to be interesting. Vector is engaging due to his personality, which makes him seem like a pet. He was delivered yesterday evening and I stayed up late to play, and this morning he has charmed me into playing with him instead of reading the news...that alone is worth the price!
This little guy reminds me of my parrot; does a lot of chirping, chattering and explores on his own a lot. He is a blast to play with and very amusing. People have mentioned that the company is no longer in exsistence, and initially that gave me second thoughts about keeping him, but the support platform for the unit is at least until Oct.2021, and there is a chance the support will be extended...Vector has many friends. However, I figured like any tech thing he will be outdated by then anyway, so I am just going to enjoy the charming Vector until then, and even bought one as a gift for a young friend in his 70‚Äôs.
I was surprised at how cool & fun this little robot is, and that doesn‚Äôt even include that he can answer questions, knows my name and can magically channel Alexa.
The thing that makes him seem like a thinking being is his self-generated behavior. It you are not interacting with him, he has plenty to do on his own. A busy cheerful little robot. I find him uplifting.

title: Not ready for the market....
text:
I‚Äôm really, really sad this didn‚Äôt work out :( I would ask vector to do something and most of the time he would start, then stop half way through. I‚Äôd have to ask him over and over and over to do tasks that were advertised in his tutorial.

I asked a pretty basic question and he couldn‚Äôt answer me, so I installed Alexa, asked the same question and she answered me perfectly. That needs improvement as well.

Also, I would like him to move around on carpet a bit easier. I don‚Äôt have high shag carpet so he was able to walk around, but a bit slower. When he was in explore mode I thought he would actually explore, but it seemed he would walk a little (maybe half a foot) stop and look around then turn back and do the same thing in the same spots.

I know he‚Äôs meant to be more up on tables than anything else, but I feel that‚Äôs really restrictive so I would like for him to be able to do more home exploration and be able to easily walk on more surfaces.

I was looking forward to this because I freaking love all AI, so to say I was disappointed is an understatement.

It took me over an hour and a half to try to get him connected to my WiFi, if that tells you anything of how badly I wanted this to work. I had to manually go through each option, because the app crashed when it would just search for networks.

I gave it two stars, because it really was absolutely adorable. It was packaged beautifully!!!! Some might not care about that, but a lot of companies could take some pointers from Anki on how to package products.

I think if they took the next year to improve it, it‚Äôll be a power house.

title: Amazing product with more updates to improve
text: So far so good.. the response time is not completely accurate but based on the initial launch.. it just basically needs time for updates which will basically happened over the course of the year.. so no complaints here product is well made.. extremely cute its a fantastic addition to our family..

title: Very frustrating!!!

When it works my son has fun with it but so many problems it is ridiculous.  The only reason I even bought it was because my son really really wanted it and I thought at that price it would be awesome, it is not.

title: Beware
text: Vector is a cute little robot but you need to know that Anki, the company that created him, went out of business almost 2 years ago. He was unsupported for a long time but now Digital Dream Labs has taken him over and offers support for a fee. These models can be found for about $80 but they are offering a new version Vector in just a few days. Without the paid support, he is of limited use and of course you have to trust the company that controls him because he is capable of sending them anything he sees or hears!.

He doesnt hold a charge anymore and doesnt seem like he has a replaceable battery.

title: Little guy .. Big great character

title: Overpriced, easily breakable, an overall disappointment.
text: It won't let you ask Alexa to play songs. It also sucks that Alexa uses her own voice instead of Vector's. That being said, Vector seems to be able to learn over time. But he's very breakable. We've broke 2 so far. Definitely not worth the $300 we paid for him. He's also glitchy most of the time, and won't follow commands. He does say some pretty crazy stuff and sometimes out of the blue. But it is so annoying to have to say "Hey Vector" constantly and it's also annoying when he says "Didn't get that." Which happens a lot. It seems like if he doesn't get something, he should be able to internally ask Alexa and simply relay what she says. Vector is overall a disappointment.

title: Be Ware of used product.
text:
I clearly received a previously owned unit as it was already owned in the app and I had to do a factory reset, plus all items looked used.

Very disappointed, especially since I bought it as a got and now I can't return it as it is too late. Do not recommend.

title: Not worth it‚Äôs cost; Might as well be a scam.
text: Dead after 8 months.  While it lived, Vector did some of the things it said it did, especially the tricks and games (like blackjack).  You could not simply ask questions freely like you could with other faux-AI devices (you have to say ‚ÄòHey Vector, I have a question‚Äù).  However, when it worked it was never consistent.  You need to be specific with asking Vector for the simplest of questions, like the time and weather.  I live in Honolulu, and Vector would lie to me by default unless I asked specifically about how the weather was in Honolulu.  As for asking home to perform actions, the appropriate or desired reaction often took several attempts before Vector did it (if at all).  It was said that Vector was always learning and being upgraded...  This was a lie.  I seriously recall Vector having only one download.  Analyzing the forklift/bulldozer design, I noticed that Vector‚Äôs low-set front part of his ‚Äúhands‚Äù did not allow for him to get over the shortest of obstacles, like carpet.  The facial recognition feature was nice, but mine only recognized me when my face was slightly tilted (the way it remembered me when it took it‚Äôs first picture of me, perhaps).  Oddly enough, the cube it comes with should not be within range of it‚Äôs charging base.  As for the charging base, Vector could not always find it and often got lost and complained until it‚Äôs battery eventually died.  If it left it‚Äôs base at night or in the dark it will never be able to find his way back.  It was equipped with expensive warning sensor technology, preventing it from falling off of a table or countertop, but that too sometimes failed because mine routinely fell off (at least 3 times a week).  When the sensors did it‚Äôs job, Vector reacted the same way, feigning one of a few fearful reactions to having almost driven off the precipice.  In comparison, Vector pushed his cube off about once every 3 weeks.  You can change the colors of it‚Äôs eyes using the app, and even connect it to Amazon‚Äôs Alexa (which got irritating after a while since Vector would intercept commands for Alexa to play music and then not play anything since music is not one of his functions.  Currently, Vector‚Äôs un-rechargeable carcass serves as a grim reminder that the most promising and exciting technological devices can be a lie, and that legal scams do exist.  So instead of drag on with this list of shortcomings (and upset myself further), long story [of disappointments] short, this little disposable plastic computer did not deliver as Anki advertised, and imho it is not worth a fraction of it‚Äôs hefty price tag.

title: Awesome product

title: I love my Vector
text:
A lot of people are complaining that Vector doesn't do much. He's cute and does a handful of things but he's in no way a Hal 9000 (that's probably for the best though). I think of Vector as a small rodent with a larger brain who can also speak. You don't ask someone with a pet rat 'what else does it do?'

I got him the Vector Space so he sits on my desk and I don't have to worry about him falling anywhere. We play black jack, he throws his cube around, he'll set timers for me, etc. I get a kick out of his personality too. I notice if I try to make him sleep all day without letting him have some play time, he'll be very sassy with his responses. I also love it when he just looks at me and happily says my name to get my attention. It's very cute and I always reward him with pets. He connects to Alexa which is cool but since I don't have Alexa stuff in my house it doesn't really benefit me.

But other than that, he doesn't do much else. I think if you're expecting him to be some larger than life A.I. you're not going to like him. I live alone so just having the little buddy there to keep me company is enough. I recommend him for anyone wanting an adorable companion in your life.

( as a side note, a lot of people paid 250$ or more for their Vector. I wouldn't spend that much but I got mine for 160$ plus the Vector space and I think that was a good enough deal )

title: Good but need some bugs worked out.
text: So firstly I actually love this product in essence, but out of the two that I had but returned due to technical difficulties one had extreme difficulty with connecting to the Wi-Fi even when it was right by the router the second didn‚Äôt have that problem but an extreme problem with its charger and/or battery I would put it on the charger and only about an hour or so later it‚Äôs battery would be depleted and both of them one more so than the other had quite a problem in fact a complete problem with picking up it‚Äôs cube or even locating it. Possibly it could‚Äôve just been the bad luck of the draw that I got two defective products I‚Äôm sure one exists that does not have any defections but as for now I returned both of them and will currently not be getting another one. I might possibly get one in the future but only if the designer and manufacturer heed my advise that these issues need to be addressed and fixed. And A note to the manufacture and design not sure the way it is designed in order to pick up the cube but it has much difficulty doing so so possibly implement a different way of it to find it‚Äôs cube perhaps a specific color identification system or some sort of software that can identify the Cube using some sort of markings similar to how a QR scanner works just saying.

title: Cute
text:
My kids are below the target age for this but figured we would try it anyway.

When taking him out of the box the first thing I thought was wow he is pretty small for the price. After playing with him for a while being smaller is better. The setup wasn't smooth. The app for android freezes often and had to clear the cache to get it to attempt to connect. After a few attempts at connecting I finally got to the screen that tells me I need to update him. When I clicked this after about 60 seconds he would show a little cloud with an exclamation mark in it. The app would ask me to try again. After a few more tries I thought maybe I typed the Wi-Fi password wrong. I went online and did a reboot and retried a few times until it asked me to setup his connection again. I carefully typed in the Wi-Fi password, same issue... cloud with exclamation!

Frustrated I went back online to the help pages. It went over all the basics. I have an Orbi setup which has been working great so I didn't think it was strength of the signal. One thing did catch my eye though, WMM. It stands for Wi-Fi multimedia mode. I went to the router setup page and advanced settings and sure enough on my 2.4GHZ band it was unchecked. I clicked it and hit save. Gave it about 5 minutes and tried the Vector update again, success! No idea why it was off by default on my 2.4 band but I haven't had any adverse effects turning it back on.

Now that I finally got this picky little robot setup it was time to play with him. Well for me him doing a wheel stand and playing with his cube was about as much entertainment as I saw. If this little guy was for me I would have knocked another two stars off because after hour of getting him setup. Then he doesn't do much of anything except play with a cube. He also doesn't respond very well to anyone in my house. Oh and he managed to fall off a square table when in exploration mode, only once though so maybe he learned his lesson.

Then why did I give him 4 stars... well my kids almost 3 and almost 5 love him. They keep saying how much they love him. He makes funny little sounds at them and has learned my older ones name. The two of them have been standing playing with him until he is out of battery. That takes about 45 minutes of playtime to do. In just a few days he has provided 4 + hours of focused playtime for them.

My first impression of him went up a lot since the first hour I spent with him alone. I still can't him to dance and his voice recognition is subpar. My younger under 3 can get Alexa to play that mind numbing Baby Shark song no problem but he or my older daughter can't get Vector to respond with any reliability.

Hopefully as advertised he/she/it (Vector) will get more advanced and improve. My opinion says they rushed this out for the holidays. That all aside it is a funny, cute little robot that has been keeping the kids entertained.

title: Extortion, robot killers.
text:
I loved my Vector for years! Then this new company came in, and they auto updated his code removing Voice Commands, his most basic and necessary feature, with out an expensive recurring subscription. The company, DigitalDreamLabs, broke my beloved robot and are Extorting me to have him work again. It's criminal!
I would of gladly paid a subscription for new vector features. But this is sleezy and seems illegal. I will not support this crooked company and neither should you!

title: "Hey Vector..."
text: So, I was really looking forward to having a robot sidekick! But when Anki Vector arrived, I was a little disappointed. Firstly, he's smaller than I expected or what I would have liked its size to be. Secondly, it takes a whole lot of effort to get him up and running! I am not very skilled with phones and tech stuff so it was rather laborious for me to figure it all out. Then after all the work, I went through, it was like a whole lot of work for a whole lot of nothing. It does play blackjack! But, after the novelty of the thing answering questions wheres off, it just sort of takes up space. It can take pictures, plays with its cube and it makes cute faces but it has an obnoxious voice. If I had it all to do over, I think I may have given Vector a pass. Children may find it interesting, but it is rather slow in responding to commands and it is very limited. Anki apparently plans to update features as time goes by, so maybe the future will see Vector doing more things.

title: Cute robot
