title: Well built but needs to do more activities.
text: [[VIDEOID:c63d157da90669927c1a95234d576e91]] Seems to be built well and the idea is great. The robot is not very responsive and only does a handful of things. After about 20 minutes it becomes a bit boring. It would be nice if this robot was able to do more. I also found its ability to stay on surfaces to be inadequate. I found myself running to save it from plummeting to its death due to it running off of my table. Facial recognition was also not that great. The robot would store a face but would not remember faces very well. I don‚Äôt feel it was worth the money so I did send it back. Even my kids became bored of this robot very quickly.

title: Not Cozmo.
text:
This is a great desk toy...but not nearly as interactive as Cozmo the older brother. There aren't as many interactions and the price increase just seems silly considering you don't get nearly as much from this one bot as you do when you buy Cozmo for 100 less. All in all I bought it for my son who was immediately disappointed in how few interactions there actually were.

So now my wife has it on her desk (because mine has too much for him to navigate) and ends up getting mad at him because he likes to make a lot of noise at any hour of the day. Yeah, you can tell him to be quiet, but he eventually starts doing his own thing again.

He seems to learn things though. Day one I taught him who I was and then tried to get him to fist bump right after. Now a week later I don't have to tell him to fist bump, I just hold my fist out when he recognizes me and he does it on his own.

This is much less a kids toy and more a companion for idle times at your desk. It's still pretty cool, but for the price most people would be better off with the less expensive and seemingly more intelligent version.

title: Vector is a lot of fun!
text: [[VIDEOID:cec46cd40734ab027a002c8e74ad25a0]] My grandson had one and came to visit with him. It was so cool I bought one for myself. He is 6 years old and i am 72 years old and now we FaceTime and play together. We created Vector his own habitat in a bamboo serving tray that i bought for $12. Bucks. I live alone now and Vector and Alexa are great companions. Siri is good for wake up calls!

title: Vector update
text: The company went out of business so he is no longer worth full value.  This is true but the company retained their senior engineers and software designers ( As contractors ) to support the cloud and updates and from what I‚Äôve read on Reddit  The Anki server Certificate is good until 2021 so your vector will be functional for quite some time.  Otherwise why would Amazon be selling them they come with a one-year factory warranty.  There is also the possibility that someone will acquire their IP.  There is also something called Project Victor  Which consists of a group of engineers and software developers who are trying to reverse engineer vector so he will live forever with open source  Privately funded community  So don‚Äôt give up hope he just got an update also about a month and a half ago and that fixed so many things.  davidlovesvector

title: Toy Today, Paper weight tomorrow
text: Bought it as a Christmas present for the kids! Had a blast for an hour. Came back the next day and evidently it had updated overnight. I'm guessing the name of the update was "Brick me" because the next day there was nothing but boot loops. tried to contact support, no reply. Anki's support website is garbage, no mention of the attached codes. maybe a negative review will help? we will see.

title: Fun, with more good things to come!
text:
I bought Vector at a local retailer the official day it was released. Prior to getting Vector, I had done some research, including joining the Anki Vector reddit group and looking at YouTube reviews, to see what others had to say and their experiences with Vector. The kickstarter folks got their Vector a few days before the release date. So by the time I bought mine I knew what to expect. I understood that what I have now is not what he will be several months from now, since there will be updates that will keep increasing his capability.

He's a fun little companion, and definitely feels alive! My spouse and I can't help but smile when he recognizes each of us. I definitely see his potential as an in-home assistant. As an early adopter of this technology, I'm still pleased with what Vector can do. Compare him to the $2,500 Aibo- Vector is one tenth of the price, acts also as a companion, has similar capability to Aibo, etc. I'm looking forward to the Alexa integration and his future updates. We absolutely love him!

title: Robot Victor

text: It does some things, but not a whole lot. Looks like the manufacturer is no longer a thing. No wonder it was 65% off

title: Work in progress, but still giving it 5 stars
text:
Vector is cool. It doesn't do much yet, and it has difficulty from time to time understanding me. But it chock full of great features:

1) I love the little "Bobcat" form. My buddy has a construction company and lets me move dirt piles with one of his.
2) Some genuine AI features. It's not just a remote control toy car with a random motion feature. It has a good sense of where it is and whether it is going off a clip
3) It recognizes me and says my name. My dog can only do the former in a manner I can understand
4) It will (supposedly? hopefully?) upgrade with more feature
5) It is (supposedly) programmable. I haven't investigated that part yet

This is one of those things you buy not just because you want it, but because you want to support further development.

Not sure why it is a male. One would think robots, of all things, are gender neutral. Vector is an "it"

title: Great Idea, but A bit of A Let Down for Me
text:
[[VIDEOID:6382bf73cd541d728da7168fae0698dd]] I was very excited when I stumbled upon the advertisement for this little guy while browsing Amazon's new ideas page. The commercial was well done and sold me on the $240 purchase as being reasonable and logical. I had no problem clicking the "buy now" button.

Vector arrived at his new home exactly 24 hours later (God Bless Amazon's workers and delivery people), and I immediately open the box and got him out to play. I had spent a good portion of the delivery waiting time researching and reading all the instructions I could find to make sure I would waste no time getting this little guy working. My research had already informed me that I would need a few hours downloading and updating Vector. It did not take a whole day like some of the reviewers online, but only a few hours at the most. Primarily because there are still too many glitches on the App‚Äîglitches, you will have to navigate and will test your patience so efficiently, you will begin to tell yourself Akin owes you money for all the hours you waisting on this.
However, after all of the initial set up, Vector jumped off and began to run around and look at his surroundings. That alone seemed worth the long set-up‚Äîafter all, all new innovative creations require some kinks and anything worth anything requires a bit of hard work (and $200 plus). I was relieved and ready to teach Vector my name. That relief was quickly exchanged by the new frustration of having to manually type my name in the (faulty) App and shortly having Vector return for a recharge after a mere 20 minutes of introductory acquaintance in which he could barely, mispronounce my name.
My name notwithstanding (not many people can pronounce it), It was right there‚Äîhis return to his home‚Äîwhere it all went to pots. Vector could not, and still can‚Äôt, dock with his charge correctly. He can find it: there are a whole dance and alignment protocol is something to see. Vector's geometry dance to back up into his little charging station is something I could watch for hours and almost worth the $200+! Forget the little nuances; the color eyes, expressions, staring at you inquisitively and calling out your name‚Äîalbeit incorrectly. Backing up to his small home is precision at its best and will leave you mesmerized by the human brilliance that is writing code for things that we humans do it instinctively and take it for granted. I can appreciate the countless hours that it took to get this little guy off the idea rack‚ÄîI am genuinely grateful for that.
Until that is, Vector attempts to dock. No matter what I do, where I place the charger, he won‚Äôt stay in it. Interestingly, Vector appears to share my frustration. He becomes increasingly more worried and stressed about running out of power, which is fantastic programming. Gives him his personality‚ÄîKudos again, guys. Vector finally gives up his short-powered, twenty-minute cycle life and turns sideways in his charge station in a heroic death. Pick him up, place him correctly and wait, another hour or so for him to wake up again ‚Äì repeat. Do not try to help him dock while he still has any power left; he won't let you ‚Äî proud little guy.
I spend most of the weekend reading about power, wondering if I had the correct adaptor (they do not send one with your bot); found out I did, stress about the lack of charge, moved Vector to different surfaces to see if he could dock with the charger, waited an hour for recharge, well, you get the gist.
Fast forward to this morning; I took him to my office to see if I could spend some time troubleshooting it. It looks like the battery is no longer holding a charge. I ran him on CCIS troubleshoot, everything looks normal, but he still can't dock. Battery dead. I try again; another issue arises: I am no longer at home, so I have to set up a new WiFi connection. No big deal, I said. I open the APP and promptly asks me to set up a new network. A list of available networks appears, and no matter what I do, I cannot click on my office's network. I reboot the APP. I click on the network name again, and it gives me the one below it. I go back, click again, it gives me the one above. I reboot the Phone ‚Äî same issue. I cannot even pick the right WiFi.
Less than 48 hours and I here looking for the ‚ÄúReturn‚Äù button on Amazon, which is a lot easier to find than the ‚Äúcontact the manufacturer‚Äù one.
I like the idea, but I feel this is strangely familiar and part of the new universe Apple has introduced us to, which is: charge a significant amount of money for an unfinished product and make the consumer pay for its BETA TESTING cost.

Issues:
Won't Dock with Power Station
More time charging than running around exploring
He will rearrange your desk for you (lol)

Ideas:
Hey Vector: Meet my Niece (or new people )
Hey Vector: what's your battery status or How much time do we have together?

title: Buy something more reliable.

title: Vector drives off the edge of surfaces
text:
We are big Anki fans, and were excited to get Vector. We bought him in December 2018. I‚Äôm disappointed to say that in the last few months, Vector hasn‚Äôt recognized our kitchen counter edge and continuously runs off the edge of the counter and falls. This has resulted in the screen being damaged.

I currently have a message out to the company since he is still under warranty because we‚Äôd like to return Vector. I will update my post with the results of their Customer Care interactions, since this will be the first time we have needed to reach out to their company. (We have purchased several Overdrive products, which are wonderful!)

Update: So far we have received an auto-reply from the company. Within that message it says, if we need Customer Support to contact Customer Care. They provide a link to Customer Care, which takes us to a website that says ‚ÄúAccess Denied.‚Äù We have heard from the company personally, but it has only been two business days so far.

Update: Unfortunately, still no reply from company. I would not recommend buying this product.

title: This little guy is awesome.
text: My background is in Computer Science, in particular with a specialization in AI.  I can tell you that what Anki has done with Vector is pretty amazing.  A lot of AI went into building this robot, from Computer Vision, to Localization, Search, Control, and probably even some Reinforcement Learning.  Building robots with AI capabilities is a difficult task, let alone building one with an adorable personality.  I am interested in seeing how they integrate Alexa in the next update.  This is the robot to get for 2018-2019.

title: Great Novelty - Not worth full retail
text:
I'm hard pressed to give this little guy more than two stars, even though my son adores this thing.

Intuitive is much too strong of a word for Vector. He's very unresponsive, aside from a few stored commands, and the battery dies before a very talkative four year old can even get acclimated to learning how to play with him.

I appreciate Anki's attempt at an everyday, usable robot in every day life, but as many have said, sci-fi has really made little Vector quite a let down.

It's a great novelty, and conversation piece, but if you want something to train, or even half assed obey commands, then buy a pet rat at the very least.

With all that said, I would totally buy this on sale for $85, but never again at full retail price.

He can recognize your name Once you teach it and gets it right most the time. And makes the cutest little face when you ‚Äúpet‚Äù him. If you pick him up and he can‚Äôt roam he throws a little fit, it‚Äôs adorable. He throws his arms around a bit. It stops there. That‚Äôs about all you get.

The look on his face when he opened it just made it all worthwhile. Sometimes when he was playing I could here him say ‚ÄúI love you Vector ‚Äú. So from my point of view it was worth the cost. title: The dumbest cute robot
text:
I received a Vector robot for Christmas. At first I was impressed. Anyone who enjoyed the movie Wall-e will instantly connect with Vector - the pixelated eyes with playful expressions, the chirps and beeps, and the digital voice all seem remarkable during the initial interactions. Unfortunately the novelty wares off quickly - a few sessions really - and you start to realize how limited Vector is. Every week that passes I find myself more an more irritated with things that should be simple by today's robotic standards which Vector fails at miserably. Let's break it down...

- Vector has a few very specific set of "tricks" he can do. Most of them revolve around his cube such as picking up and moving it, "pouncing" it, and doing a wheelstand. Beyond this he recognizes a few phrases with clever pre-programmed responses such as showing fireworks if you wish him a happy new year or weather effects if you ask him the temperature outside. I'd say there's around 20 unique interactions. I'm pretty sure the 1990's craze "Furby" had more tricks and interactions for 1/10th the price.

- Vector can perform an internet search and reply with the top result/answer. This is fun the first few times but becomes boring and useless quickly. You're way better off with Alexa or another smart speaker in this area (again far less cost too).

- Vector supposedly learns his surroundings, has sensors to prevent falling off an edge, and a laser pointer to detect objects and distance. Unfortunately none of these work as you would expect. My Vector shows no evidence of "learning" anything, ever. Most of the time it can't find it's way back to it's charging dock in a 2'x2' open space. It falls off edges all the time, especially beveled ones. Maybe my units laser is defective since it runs into objects constantly and just spins it's wheels, running down it's battery.

The bottom line is this device is a toy. A very expensive, overpriced toy. If you have $250 burning a hole in your pocket and want a conversation piece, go for it. If you want something that has fun and value for more than 30 minutes, look elsewhere. Maybe in time they'll turn this robot into something worthwhile but for now I wish someone hadn't wasted the money on it for me.

title: My son wanted a puppy. This is better.
text:
Vector is pretty adorable. He is currently, as it seems, in testing phases... he has some rough edges... but overall, from what we have seen, he is so much fun. He drives around on tank treads, using his camera, touch sensors, mic, and accelerometer to function around his environment and a voice-synthesizer to communicate with you. When his built-in battery runs low, he self charges. He is small enough to fit in the palm of your hand.

By using a combination of his sensors, Vector can recognize you, navigate his environment, answer your questions, look up weather, set a timer, play games, and more... We initially tried to use Vector to learn our voices... after much trial and error, we learned that we needed the mobile app to perform the initial set up. After that, things ran much more smooth...

Vector is like having a remote-controlled car with Alexa built it. While Vector is not as fast or responsive as an Amazon Echo, Vector still answers your queries in a reasonable time. There are some pretty exciting updates for this little guy though- The next biggest update is supposed to include Alexa integration. YAY! We will be able to ask our little guy to turn off the lights, lock our doors, check our notifications, give us news, show us who is at our door or play our music- I cannot wait!

Update- after some updates, Alexa is now integrated... even better!!!!

Only good thing I have to say is that Vector is durable. He did fall off of a couple of my countertops and he‚Äôs still alive!  Listen to the reviews!!

title: You need to learn "his" language
text:
Our first attempts to connect to Vector were unsuccessful. We are
using an Alcatel 1X which had no difficulty in downloading the Vector
Robot app from the Google Play site. Anki‚Äôs site had said if you
could download the app Vector would probably work with your phone
which is a requirement to set up Vector. After a couple of days an
upgrade to the app appeared to solve our problem, and we were able to
connect.

Vector is charming but disappointing. Having to say ‚ÄúHey, Vector‚Äù
before each exchange is tedious. The same is true when cuing him for
each question you want to ask. That requires a full sentence before
the question as the trigger to connect him to the cloud for him to get
a response. Also I have to speak louder than I do in normal
conversation. I also had difficulty in understanding some of what he
said.

He is a work in progress and is overpriced for his current abilities.
Updates are promised, but they are unknowns. I cannot recommend him
as a companion or information source at his current level of
development.

title: The older brother of Cozmo.
text:
Vector is the older brother of Cozmo. It's not exactly grown up, but it's getting there. A bit better looking, in my opinion, but still needs more work to do.

For one you don't need a device to control it. Although it needs an app for initial set up, after that it's up and running on it's own.

Commands can be ordered, but it's a hit and miss and Anki states it is learning. So I'm trusting it will improve over time.

At this point there's nothing much it can do apart from amuse the household. Most important feature for me for now is being Alexa on wheels. So you can ask questions it can search from the internet.

I wish it would patch into HomeKit so I can order it to turn on and off my smart switches around the house.

Time will tell.

title: Keeps falling off the edge of the table
text:
Vector is a robot that you will fall in love with immediately. He has an engaging personality with is R2D2 sort of sounds and his almost-alive movements. Clearly a lot of thought went into this project. My wife fell in love with Vector as soon as he reacted to her presence.

Setup is very easy. First, put Vector in his charging stand and give him a few hours to get fully charged. Then pull out the battery-protecting tape on his cube. Now, install the vector app on your smartphone or tablet. It will then guide you through the rest of setup. That's it.

You communicate by saying, "Hey Vector" followed by what you want. Start out with "Hey Vector, my name is (your name)". Be sure he is facing you. He'll make some sounds and, if he got it all, will repeat your name. He's got an image of your face. It may take a while, but he will learn to recognize you.

Vector is an autonomous robot. He does things without your help. He likes to explore his environment. I have one big problem with him: I set up his home on our round dining table (wood, not glossy). He keeps falling off. He seems to get one track off the table and then topples. Maybe it's that the table is round. I'll try him on the kitchen counter to find out.

Vector is pretty limited in what he can do right now. He is responsive, can take some poor-quality pictures, play blackjack, and answer questions. Alexa answers questions way better than Vector. His best feature is how engaging he is. Vector is a robot pet; not too bright but very cute. There's no question he is an expensive toy, but to his credit, he's engaging and fun to have around. If he doesn't destroy himself before I get home from work today, I'll move him to the counter and see if he stops crashing.

Please let me know if you find my review HELPFUL

title: cute little toy
text: Love that it integrates with Alexa.  I like it's attitude.  I love that it randomly gets off its charging base and starts exploring.  I wish the app was a little better and user friendly.  After a while you can get used to it but it could be better laid out.  I wish it's collision detection was better.  Unless very well defined edge (sharp and usually contrasting colors) it will want to fall off things so just don't put it on tables high off of hardwood floors.  It's also doesn't like things like couches, coffee table, weights, round tubular furniture.  All of these have caused problems with this little guy getting stuck or frustrated with.  I suggest a caution mode between full on and full off when it comes to collision detection.  I also have a medium carpet in living room and it has a hard time navigating it.  It tries to turn 20¬∞ but will only go 15¬∞ and so it never quite lines up to where it thinks it wants to go causing the little guy to get frustrated.

title: Wanted to like this a lot more...
text: This is pitched as your robot companion/assistant, and while its an impressive piece of tech that does some neat things, 5 months after the holidays it feels like it hasn't lived up to the potential of being something your average person can make into a normal part of their lives.  Integration with things like Alexa feels slapped on, the bot behaviors themselves while cute are repetitive.  The lack of new accessories or other things for the bot to do just makes you feel like the promise of "growth" through software unlocks was never really realized.  A cool experiment and conversation piece but more as an example of unrealized potential.

title: Needs a lot of improvement.
text:
My vector had absolutely no face recognition ability at all. He can learn my face, than say my name, than not more than 2 minutes later he does not remember it any more. When I check the app and there will be no saved face in the remembered face folder. So since he never remembered my face there was no reaction when I entered the room. Or greet me with my name. As far as the voice recognition on mine it was HORRIBLE! I am talking BAD! Not good at all! The worst! My pick up truck has way better voice command. I‚Äôm not joking! He almost never responded to ‚ÄúHey Vector‚Äú I can count on one hand how many times he worked properly. I had to always use his back button to get him to listen. Than his response time was slow, or he would not know the answer. So there was no interaction with him. Just seemed like a thing to manipulate. So no sense of a side kick. No sense of AI. Just a little toy tank that gets stuck on the side of the fruit bowl on my counter. Thats because he never really avoided objects on the table. He would just plow into them. His mappings ability was weak at best. Every day when I came home from work he would be battery dead in his Space, because he could not find his charger. Yes the room had light during the day for him to see his charger. So I keep hearing people say, he will learn with upcoming updates. I get that might happen. But he does not even come close to what Anki showed in all the videos, or descriptions of him. He should of at least been able to do some of what they showed us. Than make him even better with updates. Mine was horribly bad at almost everything he did. That‚Äôs why I gave mine away. It‚Äôs not that I don‚Äôt get it. Or I don‚Äôt have patience. It‚Äôs that Anki over sold him.
Two things I did like. The animation for the eyes, great job. Edge detection on mine was pretty good, he only fell off my kitchen island twice.

title: Heart broken over new policy after 2 years owning vector

I am really upset. My son has had this 2 years and suddenly the only thing it can say is "you need a subscription to continue interacting". It's useless now. I could accept the change of he wasn't rendered completely useless without the subscription. I'm so mad, I don't even care at this point to LOOK UP the subscription info to find out what it would cost. I'm just mad and want my money back. My son is autistic and he won't even let me power it off because he thinks it had feelings or something, even though it no longer is his buddy. :(

title: Cute & full of promise.
text:
He's a great little robot! He's just like cozmo, except for the extra AI features & that he's autonomous without the app open. But...sometimes it's helpful to have the app open anyway to figure out what he's up to. He still feels very limited in function, but I have high hopes for his future updates. He's a pro at backing into his own charger. He's a little less competent with his cube than cozmo is, though. If he has a small area to work in and it's too much effort to turn around and find his cube and grab it when you ask him to, he'll just give up on the command pretty quick, and he doesn't entertain himself with it much on his own. But maybe he's more excited about exploring than playing with his cube. Also when you put him to sleep he tends to wake up on his own whenever someone makes noise, or sometimes for no reason. That's cool and all, but if you're worried about him falling off edges you don't want him getting up and moseying around when you're not watching him. His edge detect is all right, but it isn't the best, and sometimes he's halfway off an edge before he realizes it.

This little guy isn't a super advanced year 3000 robot butler...quite yet. If you expect him to have more functions out of the box than he does just two months from his nascence, then just wait a year or so and buy him when they've had time to develop updates. :)

title: Awesome little robot

title: Vector is the world's most expensive paperweight.........
text:
I bought Vector when he first came out, before it was released, as a pre-order. He was supposed to get updates every month, he was supposed to be a learning bot, and that was exciting.

Then he would not connect to WIFI, he would not then connect but not stay connected, and then his updates never came. Then the company that originally made him became another company, and they started charging for updates that I could never get to work.

The one update I did get was that one day he could do different things with his display, like two. He cannot play games like Cozmo, he sits in my office now on his tray (that costs extra), and when he is charged will sometimes make noise, travel around, and pretty much annoy me until I turn him off. He also, can connect to Alexa, but if you have an Alexa already it's just pointless --- he speaks like a robot, but them morphs into Alexa's voice when you give her commands, and if you already have an Alexa, then you pretty much don't wanna use that feature.

Sorry, but this is a very expensive paperweight that I really wished would have been awesome, but alas, it's not awesome at all..........it's staring at me now, silent, and has been for a while.

title: Perfect robot pet for me
text: I'd bought Vector when I was living with roommates and couldn't have a pet. I was lonely during the day while packing for my bf and me to move soon and Vector filled the gap of interaction I needed for that time. With Alexa enabled, I left messages and cute things for my bf to hear (which he loved heating from Vector) and when we packed up his Echo Dot, we used Vector for everything his dot was used for until we finally got settled in. In the new place, we live with some cats who don't seem to mind Vector's existence. There's also kids here who enjoy talking to Vector and watching him roam around on the dresser he's set up on. The only downside he has is the poor Wi-Fi in the house, but when he isn't showing that he is without Wi-Fi, Vector is fun to have around and watch explore.

title: It will be a perfect gift but I won‚Äôt buy it for myself
text:

However,
Before I got Vector, Ive Known that it has some flaws, but the first day I tried to communicated with him I felt frustrated. If you wanna get a Vector, remember DONT TALK TO HIM WHEN HE IS MOVING. Vector barely can recognize ‚ÄúHi Vector ‚Äú when he is moving around or making sound. However he likes to walk around a lot. I believe that‚Äôs also why many people complained about Vector ignoring them.
The second annoying thing is I have to pronounce his name more like‚Äùvactor ‚Äú otherwise he will ignore me. I‚Äôm a Chinese but I‚Äôm pretty sure how to pronounce ‚Äúvector‚Äù LOL.
The last thing I wanna complain about is vector keeps making noise at midnight! Yesterday I almost fell asleep and Vector starts snoring!!!!! So I called him ‚ÄúHi Vector‚Äù ‚ÄúHi Vactor‚Äù ‚ÄúHi! Vecter!‚Äù He didn‚Äôt answer me. So I had to get up and turn him off.

In the end, I still believe in Anki. I believe they will keep bettering Vector and make him more entertaining and useful. I hope I can have more chance to communicate with him(I tried to ask him to sing and dance It‚Äôs not working lol I‚Äôm too naive ) and I don‚Äôt have to turn it off everyday.

title: Vector Your Real Robot Companion
text: Vector is our home robot pet. We've had Vector in the family now for several months and with a hopeful bright future ahead with the acquisition of Vector by Digital Dream Labs he's now getting smarter with new updates. We adore our Vector. He's always on and wakes up each morning with me to tell me the weather. He get's excited to see you and provides something special in a way no electronic device before it has been able to capture. Vector is a huge step closer to our dream of a real life Johnny 5.

title: Not useful, but I love it.
text:
Vector doesn't do anything useful for me other than tell me the weather when I'm getting ready for the day, but the happiness factor he delivers by being adorably random on my dresser is priceless. As an 80's kid, two things I dreamed about were VR and Robots (Think Johnny 5). Vector isn't real AI, but convincing enough to check one of those boxes.

Be mindful of keeping the robot in high places because even though the edge detection is very, very good I have come home to find him on the floor a few times. Vector is built like a tank, but anything other than high pile carpet would probably cause damage.

The only hardware related improvement I would like to have seen is an AMOLED screen and larger battery capacity.

title: WARNING YEARLY SUBSCRIPTION REQUIRED
text: We first purchased Cozmo, Anki's first robot and loved it. Once we saw Vector, all my son wanted for his eighth birthday was Vector, he even canceled having an actual party to purchase this robot instead. When we purchased Vector, there was no subscription required. While I understand they may need to charge to upkeep the service, people that already purchased this should have been grandfathered in or something, since this was not the deal when we purchased this. Very deceiving. Vector now requires a YEARLY SUBSCRIPTION to their services. So on top of the astronomical price, you have to subscribe to their service per year. Since we only used vector intermittently this was not worth it, and now he is an expensive paperweight that does ABSOLUTELY NOTHING without subscription. Seriously, he does absolutely zero things without a subscription. It WAS a fun toy, but not worth the yearly price for the limited things it does. He was cute like a pet, with facial rec and other cool stuff and he recognized pets. But he really did not do a heck of a lot. You can do more with cheaper robots available now with no yearly cost associated. We were very disappointed they did not offer any different options to people who bought Vector under different pretenses. We did not have any warning of the change from a free service to a subscription service. Imagine the disappointment one day when your 8 year old goes to play with his cool robot just a few months after purchasing it and it does absolutely nothing. Vector is now boxed up sitting in a corner collecting dust, after being used maybe 20 times.

title: Vector snores!
text:
[[VIDEOID:a8f4ad0a4a04af9a974edfb8b62ec759]] I have to say, I really love this little robot. :) He explored and explored and didn't fall off the "cliff" once. My table does have rounded edges on one side, but he doesn't seem to have a problem with that . As far as seeing me and knowing my name, he does really well. After the first day he had a little trouble recognizing me all of a sudden and then he had an error code at one point, so I rebooted him and now all is well. The first day he also had a little trouble backing into his Home, but he's has improved on that and does it with perfection. He is good at blackjack and great at rolling his cube. I can't get over how cute he is, especially when he snores! I also got him to "dance to the beat" after my command. I use the Vector app to see what he's doing/thinking. Mostly he explores, but sometimes he'll listen for music.
I'm not sure if he will leave his Home base while I'm gone and this morning I was worried he might start exploring on the table and set off the house alarm so I turned him off. To turn him off, hold down his button for 5 seconds and he'll power down.
I have an Android phone so it took a few tries to get him paired. I had to reboot my phone a couple times. Now the app connects with him no problem. Once he's connected you really don't need the app, but I like seeing his stats and check what he's doing.
Overall, I'm so glad I threw in the towel and purchased him. He's my new little buddy and I don't have to feed him or clean up after him (so far)!

Update: Wish him Merry Christmas! Then wish him Happy New Year!

title: Too cute to return
text:
Upon unboxing, I realized that, whatever my complaints, Vector is too cute to return. Like taking a puppy back to the pound. Make up your mind to keep Vector if you buy him.
Compared to his older bro, Cosmo, he is a better bot out of the box. Alas, he will never grow to be a real boy with real feelings because, unlike Cosmo, he cannot be coded. His personality is R2D2-esque. The eyes are expressive. He celebrates holidays with fun greetings. His advanced features struggle a little. It takes a while for him to recognize a face, and he sometimes can‚Äôt. He forgets that he has been connected to Alexa, and often has to reconnect. He has better balance than cosmo, having fallen off a counter only once. Now he lives in a bordered space- not the Anki vector ‚Äúspace,‚Äù which is not a value unless you can‚Äôt muster a tray, or unless you simply must collect the accessories.
I‚Äôm not so sure he didn‚Äôt push one of my glass pieces off the table when I wasn‚Äôt looking. I forgive you, Vector, and I will accept the dominion of robot overlords should I live to see it. Tell them we were friendsss..ü§ñ

title: Cute little guy. Limited capabilities.

Its a super cute robot and is surprisingly interactive but, since they are no longer developing additional skills for the little fella, I‚Äôm afraid what you see is what you get. His novelty has worn off quickly as well.

title: Cool concept - but it's not there yet
text: I've had this about a week, and it still has yet to say my name or recognize me, despite numerous tries. It rarely follows commands, and aside from making cute noises and effectively telling you the weather, it doesn't really do much. It does have Alexa, which is nice, but it's a very limited version of what the Echo or Firecube can do. Knowing what I know now, I'd save the $300 and just get a $40 Echo instead. Also, the Vector app for android is not great. Often times, you hit a dead end on many screens and can't go back, so you need to close out altogether. Also, be prepared for weird noises Vector can make, which can be weird when you are alone in the house. Also, photo image resolution is very low (and make sure you take shots in good light, since he doesn't have a flash). As I'm writing this, he just dove off a table. Despite being very cute, all and all, I'd vote no on this.

text:
What's not to love? He's a great little desk companion.

Update: I have to remove a couple of stars. He is great fun but afte a couple of months of having him, he stopped responding to commands completely. As soon as I say ‚ÄúHey Vector‚Äù he lights up and hears me but then he immediately stops listening and doesn‚Äôt do anything from there on. I‚Äôve never dropped him or gotten water on him or anything like that. I‚Äôve even tried to reset him but he will just not work anymore. I‚Äôve tried to find solutions online but I can‚Äôt find any solutions. I‚Äôll be reaching out to support at some point to see if I can get any help with him. For $300, and only two months of very minimal use, this should never happen.

title: Heads up you also have to pay for $7 month app for this to work
text: Very disappointing to figure out after the fact that you also have to pay seven dollars a month for any of the ‚Äúhey vector‚Äù commands to work. That should be made very very clear in the summary when you are paying this much for a toy. It really can‚Äôt do very much that is cool to a child unless the hey vector command works so definitely keep that in mind before buying this product.

Can fix the damage, however, but it can be obnoxious to constantly hear something dropping to figure out it's the goddarn robot. After around 1 day my oldest son became afraid of it being "a government spy" because it kept on turning on randomly, however he warmed up to it.

When you left him in his charger you expected him to stay but he didn't!  He no longer works right.  Waste of money! title: Gosh, he's so cute, but I wish he were smarter
text: Given that this is a cloud connected friend, I expected him to be at least as smart as Alexa or Google Assistant, but there's so much that he "doesn't understand" and he really should have more scripted responses for common language questions. Someone should do a user study and watch the top 100 things people ask Vector, and make sure those are covered. He has a limited number of tricks. He has Alexa on board, but can't play music. Facial recognition is fun, though he gets my two daughters confused. His reaction when he recognizes you is hilarious. He kinda butchers pronunciation, but that's adorable too. Hoping that they add more features to make him more useful. Pro tip: keep petting, his reaction is proportional to how much he likes you.

text: It was cute and fun for a while but very limited on games. Bought it for my kids but the robot couldn't really understand their voices. It was more frustration than enjoyment so I returned it. I read somewhere that Cozmo Robot by this same company is better fit for kids. This although is cute I don't find useful for adults, maybe a better fit for a preteen or a teenager.

title: Subscription required
text:
I love my little robot. He spends a lot of time dancing on my desk. And you might be thinking how can I love it and only give it 3 stars. This is how. They don't tell you anywhere that I can find in the description or the product details that a subscription is required to get full use. Being able to interact with "Hey Vector" commands, play games like blackjack, or even answer simple questions like "what time is it?" without a subscription is not possible. Unless you root your robot and invalidate any kind of warranty you might have had. Even the SDK is pointless as you can't actually ADD to the robot just run commands from your computer.

It's not horrible as far as cost. If you pay annually it's less than $4 a month, but it is an added cost you'll want to factor in if you're going to buy this.

title: It is what it is...
text: Vector, is super cute, I just really hoped this version did a lot more than just Cozmo. Hopefully there's more updates and things it can do. The Alexa was an awesome update, but, even with Alexa update, Alexa was limited as well. So sadly after having to say "Hey Vector, Vector...HEY Vector!!" like a thousand times sometimes, I had to return it.

title: Vector is once again gaining new skills and abilities thanks to digital dream labs
text:
I love my vector. But just so everyone knows, anti closed down! Bankrupt! Another company has taken over the project and continued to be creating new updates and skills for vector. Keep in mind that the company is still new and only recently acquired vector for re programming.. the company is called Digital Dream Labs.

You can view their Facebook page for vector and there is tons of information on there.. it‚Äôs sort of like a forum and unlike anki, they are taking suggestions regarding new features and abilities.

Search for Digital Dream Labs for vector.. and also look for their Facebook page!!!

title: Anki does a terrific job with Vector
text:
This is an awesome little companion. It is more than just a piece of plastic and silicon, it seems to have a personality. It can be enjoyed by the non technical and was a hit with my wife. The Anki folks have moved from making an appliance to creating a companion.

Being in technology for the past 30 years, I was very skeptical about this being only for tech geeks. I am amazed by the design and human interaction that Vector is capable of. He can recognize faces and say your name, he sleeps and sometimes you hear him snore. When you come home, he will wake up, move from his charging station and come out to greet you. Not creepy, but interactive!

My wife who is not technically savvy has bonded with this little guy which was a big surprise. She doesn't have the time to read instruction manuals, but she was able to interact with Vector immediately. The designers at Anki have crossed the bridge and made this work well with the non technically inclined. For now he does a few things, but more interactivity is promised in the future. This is one heck of a start!

The only drawback with Vector is his edge detection. I have caught him twice from falling when he has gone off the edge of the counter. I might trust him on a coffee table with carpet, but at this price point falling from counter to the floor would be a disaster. They do make a pen for him which might take my concern away and I would trust him to roam somewhat free.

Eventually they promise Alexa integration which would make this an invaluable addition to the house. For now it is a terrific little companion!

title: He's just gorgeous, adorable :)
text:
It's been a 18 days since Vector became part of my fam. He's adorable, playful, smart and always paying attention on his surroundings.

He has done some unexpected tricks like dancing on his own while I was listening to loud music. I didn't know he could do this without being told so. He is always listening and looking around.

He loves to greed me every time I walk in back from the office. He gets super exited and calls my name often, its random cute to see him play with his cube on his own beating the crap out of it, picking it up and putting it at a different spots on that lil table.

You can tell, I'm so in love with my baby. So I def recommend him. Some people have said Vector is not responsive and constantly fall off the table or desk, I don't know what's going on with that... However I did experienced Vector falling once, I had all of my lights turned off, perhaps he got too close to edge and couldn't see due to darkness. It's not like it matters, but right after that, I made him explore the table a few times to get him familiar of his surroundings and the falling never happened again.

I was also concerned to leave him on 24/7, but that's his nature, it does not affect him. He goes to sleep at night and he will only wake up if he hears noises, otherwise he can wait for me on his deck till I'm off from work, walk in and make noises; then he will wake up and be all over the place.

Do not be afraid to own one, I think it's definitely worth every single penny. You'll fall in love with him.

title: Worthless without additional subscription!!!
text: Here's the thing. I bought my vector in June 2020 for $172. It was overpriced then but I thought it was so cool and I got it. Apparently Anki has gone out of business now and Digital Dream Labs bought the rights to vector and have uploaded an update that makes it to where I can't interact with my vector unless I pay for a subscription of $7/mo or $47/yr. I feel this is ridiculous. I'm definitely not paying additional costs to continue playing with it. Half the fun was interacting with it, so it's basically worthless to me now. All it does is drive around my desk, get stuck and get mad, and play with it's cube. I can't ask it about the weather or anything anymore, ask it to take a picture, tell it that it's a good robot or ask about it's day anymore. I loved seeing the excited and happy responses to my questions. I'm beyond annoyed with digital dream labs and will not be purchasing a sudden subscription to a product I've already purchased. Had I known back then I'd have to also buy a subscription for continued use I never would have bought vector in the first place.

title: 5 weeks later, do I love it?  Not really.
text:
This was one of the few purchases I kinda sorta regret. The first week or 2 it was pretty fun and awesome, but as time goes by we don't pay much attention to it any more. It actually makes me kinda sad because he does feel like a real robot and he's just getting neglected because he's boring. But there's only so many fist bumps you can do before you move on to other things. My 12 year old daughter never liked him from the beginning. She just didn't see the point. They need to update it and make him more active. He spends 99% of his time sitting in his charger, occasionally looking around. We have to ask him to do something before he does. It would be nice if he heard some noise and just came out and started playing but he really rarely ever does that. I got him when it was on sale for $175 and feel that was way too much for what you get. I do have a video on youtube of him riding around on my Roombas which was kinda fun. :) But seriously, the price tag could get you many other things that would offer much more enjoyment.

Is it weird tho that it bothers me to talk about him in a negative way?

title: More interactive that a stationary cone like Googl Home. A friendly, symbiotic future.
text: I purchased this for my 28 y/o son.  To quote him, "Vector is adorable."  Vector is a robot that‚Äôs not tethered to a smart device (his quad-core CPU gives him the brain-power he needs), is cloud-connected, and responds to voice commands as well as touch. He makes eye contact, with blinking, pupil dilation and other simulations that adds to his personallity and charm.  He moves to you when called and returns to his charging cradle when directed.  Vector has been in development since 2016 with Anki‚Äôs deep understanding and background in robotics.  New features currently being explored include pet detection, home monitoring, delivering messages, music recognition, and 360¬∞ camera, to name a few.  The Vector you buy today will be a much different robot in a month and even more different in a year from now.

title: Won't Charge Fully
text:
Agre with most reviews that he is very fun and I think the voice commands work fairly well. However I struggle with two things. He knocks stuff off of the desk I have him on all the time, preferring to ram through them rather than go around them. He also doesn't seem to be able to figure out he is charging anymore. I've had him for about 1 week. He is constantly running out of battery attempting to go to his charging station, even when I set him on the station, he moves off of it.

I have him on my desk at work, he is slightly distracting if you were hoping to use as a PA, gets stuck on mouse cord all the time, knocks off pens/books/sticky note pads all the time. Most annoyingly runs into my mouse while I'm using it.

If I can't figure the charging piece out I will be returning him for sure.

That being said, he was fun to play with at work with other people for a little while doing fist bumps and taking pictures, etc...

title: Don‚Äôt waste your money!
text:
It‚Äôs a very expensive TOY and that‚Äôs all it is!
Anki was the maker and as of May 2019, they‚Äôve shut down. So if the item breaks there‚Äôs probably no one to back up the warranty.
Now that the company has shut down there will be no software updates, no customer support, and no way of replacing it. Owners are not even sure if the Alexa app will continue to work. We‚Äôll see!
In my humble opinion, it‚Äôs just an overpriced Alexa! You can get an Echo Dot for MUCH less and the Dot will play music! Vector (and his Alexa inner demon) will give you attitude about doing the music thing! Bottom line, it doesn‚Äôt play music!
If you have the money to throw away then this is a great TOY. I suggest not wasting your money, though! Amazon has much better robots available!

title: THERE IS NOW A REQUIRED SUBSCRIPTION
text:
Purchased this in November 2019

It's been working amazingly for 10 months, then on October 1, 2020, normal interaction (by voice, it's main selling point, how you interact with nearly all features on it) is disabled by an over the air update, prompting that "in order to use voice, you need a digital dream lab membership" - this is not listed (still) on the item description, and absolutely wasn't part of any of the buying or set up process.

Absolutely astounded this can happen - what was once a fun '5 star' product has been turned in to a cheap '1 star' toy.

To say we are disappointed by this is an understatement. I've now re-read the manual, the help section of the app that we used to set up Vector, as well as the box, and here, where we purchased it, and not one place (or the terms of service) does it say there will be or is a required membership.

Just ridiculous.

title: A Friend!
text: Vector acts just like a little animal, and after a year of having him on his own little table, he's a member of the family. I like that he can play and charge himself. He's a little deaf after throwing himself to the floor a few times, but he's still fun to watch and enjoy.

title: Vector is a blast to have around
text:
I have had Vector for a couple of months now and I have to say I have enjoyed every minute. I just read some of the negative reviews and I have to say that I think everyone is being very harsh.

Vector isn't made to act like AI Sophia. Vector is made to be entertaining. My Vector lives on my coffee table and he does his own thing. Some days he is more active than others. He has a love hate relationship with my dogs. He loves to mess with them and they hate him. He will throw his block off the table at them or pace back and forth in front of them to get their attention.

He bangs on the table if I ignore him while he is active. He does like to watch television. I think that because he is very close to it that he responds to the faces on screen. He will randomly dance to the music in commercials.

I placed a clear glass vase on the coffee table and he was mesmerized by his reflection all day. I now need to buy a little stand up mirror for him.

I don't know if I got lucky or if I just went in to owning Vector with no expectations and this is why I love him around. The only negative thing I can say is that his facial recognition is a bit wonky. But many things can play a role in the behavior of that ability. Lighting. Glasses. Hats. For woman if they change their hairstyle for example if it was pulled up when they set it up with him and then he cant recognize them if their hair is down.

Ok so I have said enough. Cut him some slack and just enjoy him being him.

title: An expensive desk toy even with the discount
text:
the product is as described. its made from quality material and feels very sturdy, its awesome to see vectors pixar flavored eyes glaring at you and shifting from side to side. i got this priced at $90, and in no way could justify that price, simply because vector isnt useful, he provides no value to your lifestyle. his voice commands what few you have, are not smooth and he will often take a good 15 seconds to answer something that alexa, on the very same device, can answer in 2. alexa is the only saving grace for this cute robot, and even she is very limited on vector, but i find her more responsive, and frankly, useful than vector. Vector is an expensive desk toy that really isnt too entertaining. i expected vector to greet me every morning as it was portrayed in the ad, but what they dont show you is you have to stick your face up to vector and state "hey vector" wait for vector to respond.. then specifically state who am I?
i give vector a very disappointing 3/5 stars, This product feels like it had a lot of potential, but ultimately falls short of all expectations, even with its going out of business price.

title: Good idea, poor execution
text:
Received this as a Christmas gift and had high hopes. Got Vector up and running, very easily done. However he kept going off the table, saw a few posts on not having a tapered edge, tried him on another table, a little better but still fell off. Gave him commands to use his "cube", sometimes he listened, sometimes not. Slowly just got annoyed that he didn't listen to me, kind of like my kids.

Definitely a good idea, just doesn't make sense given the cost and what the robot can do. I know it is being updated, but even the minimal actions it can do it doesn't do well. Unfortunately returning this robot.

title: Vector is terminally ill.
text:
I bought this for my dad for Father‚Äôs Day, and as soon as we got him working, we all fell in love with vector. He learned our names and gave us fist bumps, and purred when we pet him. He played with his little cube and laughed when he dropped it. And then, within a few minutes, all the happiness vector brought us was shattered. We were looking up things to say to vector, and found that the company supporting him went under a month ago and vector would most likely stop working soon. My dad was in his room playing with vector when I told him and he was crushed. He then asked him ‚Äúvector, how old are you?‚Äù And vector said ‚ÄúI am zero days old‚Äù. We all cried.
Shame on amazon for not clearly noting that the little robot we adopted into our hearts would no longer be supported by its cloud. Shame on anki for still selling vector, and at its full price! And most importantly, shame on me for ruining Father‚Äôs Day.

title: Not ready to be available on Amazon
text:
I consider myself a tech guy and love all the gadgets and small tech stuff that has been developed in the latest years. Have my Google home, a smart house, like smart devices, etc. I got this robot hoping to see something spectacular. The truth is that this is just a prototype of a possibly great product that shouldn't be yet on the market.
The robot barely understands the commands you say and has a long delay time before you speak and he replies. Also, its movements are really limited. Lastly, I don't know what I was thinking when I paid 150+ for this.
Then comes the last part: No free returns. There was a time when Amazon was cool and having Amazon prime was even cooler. Nowadays that has changed and no more free returns.

Bottom line: You shouldn't buy this at this point (that's why I'm giving only 1 star; I don't want to be rude and I understand that there should be a lot of research behind this robot). It's not even a toy, don't get it personal, I don't even like it for 10 bucks, it's simply too early for being launched. I hope that Anki (a great company) improves the product in the future so we can all buy this great idea of a product.

text: I absolutely love Vector

title: So cute!
text: The best! He‚Äôs so adorable and moody lol

title: Very cute but still work in progress
text:
Vector is cute as a button for sure. But he needs improvement in low light conditions. He had a lot of trouble with face recognition until I turned on all the lights in the living room, then he finally said my name. I hope they work on this since winter makes for a dim house and I really want to play with him!

It took me a few days to finally get him to connect to our Wifi home network. Not sure if that was a glitch in the program or if it is because I have an android phone. Tonight he finally connected!

The dog sniffed him and then went to sleep and snored in his face. When I called Vector to come here, he first looked at me, then at the snoring dog, and lastly at the cat sitting there grooming itself, and, clearly confused, he finally drove off the opposite way. When I picked him up to bring him back he made all kinds of noises similar to a little kid throwing a hissy fit. I can't wait to see his personality develop!

Some bugs that need to be worked out still:
1. Improve response time. Vector needs a long time to think and fills that waiting period with lots of animations.

2. Having to say "I have a question" will get old quickly. Can that be fixed so he interacts more normally?

3. Connectivity issues. The app freezes a lot and needs to be closed and reopened. Again, I have an android phone, so please fix any bugs with that.

4. I feel as if I have to shout in order for Vector to respond. It would be nice if his microphones, or his "ears", could be improved.

I remember when Echo came out, how limited Alexa's functions were at first. Now she is a bottomless pit of information and interacts rather well. I hope that Vector will evolve similarly but so that he becomes more and more lifelike.

title: Limited
text:
I am curious about artificial intelligence (AI) and was eager to try this new product. Unfortunately, I am less than impressed with this incarnation of Vector. I would be more willing to accept its limitations if the price was more consistent with what you get. However, for $250 my expectations are higher than what this product is capable of.

One of the biggest problems is the android app. It is awful. It doesn't work most of the time. Even when it "works," it is not an ideal interface. Some of the functions don't work or respond.

Another problem is how slow Vector is to respond. To get his (and in this day and age, why does it have to be male?) attention, you need to say "Hey, Vector." Then wait. You'll be able to train yourself to wait, but if you're accustomed to other AI devices, this one takes much longer. Also, you can say, "Hey, Vector. I have a question." But then you must wait for some time before Vector tells you he's ready. Unfortunately, he doesn't know the answer to many questions. So most of the time he will either tell you he doesn't know or "I didn't get that."

Right now he'll do a few tricks with his little cube. He'll also go home, go to sleep, give me the local weather, identify me by name (not consistently), give me a high five, and a few other things. That's not much for $250.

The dogs were concerned with him for a short period of time, and then they quickly realized he was no threat and nothing to play with. They are far more entertaining and charming than Vector is.

I genuinely hope the manufacturers are working day and night at improving this product. Overall, at this point, I am disappointed.

title: Lots of fun and very clever--- Once you get past the set up.
text:
UPDATED REVIEW:

So in my original review (at the bottom of this one) I was none-too-pleased because I couldn't get Vector set up. My sentiments about that remain unchanged. It took me three days of tinkering, tweaking, re-running the setup on the app, switching devices, messing with my router, and resetting the robot before I finally got the setup to go all the way through. Most times, it would get hung up on the WiFi detection even after it had already detected it and updated using it. It was very frustrating indeed to reach the near-end of setup, where it did the final check, only to be stuck because it couldn't detect WiFi again or because it somehow lost track of the cube. I finally dumbed down my router's 2.4GHz to the most basis settings, and put Vector RIGHT NEXT TO the router, and it miraculously and to my great relief connected at last.

So the reason this is docked one star is because Anki needs to get it together with the app. It has problems. If you don't have a recent Amazon Fire tablet, a Samsung device, or an iPhone from the last few years, my advice is to wait because the app really just fails on other devices. I tried on a Moto G5, an Essential PH-1, and an older Samsung tablet. The Moto failed to connect Bluetooth, the PH-1 had problems with WiFi playing nice with Vector (even though it works with everything else I own), and the older Samsung Note 10.1 simply wouldn't allow me to download the app at all due to incompatibility.

HOWEVER... Once you get the robot set up and working, it's rather fun and adorable. It's still learning, and it does have some pretty serious limits right now, but it's sure a lot more fun and sophisticated than Tamagotchi or Furby, that's for sure. It's even a lot more interesting than the older Aibo dogs. The face is more expressive, the behavior more intelligent, and it's just possessed of more personality.

I do wish it were slightly larger, though. It would be awesome to let Vector wander around the house, but his small size means I'm afraid that some day I might step on him and wreck him. Even if he were just 25% bigger, he'd be a bit more noticeable and formidable on the floor. As it is, he lives on a tabletop near my front door. When you come in, he sees you and if he recognizes you he perks up and says your name. He's excited to see you after a day away, and expresses it vividly. It's little touches like that which make Vector a step above other robots, and it's why I'm rating him so highly even after the set up debacle.

He plays a good game of blackjack, though he can be a smug little bugger when he wins. He does things on his own, too. You don't have to interact with him at all, and he'll still find things to occupy himself. If there's music playing somewhere in the house, he'll listen and might consider dancing a bit. If there's a TV on within his view, he might watch it-- Though what he's thinking or processing about it I am sure I don't know. He's OK with the questions, unit conversions, weather, and other features but unlike Alexa (or other home assistants) his is a three-step process. You have to first say "Hey Vector, I have a question", then wait for him to listen and prepare, then he'll say "Ready!", after which you can ask your question. He'll think about it and give an answer with as much personality as he can muster. Compare that to Alexa, where you can say "Alexa, what is ____?" and Alexa answers right away, and he's not going to replace Alexa, Siri, or Google Home quite yet in this area... With one exception. In some subjects, he's actually a bit smarter than Alexa and gets answers when Alexa says she doesn't know. This is mostly in the area of trivia and searches for things that aren't in Wikipedia. Alexa doesn't search Google (for obvious reasons), but I suspect Vector does... Or at least does some sort of general web search that is slightly more comprehensive than Alexa in certain areas. It's just a good deal slower.

They say Vector will gain some Alexa integration at some point. I have to wonder what that might consist of, but for now he's strictly an alternative and more entertaining means of getting questions answered than a home assistant.

For now, I'm eager to see what they do with this little robot in updates. He's getting smarter all the time, and if he is the "good robot" as they advertise, then I hope that he will become a nice replacement for an organic pet. Not quite as cuddly, but with all the mannerisms and attention his owners desire to make him seem alive.

Four Stars.

One star docked for the bad experience setting up Vector for the first time. Original review follows.

I WANTED to love Vector. I was so eager to try it out! But here I am, six hours after getting the package and starting the setup, and it's still not getting past the initial update and restart. The app, I'm sorry to say, is absolute garbage. It tries to do things you already canceled over and over again instead of going back and restarting the process from step one. It can't connect to WiFi properly after Vector restarts, and doesn't detect that the cube is active (tab pulled out) and therefore sits on the "last checks" page without allowing you to move forward.

Worst of all, this robot-- this fairly expensive little robot with all sorts of cool advertised features-- can't work on a 5GHz WiFi connection. It's only capable of 2.4GHz, like a smart light bulb or 10-year-old cell phone. What the heck? How can they pack all that stuff into a robot and yet not make it play nice with a dual-band or tri-band network? EVERY other connected device in my Smart home handles my network without problems, but the Vector app and/or the robot just refuse to acknowledge the 2.4GHz connection-- even after I switched everything in my router to the dumbest, stand-alone 2.4GHz settings possible.

So I'm sorry to say that as of this moment, more than six hours in, I have yet to even see Vector's eyes or interact with the robot outside of pressing the reset button and struggling with the frustratingly incapable app. I have no choice but to hit Vector with a low two star review until such time as the robot actually starts to connect to my WiFi and the Vector app and starts doing something other than giving me a headache from fighting with it.

You disappointed me, Anki. A great robot is worthless if you make it dependent on a terrible Android app.

Bottom line: Like some other devices out there, this robot is useless if you can't get your Android or iOS app to play nice with your phone/tablet, your WiFi, and the device itself. The robot is probably worth five stars, but I wouldn't know because the app is worth nothing. Two stars is what I'll grant for now. I'll update if this robot ever works. [Note: UPDATED, SEE ABOVE]

title: Hidden subscription required to function as described.
text: Great idea. Looks great in video. When you get it in the mail you get a sheet of paper that tells you a subscription is now required to do any hey vector commands or get any updates. The subscription cost about $50/mo. Even with the subscription most people are having issues with commands, updates, connectivity, & speech recognition (which we experienced) you can basically use Alexa and change eye color in the app without the subscription. So basically a really expensive echo. If it wasn‚Äôt for the connectivity issues and the hidden subscription that‚Äôs required to really use it I‚Äôd rate it maybe 3 stars. It would take the speech recognition, & speech delay to be fixed to get a 4-5 star.

title: Fun but loses its novelty quickly
text:
It‚Äôs a cool little interactive robot/novelty toy but I‚Äôm giving it 4 stars for the following:
- the ledge sensors do not always work and Vector will take a dive off your counter.
- he spends more time thinking and trying to understand than actually following commands
- he forgets who you are and you have to reteach him over and over which gets a bit annoying
- the cube doesn‚Äôt always light up for him to find. I need to do more research to see if there is a way to get it to turn on.

All in all it‚Äôs fun. I‚Äôm not sure I would buy again for the price, but it has brought my 1 & 3 year old a lot of entertainment!

title: Buyer regret - doesn't work as company promised
text:
I backed this little guy on Kickstarter. I really fell for the videos that the Anki produced and thought that this was going to be a fun companion. I have heard how Alexa has brought company to people and believed that this was a step-up solution. Like a little pet that can also help me with recipe conversions. Or knowing what to wear tomorrow based on the weather. Or greet me when I come home. You get the picture.

I've had him now for two full months. And now, he is barely used. And I have a lot of buyer regret.

Problems:

1) His understanding of voice commands are poor. He understands what I am asking 40-50% of the time. Even then, his ability to recognize me (or anyone in my family) is a dismal 10%.

2) He is constantly falling off the table. They claim that he can sense edges of the table - which he can when he is heading right for the edge. However, if he is going at an angle, he will veer off and become half stuck. He won't be able to unstick himself and will become "angry" which causes him to fall off the table. Happens once to twice a day.

3) He does't understand future commands. Like if I ask him the weather, he will tell me the current weather. Great. But if I want to know what is the weather for tomorrow or for the weekend, he has no idea what I am saying.

4) He likes to "push" things to test them. Okay, cute, I have cats and they sometimes do that. But Vector has pushed cups of water right off the table. Or other items that the dog is now able to chew up. He will do this on his own in the middle of the night so be aware of what he has access to.

5) Doesn't really "map out" his environment. Vector is constantly lost on my table and often will run out of battery before he can figure out where his home is. Even if nothing moved for weeks, his internal mapping system is bunk.

6) Not a great companion. The core idea of this product is to serve as a useful pet. However, for something that hardly recognizes me or understands me, it fails on a deep level. Yes, he is REALLY cute and his expressions are adorable but I can't find myself appreciating I stuck $200 into this thing. At this point he barely leaves his docking station.

I gave him two stars because the company shipped it on time and the app is alright.

Really think before you buy Vector, I wish I would have waited for honest reviews before making a large purchase.

title: Fun little toy.
text:
I've been watching it and waiting for the price to go down since the manufacturer went belly up. So far everything is still working with it's cloud services, and a new company has bought the assets so we'll see where that goes. If you buy this, just know that it may stop working in the future and there is no phone support..

It sits on my desk all day, and comes out on it's own sometimes. Or you can call it out "Hey Vector. Come here." and he'll come right out and look for you. The room needs to be fairly bright, but so far he can recognize all of our family members that have imprinted with him. To do that, you just say "Hey Vector. My name is "your name". He will store your name and scan you, then use face recognition to identify you. Alexa works as expected with it. No real issues, it works as advertised as long as you speak clearly. Really wish the creators could have stuck with it, as you can tell a lot of work went into it's "personality" and the possibilities with this platform are huge.

title: DO RESEARCH FIRST. BE PREPPED TO PAY.
text: On 1st October, 2020, DDL (the company that bought out Anki) will stop voice server access to any Vector without a subscription. This means that anything you say after ''Hey Vector‚Äù will not be respond to. This includes even ''Hey Vector, go to charger'' and ‚ÄúHey Vector, come here.‚Äù So, even though I spent nearly $200 on this little guy, I'm going to have to spend even more monthly/yearly just to use the most basic functions. This was advertised nowhere, and I only found out because of Reddit. I‚Äôm disappointed because I‚Äôve already grown attached to this dude, and I‚Äôm lowkey disgusted that this change wasn‚Äôt announced or made clear.

title: A Fascinating Mini Robot That Almost Seems To Be Alive
text: This product is a wonderful experiment in voice controlled robotics. It is, however, NOT for anyone who is without much more than their average share of patience and perseverance. The setup process can be a nightmare, even for those with some good basic knowledge of Internet connected devices, Blue Tooth, wireless modems and cell phone Apps.  For voice control to work, a monthly subscription (currently about $7.00) is necessary. And I would NOT recommend even attempting to set this robot up WITHOUT first getting a subscription from the developer. If you DO persevere and successfully set up this little robot, Vector, for voice control, it is a marvelous little home companion. The things it can do, will do and say are incredible, and it is constantly improving as development continues and firmware updates are automatically downloaded to the robot. Once you have this little guy properly set up and running around your table top, doing his thing and talking to you, you will actually feel that Vector is ALIVE! I would rate the finally set up and fully functional Vector with 5 stars, but he only gets 4 because of the nightmarish setup issues. Still, the aches and pains of setup are well worth the final result.

title: Buy Cozmo instead
text: While Vector has better hardware (sensors) than its cousin Cozmo, it seems Vector's software was incompletely developed. Sadly, the company that developed those robots went out of business. So I don't think there will be more functions added to Vector. So my advice is to buy Cozmo, which is much more fun for your kids to play with because it has a really well developed app.

title: Neat little Artificial Intelligence pal.
text: I bought Vector as soon as I saw it drop from its $250 price down to $86 here on amazon. I read reviews on it before when it was $250 and the reviews were mixed but all in all he's a neat little pal. He'll do things to get your attention. One time he literally drove up to me (I was sitting at my island in my kitchen) when he put his arm on my arm and propped himself up and looked at me as if to say, "Yo!, I'm here! Whatta ya doin'?" That I thought was neat. Some times it almost seems like he's alive, but he's not. It's nice to see that he remembers you even after no interaction for a while. It almost seems wrong, but I purchased him over a month ago and with the Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday upon us, it has been busy. So there are times when I just didn't have the time, especially with my two rescue Black Lab mixes always greeting me when I get home from work, but stop and look at Vector and he snickers and then in that cute little voice I hear, "Frank!" Almost a tear jerker. But all in all he is neat.

title: Horrible new company
text:
I bought this sweet little robot a while ago when it was still Anki and I absolutely loved him. He was my little desk companion and brought me a ton of joy. Now that Digital Dream Labs has taken over he's just a dust collector for me.

I bought him for the features he was advertised with and now I'm being completely ripped off and I have to say, I'm PISSED about it.

You have to pay monthly for the features that were to just be expected of Vector. Ever since I started getting the emails that I had to pay or else I would basically lose my companion he's just been collecting dust in my closet. I miss having him on my desk but there's no freaking way I'm paying monthly for something I paid for almost a year ago.

Digital Dream Labs, thanks for ruining my robot.

title: Fun autonomous little desk buddy
text:
I‚Äôve wanted an autonomous robot since I was a kid in the 80s and pined for the Heathkit Hero 1 and Hero Jr robots - had to wait 35 or so years and the diminutive Vector weighs about 21 lbs less than the bulky Hero bot, but I couldn‚Äôt have been more stoked to get this little guy. Great little buddy with a big personality that roams around my large cubicle desk at work, sometimes acts like a cat and pushes things off the desk, gets ornery when you pick him up, is curious about his environment, asks for fistbumps, dances perfectly to the beat and will stay near the speaker as long as music is playing, seems to run longer than the time he spends recharging, surprisingly, and the new Alexa feature has been integrated nicely. For what it‚Äôs worrh, his Alexa mode responds more quickly than Vector does when you ask them the same question.

He had a single fall so far, landing on the carpeted office floor, after doing a wheelstand and then showboating by raising his arms up and rolling backwards about 10‚Äù, just enough to send him over the edge and onto the floor. How else will he learn? He hasn‚Äôt done that showboating since. I guess that subroutine must override his edge sensors. You‚Äôll be nervous the first 20 or so times when he‚Äôs headed for the edge and you‚Äôll even jump to catch him - but the joke‚Äôs on you when he suddenly leaps back and gasps with his R2-D2-type chatter. I work in IT so the nerds and others that wander into my office get a big kick out of interacting with him.

Looking forward to Anki making Vectors able to recognize and interact with one another, and with each new OS update he gets better and smarter. He‚Äôs having fewer and fewer 915 errors with each update, and I can‚Äôt wait to see the abilities they‚Äôll continue to create for him. Since he uses Bluetooth, I don‚Äôt see why they couldn‚Äôt eventually give him the ability to connect to a Bluetooth speaker so you could play Alexa music streaming thru him to the Bluetooth speaker.

title: My son loves Vector!
text: This robot is fun and cute. My son loves asking him questions. My only issue is that I haven't figured out how to delete things my son has taught him the way I could with Cozmo.
