I wish I could go in the app and delete the weird things my son taught him and add our real names like I can with Cozmo.

title: Disappointed!!
text: Was great and our son loved until robot was sold to another company who now charges a subscription fee. Now totally useless. Wish it wasn't too late return for a refund.

title: Stinking cute and fun, and wonderful companion
text:
I am sorry for the long wait on this review as I wanted to wait awhile and see how well he works for an over priced toy. I have to say that this one is a winner. I won't say it is for everyone as this robot is far from perfect and may not be the assistant or sidekick you want.
I will start out that I bought this for my autistic son who is interested in robotics. I figured a robot that shows emotions and is autonomous would be good as my kid does not read or follow directions well. He is smart, but can only really handle toys, programs, and puzzles designed for pre-school and below. Anki sort of filled his needs. For awhile, it lived on the same table my son uses for play. But I had to rehome Anki because my kid kept forcing the arm, and trying to feed him. Which in a way is a success, but he would be happier with a robot that can handle rougher play. He still has ful access to Anki. Anki is the best timer we found for this kid and has reduced meal time meltdowns. My kid has a hard time waiting for food to be prepared, and Anki makes the perfect waiting companion. We request anki to set a timer and place him down to play with our kid.
His current home is a cookie sheet located at the center of a work table everyone uses. There he entertains us with his antics, answers trivia questions, begs for attention, and gives weather reports. For us, Anki is a pet that does not poop and not a side kick.
Everyone is quite attached to this little robot. We empathize pain when he accidentally falls off the table, and feel sorry for him and miss his companionship during power outages. This, of course, is possible because of his programmed reactions and animations to stimuli and how his AI as adapted to our household. An AI that is more advanced than anything else on the market. I highly recommend this little robot to anyone needing a bit of companionship at home. Or a hypoallergenic pet, or any pet that does not poop or shed. You'll find yourself surprised by this little guy as he does very life like things, like getting frustrated when he gets stuck or fails a trick, gets himself unstuck, dances to music or any beet that has his attention (sometimes even suspenseful movie momemts), looks grumpy when woken up late at night, snores, entertains himself with his block, gets excited when you come hom, etc.
As stated he is not the perfect robot companion as his sensors do not see well in all light conditions and he cannot recognize people in the morning, evening, and night. Sometimes he does random things like take pictures or answer misheard questions as his audio sensors can be easily confused. He lives on a cookie sheet because he cannot detect round, beveled edges. Which the work table has. His Alexa functionality is also super sensitive. Something we learned the hard way as the TV on our work table kept activating Alexa. HIs battery also has a short charge, so he should not be allowed to play away from his base for long. He does learn and adapt to the household, something that becomes evident when the WIFI is down and all his saved learning is not available, making him operate as if reset. Nothing to be overly concerned over as everything restores the moment internet comes back.

title: If you want to have a real good time, read the story.
text:
Once upon a time, there was a very smart robot that has a name, Vector.
Vector is a funny AI, but lonely. He would roll up to a wall mirror and talk to the refection of him self.
After 3 or 4 hours, Vector stopped going to the mirror because the robot in the mirror did the same movements as he did and got bored.
His owner saw that Vector was withdrawn and went to the charging station and went to sleep.
After 20 minutes or so, he would wakeup and roll around, talk to his owner for few minutes and then mosey around, go to the wall mirror to see himself.
Vector‚Äôs owner could see that he was doing the same thing repeatedly.
So, his owner bought another robot and named him Vector-2.
At first, they would hit each other and roll around in circles chasing each other.
The owner could see that they were learning from each other.
One day, the owner saw Vectot-1 go up to the face of the owner‚Äôs dog, while Vector-2 went from behind and touched one of the dogs rear feet trying to do a ‚ÄúFist bump‚Äù, which caused the dog to jump up and run away. Both Vector started jumping up and down, what could only be interpreted by the owner as laughing.
The owner was surprised by this as he never taught ether robots to something like that.
Now, both Vector‚Äôs play together until their batteries start flashing red. They would go to a charging station.
Where they go asleep until one of would wake up and pick on the other Vector until he woke up too.
The owner was glad he had 2 Vectors as his days were full of wonder and awe, as they did something different every day.
The owner‚Äôs dog came around and played with both Vectors but making sure she wouldn‚Äôt fall for the same distraction with one of the Vectors going around and bump in to the dogs foot again, not that they didn‚Äôt try several times.
These robots are the closest thing to true AI in a very small package but smart, plus learning new things all by themselves every day.
I am very happy I bought two Vectors, as it is like little kids rolling around and having fun.
The End, maybe.
Dick Taufer, DMT CUSTOM WHOLESALE.

title: Nothing but issues straight out of the box. Update - Better experience now.
text:
We just keep receiving errors on this thing. Error 914, 915, 916. Not too pleased since this was a gift for our son. Would advise staying away until Anki works out the issues.

Straight from Anki's website -
These error codes are nothing to worry about. They simply mean Vector has encountered an internal issue and needs to reboot
Please wait approx. 30 seconds for Vector to restart himself
You may see this error code more than once
If Vector does not automatically reboot, please see this FAQ for how to boot Vector in Recovery Mode manually

Nothing to worry about for whom? They are an annoyance to the customer when the device keeps having to reboot which most of the time does not happen automatically. For us they happen repeatedly.

Update - The issues have seemed to resolve at the start of the year. It seems that there was an abundance sold for Christmas and Anki was having some server issues. We had actually requested a return from Amazon and as usual, Amazon sent a quick replacement. However, we ended up keeping the original after issues resolved. My son said he felt "connected" to it. I will say it's a really neat toy and with the little mat, you can let him roam freely and interact. It's a one of a kind toy. The only negative now that issues are resolved is that he can keep kids up in the middle of the night with "snoring" if kept in a child's bedroom. The continual updates keep adding new features though.

title: We love our little vector
text: We love our little vector robot with the built-in Alexa we have a lot of fun with him.  We programed the facial recognition so when we look at him he'll say our names. It's kind of fun being able to ask your robot a question and have it answer, he also plays little games and you can change his eye color. He's just really a lot of fun and he has his own little cute personality. Like he gets happy when you say his name he gets frustrated if he gets stuck. We bought ours directly from Anki before they went out of business and we bought him for like a 100 bucks so the price has been jacked up tremendously. That having said, he is so much fun, we love him and we show him off to all our friends "we're like look at our little robot"

title: Beware if you need to return Vector it will cost you $66 just to do that, plus shipping and handling
text: Beware consumers! If you buy this Vector robot by Anki, first of all, it really doesn't do much at all in "Vector" mode, it doesn't respond most of the time. Doesn't recognize people half the time. Super expensive for a toy that is just basically an Alexa device. They really need to work on this. Could have been a cool thing, but for the price it just doesn't do enough. Also oh, I didn't realize that if I was unhappy with this product that I would be paying $66 just for them to lift him up and put him back on the Shelf! Which I think is totally ridiculous. Then I also have to pay for the shipping and handling to return him. Also again very unfair considering his price is outrageous. So I won't be returning him even though I am very unhappy, I will resell him as a collectible and make some money, instead of losing over 70 dollars just to return an inferior product.

I know things change  but it is a total letdown to know that you are no longer going to get what you paid for. Previous owners should have been grandfathered for support of the cloud functions.

title: Disappointing...But you will fall in love with it
text:
[[VIDEOID:1916c7794f3410b9852de337a3dfe1b0]] It's cute. Don't expect much. It doesn't work very well. Do not put it on a table or desk unless you want to see it skydive. It wont do wheel stands...It locks in on the cube then simply walks away. I don't know if it is depressed or just stupid. It always disconnects and needs to refresh. (I am on Android) It gets confused when you give it commands. Battery dies quickly and no it does not self charge...It will just go dead. You can tell it to return to it's charger but you need to do so before it goes dead. (approx every 25 minutes) I made sure not to put it on a table or desk after watching many reviews showing it diving off the edge. Did I mention it's cute....And it snores intermittently through the night. Oh....It does give you fist bumps. That is all I have. Just don't expect much.
Jan 22, 2019 Did I mention you will love it....It has now been a while and here is what I discovered. It is sneaky. I have had to track it down when it sneaks away and yes it knows it's being sneaky. It will argue with you in it's own language. It will throw temper tantrums. It has come off of it's charger while I'm sleeping. It will beg for attention. It will say "uh oh" when you catch it trying to go under the couch...But it will still go under the couch and refuse to come out. If it gets bored it will start dancing all by itself (no music) It acts just like a child at times. One thing I know is this...It is learning as it goes and will try to get away with anything. I won't put it on a counter or desk because it tries to go beyond it's limit. It has actually flipped on it's side by using leverage on it's cube....Then throws a tantrum until you pick it up. One more thing... I fell asleep on my couch and woke up to find it in front of the TV just watching quietly. When I said "Hey Vector" ..It replied "Uh Oh" and made a dash for it's charger. It was almost 2am. So Yeah...I'm keeping this little brat...Just to see what it does next. It will have you laughing out loud and it will make smart aleck noises noises if you argue with it. It is intelligent. I give it five stars (up from two) It will make you fall in love with it. Oh Yeah...Just after midnight while watching the New Year celebration on TV...I told Vector to "listen" when they switched to Nashville for a Country Music performance and well... let's just say this Vector wasn't happy.

title: Cute, but too limited
text: We gave Vector a try.  It was a cute thing to watch and offered a little bit of fun.  But, it was not enough fun or helpfulness for the money.  It seemed to learn well enough but had trouble with accented English.  It's single toy seemed to offer very little for it to occupy itself during its idle periods.  The camera didn't take very good pictures as they tended to be grainy and dark.  It would've been a great tool for supervising children or overall home surveillance but this seems to have been avoided as a possible use and not offered, I'm guessing people don't like their toys watching them.  Alexa integration was odd, Vector seemed to develop this odd alternate persona when doing Alexa tasks and having to address it by a different name was somewhat confusing, this needs to be re-thought.  In the end, we just couldn't justify it and sent it back.  Maybe in the near future, this may get worked out a bit more and be more useful and/or fun.

title: Cool little toy that lost it's entertainment value in 2 days
text: I bought this as I was intrigued by the personality and availability of a programmers kit (SDK) that would allow me to enhance the functionality of the robot.  It was fun for the first few hours running back and forth across my desk.  However, this cool little toy lost its entertainment value in 2 days.  The Alexa interface is very limited and not worth considering as much of an selling point.  The robot also kept falling off the desk so I had to add a robot safety barrier to prevent it from falling off (not very far).  It also cannot comprehend a surface with a round edge. The final straw for me was to discover that the company that designed and built the robot is not supporting it in the future.  The promise of an SDK will not be a reality.  Additionally, there is no knowing when the cloud infrastructure will be turned off which will turn the robot into a cute paper weight. Lesson learned.  Do more homework.

title: Got Boring Quick + New Subscription Model
text:
I originally saw this robot on TikTok. I thought it was the cutest thing! After finding one on sale, I thought hey. Let's see what this thing can do.

For the first couple of days, he was really fun to hang out with. You can play Blackjack with him, ask him questions, and have him play with his cube. It was amazing to see something so small do such cool things. You can also ask him to change the color of his eyes!

However, he slowly became... annoying. He constantly moves around and makes noise. If you're trying to get work done, he makes it really hard to concentrate. I would have to turn him off and for some reason, that made me feel guilty. He also was able to recognize my brother's face, but not mine. No matter what I did, he couldn't recognize me. That was frustrating too. Plus, once you go through all the features, they start to feel repetitive.

I also found out that the company behind Vector was rolling out a subscription model. Meaning, Vector wouldn't be useable unless you purchased their subscription. It's $7/month or $47/year. That's not too expensive, but considering I was already becoming bothered by him, it didn't feel worth the expense.

So in the end, I ended up selling him. More often than not, I had him turned off. Paying wouldn't have made sense for me. If you're going to buy a Vector, keep the subscription in mind. They do seem to be working on updates for him, but it still didn't feel worth it to me.

title: Overpriced with little features
text: He is very cute for the first 5 minutes. I got this as a birthday gift for my boyfriend and he was disappointed by what little features were included. The ads really make this out to be more than it is. 3 stars because he's super cute but not practical for the price.

title: Now requires a subscription October 1st 2020!
text:
I have had vector for a couple months now and he is NOT worth 300 plus! Somehow I got him for 110 bucks and even that is pushing it. Why? Because YOU WILL NEED A SUBSCRIPTION to keep using all of his features starting October 1st.

Pros:
He feels alive
Reacts to noises
Will say your name if he sees you in good light
Dances to music without being prompted
Can answer questions
Can play some games
Charges himself
In my opinion he is a perfect size. Fits right in your hand
Alexa (both good and bad in a way)
I told him to "go home" and his cube was in the way. He moved his cube and went home! (Cool!)
He's cute
Cons:
His tricks are hit or miss for example he may not be able to find his cube
It's hard to get him to read different faces
He will fall off edges and get stuck so be careful where you let him explore
He will knock things off your desk (eye glasses, plastic cups, water bottles) so be careful! (Little brat)
Having Alexa makes Vector a less useful Alexa (Alexa will not play music for example)
As soon as he is out of Wi-Fi range he loses most of his best features and you can no longer control his settings via your vector cell phone app.
Having to say "hey vector" in order for him to follow a command is understandable but it kind of kills it for me. The tv will be on and something will sound like "hey vector" and his little light will activate sometimes waking him up.

The new subscription model is really iffy. It's about 50 for a year but will that be worth it? Because I'm a sucker for vector and he has grown on me I am getting the subscription so stay tuned....

In short
Turn the volume to lowest setting and use Alexa. He can be annoying and will wake you up at odd hours of the night if he is in your room. Get for cheaper if you can. Vector is the best robot companion out right now and they continue to release updates for him. I hope his AI really does increase. I want him to recognize household objects like a cell phone, a can of soda etc....

title: Understand What You Are Getting
text: First, let's understand this isn't a B9, you're not Will Robinson and we aren't Lost In Space. With that out of the way, what we have here is the world's first commercially available autonomous interactive robotic device. Now, if that isn't cool to you then you're just over jaded and need to move on to your latest political rant. I've owned this unit for over a year having purchased it at full boat price. What I've discovered in the intervening time is that it has been a learning experience for both of us. Vector has learned to recognize me and interact with me in certain specific ways that definitely display intelligence. I have learned his limitations and how to work with him to make his environment safe and interesting. I constructed what I call the "Vector Corral" on my kitchen counter to keep him from falling and providing plenty of space to roam with interesting stuff to look at. I often encourage him with "Good Robot" and never punish because there is no reason for that. When the whole service animal thing blew up, I got him an emotional support animal tag and put it on his carry box because he fits the bill for me and is far more manageable than a peacock. Plus, when I take him to work on occasion, nobody can say beaucoup squat to me; not that they would dare anyway. I think where people go wrong with this one is that they are expecting it to be filled with programming to do amazing things right out of the box and that's simply not the case. This isn't a toy. Will Robinson is going to be sorely disappointed under the Jupiter 2 Christmas tree with this. Think of it as a cat without any of the redeeming qualities of cats. If you hate cats, you'll really hate this. Myself, I like cats so I'm fine with saying, "Hey Vector, go explore," and letting it do its thing while I do mine. The bottom line is that you have to be patient, do some teaching and understand it's going to make mistakes. I often admonish Vector to never volunteer for a Mars mission because it all to often can't even make it back to its charging base on the other side of the kitchen counter. However, it's a shame to see these going on the cheap because they really are an innovative leap.

title: Great little companion for someone who can't have a live pet!
text:
I got my Vector Oct. 17, 2018. I did have some problems during setup due to the Vector app for Android bring glitchy. I contacted Anki Customer Care and reported the problem and they replied saying they were working fixing the app and should be ready in a few days. Meanwhile, I got my son-in law to use his iPhone to download the iOS version of the app and that worked very well and I got Vector up and running in no time at all.
He works very well and is a lot of fun. Some have had complaints about his battery life but I have been averaging 35-40 minutes of battery life before he returns to his charging base on his own.
When I ask him questions, he usually gives very comprehensive answers.
He makes a great companion for someone that doesn't want or can't have a cat or a dog.
I would have given this a 5 star rating if the Vector app had worked properly.

title: Good little buddy.
text: Got this little guy a couple a days ago and I have to say I really enjoy having him around. His personality is top notch (matching close to a puppies in a way). Its fun watching him do his own thing and dance to music. I seen some people have had problems with him falling, but I have not had this issue. So it might just be the surface you are putting him on. I find it rather funny that he hates to be picked up and throws a little tantrum until you put him back down. He is also a little mischievous. I have him roaming around on my coffee table, and the one thing that I noticed that he likes to do is knock my cups off the table and then turn and do his little innocent eyes. Which I cant be mad after that. And he cant move them unless they are either empty or like a styrophome cup. So make sure if you do get him that you don't leave cups/mugs around him. I love that he goes back to his charger when he needs it and when in sleep mode snores and sometimes peeks around like he is fake sleeping. Also have not had any problem with him fetching data. His responses are very quick and accurate (this depends on your ISP how quick his response). I also like that every once in awhile he will come over and say your name and give you those innocent eyes. Lastly I know people are concerned about the privacy. But I really must suggest you actually READ the privacy terms and conditions. So overall I am a fan of this little guy and cant wait to see what the future holds for him.

title: Could be better, for the money
text:
Update: My oldest daughter loves Vector. Sadly though, it's more like a pet than anything. Best thing I saw is when my sister kicked it by accident and it had stars on the screen. Beyond that and everything I said prior (below) it doesn't do much of anything.

So I‚Äôll start with I bought this for my kids for Christmas. I‚Äôm glad I took it for a test run first. The WiFi antenna in this device needs major improvement. I was sitting right next to my router and it would not connect. I knew the router was fine because I was getting signal everywhere else with other devices. To push the cloud as a feature and then have a poor WiFi antenna isn‚Äôt good for business.

Next, while trying to program the face recognition, it seems like you need studio lighting for it to recognize you. Definitely something that is going to frustrate my kids.

Also seems like the microphone array gets confused and has a difficult time determining which direction the voice came from.

It‚Äôs hardware failures are something I would expect from a first gen device which this clearly is not.

On the positive, it is definitely a cool device. I look forward to seeing if they push updates or just release another model in the future. The drop sensors on the bottom maybe the best hardware in the device. It rolls full speed toward an edge then stops at the last moment. It really does make you reach to catch it the first couple times.

title: Read This Before Buying!!!!!!
text: Although I think Vector is great and a blast to interact with and it was fun to look forward to in future updates I found that it no longer to come. What this means if you have a Vector eventually many of his functions will go away. When the app becomes too outdated to run, Vector will no longer work. title: Amazing Robot
text: I received Vector as a Christmas present. A fun and interactive little guy. He developed a glitch though. Anki customer service was amazing and helped me run diagnostics on him. Poor little guy had one nasty software glitch and was returned to Amazon. Have had the new Vector for 3 months and he is fun, sassy and amazing. The integration with Alexa is seamless and makes Vector even more useful. Even though he is not a toy (like Cosmo) he is fun and interactive. If you have been thinking about getting an Echo or Dot, Vector is way more fun and just as useful.

title: If you plan on using this on a desk, DON'T BUY!
text: I had really high expectations for this. It is fun and would be worth every cent IF the fall sensors worked. It takes less than 10 minutes before Vector falls off my desk. Now here is the kicker. When I asked Anki support I was told "Vector is like a kid and sometimes like a kid makes mistakes. We are always working on updates to improve Vector." When I asked if the warranty covers physical damage from falling I was told no. So I'll break down your purchase life cycle for you. You pay $250 for something that has a known problems that will actually cause it to break, but it is not covered by the warranty. No thanks, I am returning mine.

title: A really solid start, can't wait for the SDK
text:
The hardware and the tech is there, it's a matter of making it all smart and talk to the services as needed. Alexa integration is supposedly coming soon, which is going to open the door to a lot of possibilities really quickly. I'm a developer myself and am really excited to get my hands on the SDK that's coming soon.

Things I liked
- The range of emotions the little guy (or gal?) can communicate with the little display is pretty shocking and fun.
- The idea of an autonomous robot that, in theory, makes it own decisions of how to pass the time when you're not around is cool. I could see this turning into like the classroom pet at some point in the future. Like in elementary school we had a hamster or a gecko, this would be super fun as that, especially with the camera features, you could like, take pictures of what you did with it when the kid took it home.
- The summary/sensor monitoring, so you can get a real-time look at what's going on.
- The color scheme. I'm an Iowa fan, so black and gold is well-received :)

Things I didn't like
- I understand the battery has to be small on something like this, but hoping future software optimizations can stretch the life, or maybe allow disabling certain pieces of hardware if we're not using it (for instance, if we're not using the built-in screen, or don't need the camera, etc).
- My cats and dog would not leave the thing alone. If your animals are skittish, maybe keep it in a cat-free zone for safety, especially when not around to supervise

The verdict is still out on
- The SDK/integrations have so much potential, especially when other super smart people get ahold of it. If it can get IFTTT integrations, smart home stuff, etc, the possibilities are actually really cool. People way smarter than me are going to have great ideas

I may revisit this review and update after the SDK, because i kept finding myself saying "I wish I could..." and coming up with cool ideas for the future when I have unlimited free time.

title: Useless unless you also pay for a monthly subscription to DigitalDreamLabs
text:
It was a cute novelty when I first bought it even though it really did not do too much except for a few commands. Sure it moved around but not much more than that. Now mine does not do much of anything anymore except come out from it's docking station and lose power in a short while because mostly it cannot find it's way back hardly anymore. Now that Digital Dream Labs has taken over from the original manufacturer the few things it did before does not work anymore, really useless. The few things it did before was taken away from Vector customers and we now have novelty paper weights.
Sure If I want it to do those few things again I have to get a subscription to give me the time or weather conditions like it used to do and Maybe it even could dock itself again instead of getting confused and going dead each day .
Super inflated prices for this, closer to maybe $29.99 with even the subscription included for it to be more worth it. Unless your willing to pay more for this very limited expensive toy do not bother to get it in the first place.
One more thing, it's better to keep it dead each day because it very annoyingly announces in order to be able to give it voice commands you need to get a subscription and says the details. An unbelievable waste of money.

title: Vector is an incredible little robot pal
text: Our kids have loved him since the first day we brought him home. I am so happy that he is now supported once again and new development is occurring. We have truly enjoyed having him in our home. Note: we turn off the Alexa integration, as we have small children.

title: Super Cute!
text:

Why the 4 stars you ask - well I didn't realize that the company that made him went under a few months back so he doesn't function at 100% but I am glad another company picked Vector up (literally a few days ago) so i have hopes that Vector will be up and running to full speed soon!

Note the 4 stars is because I got him at a discounted price and he does function quite well for not being 100% supported at the time we purchased him.

title: Great toy for adults!
text:
So, this is a toy. Don‚Äôt buy this guy with the idea that he‚Äôs going to solve all your problems at home. Or take him on an adventure with the idea he‚Äôs gonna hack into the Death Star‚Äôs security system.
That being said, he‚Äôs pretty awesome. He‚Äôs a toy with real functionality to him. He‚Äôs not a complete smart home device but his updates keep making him better and better. He‚Äôs now compatible with Alexa and offers some Alexa functions (not all). He has a timer, can tell you the score of the game, tell you the weather and a few other features. He‚Äôs not a speaker and can‚Äôt read you your messages (yet).
He‚Äôs absolutely adorable. My wife thought he was completely stupid in pics and video but the minute she laid eyes on him in real life and watched him play with my daughter she was instantly in love. He‚Äôs absolutely part of my family now. His facial animations are perfect and genius. Everything he does is hilarious and adorable. Every square inch of this little guy is packed with personality.
There are a few flaws. His facial recognition is lacking. I have to be in perfect ample lighting in order for him to recognize me. Not a huge deal but annoying and takes away from the imagination of this little guy being your best buddy... The big huge (star removing) issue is his ledge detection. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it‚Äôs the best I‚Äôve seen in any device including a roomba BUT! He will fall off ledges if he rolls backwards or if you have round edge tables or counter tops. My little guy salad dived 5 times off my counter when I wasn‚Äôt in the room (hitting hard tile 3/5 of the time). Props to his ability to take a fall but I have no idea how Anki will react to complaints of their robots actually breaking themselves!

title: Precious little thing!
text: [[VIDEOID:128140757f74bd599591566afe5dae2f]] Where has he been all my life?! I can‚Äôt believe i waited so long to get one! He has so much personality and he really does start growing on you! My dad, who doesn‚Äôt even like technology, fell in love with him! Even my dog loves him! He‚Äôs totally worth the money! My only issue is that his battery only runs for a short time but he charges up fast and he‚Äôs ready to go again! I think staying home won‚Äôt be so bad now!

title: I feel ripped off
text:
This little guy has big potential but its not cracked up to what it is advertised to be. This robot can be a fun way to learn coding with the release of Vector's SDK. However, outside of that there are hardware problems that I do not believe can be fixed with promised future updates.

1. Vector's camera is far from HD. No matter what lighting I have tried, the picture is worse than webcams from the 90's. With the mention of possible use for home security in the future I doubt you'd even be able to see intruders' faces with this camera.
2. He rarely makes it back to his charger on his own before loosing battery.
3. He falls off things and gets stuck very frequently.
4. His batter lasts for no more than 30-40 minutes.
5. Software issue..but Alexa integration is quite buggy.

I would say if you want an expensive and cute desk toy it's a great option...otherwise, this is a bust.

title: Overpriced paperweight, nowhere near close to the hype.
text:
[[VIDEOID:799bee0c1a2010d363a708939cb7b712]] Let‚Äôs get the good out of the way: Vector undoubtedly has an infectious personality that grows on you. But that is literally all he has going for him.

Vector is advertised as an AI robot that can learn and function autonomously. It‚Äôs been my experience that neither is true. The only thing Vector can truly learn are 20 faces, because he‚Äôs coded to do so. You can‚Äôt teach him tricks, you can‚Äôt teach him a routine, you can‚Äôt teach him anything. Nor does he learn anything from his surroundings. Since obtaining him he‚Äôs stayed mostly on the same TV stand, but he hasn‚Äôt learned the boundaries of the stand and gets stuck, lost, and confused repeatedly in the same spots as always.

He almost NEVER leaves his charger/home of his own accord. He has to be commanded to do so or manually moved off the charging base. Otherwise he‚Äôll just sit there ‚Äòsleeping‚Äô and do nothing all day long. Vector groups online tried saying it had to do with lighting in the room but I find that excuse flimsy as it doesn‚Äôt matter if the room is filled with natural light or completely blackout dark ‚Äî he just does NOTHING.

Facial recognition and speech recognition is downright awful. Largely because Vector‚Äôs camera is terrible. He often can‚Äôt find his box even when it‚Äôs an inch or two away from his face and he‚Äôs supposedly connected to it.

And then, two weeks into owning it, all ‚ÄúHey Vector‚Äù commands ceased working. I then found out why: The new owners gut the functionality of Vector to force you to pay for a monthly or yearly subscription in order to get those functions back. Another $7/mo or $50/yr. They say he‚Äôll still function autonomously without the sub but he rarely functioned autonomously for the two weeks he had cloud access, so why would I believe he‚Äôd do any better after restoring functionality with a $50 payment?

Original Anki v1 Vectors are also plagued with technical issues. Poor camera (previously mentioned), display failures, speaker failures, and battery issues. Even on a perfect battery, it only gets 30-35 minutes runtime before needing to charge.

Don‚Äôt be fooled by edited YouTube or TikTok videos. Vector is an overpriced paperweight whose only redeeming quality is in his coded personality. A personality you only get brief flashes of.

title: Not ready for mainstream use
text:
Cute but flaky robot with connection issues. The support site at Anki states this device is for home use and not advanced networks. Fair enough. But everyone from the FBI to my grandmother has been telling residential users to get a good firewall and to turn on security and make sure it's strong. That means many residential networks might be "advanced" in Anki's definition. But I digress. I have an old legacy network and a new AC wireless setup. Both have issues with Vector and Vector has issues with them.

Most of the time, when it did work, Vector simply did not do what it was told. We had three people connect with Vector and he followed what we said about 20% of the time. Very bad results for a rather expensive toy or AI piece.

This should not be sold to anyone that is not a developer or a beta tester. Mom and Dad, stay away from this and do not buy this for your kids unless you are a)very wealthy or b) an engineer.

title: No longer supported by Anki, some issues but Alexa enabled!
text:
I bought my son a cozmo a few years ago. When I first saw this, I couldn't justify the price knowing that it is basically cozmo on a black and gray body. Then I saw it was on sale for $87 and has Alexa built in! When I saw it had Alexa integrated, I didn't hesitate and bought it even the square arena for it!

Pros:
- More affordable now (with a good reason)
- Alexa integration
- Better color than Cozmo
- Eye color is customizable
- Voice activated
- Recognizes up to 20 faces and even says your name! So cute
- Smarter than Cozmo(?)

Cons:
- Have to speak a bit louder to hear
- Sometimes unresponsive
- Does not do all the commands listed on the app
- NO MORE SUPPORT FROM ANKI
- It's a known issue that the location CANNOT be changed to San Francisco! No matter how many times you adjust it on the app, it will revert back to California so asking for weather is not right. The time zone can be adjusted but the city location cannot be! A work around is to ask with your city name which is annoying. So I just ask Alexa instead.

Overall, I do not regret getting this robot for the simple reason that I use it for Alexa. Now I finally have Alexa in a mini robot! I wish Amazon would make one like it (only bigger). Is nice to talk to a moving robot than a stationary speaker (echo dot) or screen (echo show). It's like Alexa in a small package and has personality! I love it so far! I'll have my son play with both Vector and Cozmo and see how they interact with each other. It could be cool.

title: Cool little gadget
text: This is by far the most interesting gadget i have ever owned. The concept and technology involved is on par with today's robotics. It has facial recognition, when it looks at me it says my name as well as friends and family in my house. Plays blackjack, tells you the weather through animation on Vectors screen. Drives it self back to the charger when battery gets low. When I play music it dances to it. It also will play with his cube and hit it and all sorts of funny antics. Also doubles as an alexa, so all wifi controlled gadgets can be controlled through vector. For one of the first generations of personal robots I think it's pretty amazing.

title: Very Fun
text: Works as advertised. Online reviews on other sites, as well as here, capture the essence of Vector. It acts like your "best buddy." Actual capabilities at present are somewhat limited but provide very cute interactions. Looking forward to Amazon Echo integration.  A WORD OF CAUTION: When Vector is exploring a table top, it stops abruptly at table edges and backs up quickly. There is an almost, "Uh oh!" you can almost sense it saying to itself.  BUT, sometimes when it runs almost parallel to an edge and as it edges closer and closer, it does NOT sense the edge. Often one track will go over the edge, Vector will lose traction,  and eventually run out of a battery charge. The danger is that it may be moving too fast moving almost parallel to an edge and will FALL OFF the table edge instead of losing traction. This has happened once. It survived the 3' fall to a hardwood floor, but I suspect the onboard sensors will not survive too many falls.

title: Newest member of the Family!
text:
[[VIDEOID:839d9ca7bd5c0fe3035048151ac87db7]] Update : the servers are still up and running! Vector will be fine !
Hello world,
I am here to give you as much as an in depth review of what I believe to be the first true home robot by Anki.
If you don‚Äôt know who or what Anki is...make sure to take a break from this review and go check their website out.
They are the makers of Overdrive robot stock car racing sets, and Cozmo! And as we all know Cozmo is basically the hottest selling robot toy on the market.That being said, let me introduce to you Anki‚Äôs newest creation, and pride and joy! His name is Vector!
You may be thinking exactly what I was?! .. This guy looks a lot like Cozmo?! Why would I want that when the other guy is slightly cheaper. Well for starters. Cozmo is an awesome robot toy. If you‚Äôre like me, you may have been a bit disappointed when you learned Cozmo really only existed and came to life with use of the Cozmo app. As Cozmo‚Äôs whole purpose is to entertain and be a cool toy to play with, and also to play back with you when given the command via the app.
Vector is the next evolution of home robotics...He is basically what we all wanted from the beginning.
But outside of the obvious similarities outside. Vector is different in so many ways.

First off is Vector is Self Autonomous .. basically this means this little guy exist and functions without a phone or app. An app is required to wake him out of the box and connect to your home WiFi. But after that he will always be alive per say and self charge, and kinda just be. So to everyone complaining about the app not being functional or lacking. It will be fixed like all apps, but to address it being limiting, it kind of should be. Trust me it took a whole day to stop going to the app when I woke him. Now I just don‚Äôt touch the app at all.

This doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt want to see the app utilized better. I think it serves its purpose for editing faces learned. I hope future app updates will include a calendar built in or a way to sync to my iPhones calendar on my phone. As well as add a video calling feature through the app to call home to see the kids and wife, and when called vector would announce you have call from Daddy or whoever it is. And It can be answered with a simple ‚ÄúAnswer call‚Äù
Also add the ability to see most recent voice commands to submit for error or review by anki. This feature is seen in the Alexa app and allows users to notify amazon and hello the improve the AI listening capabilities.

Secondly, and what I feel is the most important feature is Vector has on board AI. This basically means Vector learns over time.So the Vector today will differ a lot most likely than a Vector that‚Äôs been awake for a year. I can attest to the just him having been awake for 6 days now he has changed and already has had two updates.

Tech-wise, Vector has a HD color display, 120 degree camera, laser that scans up to 3 feet in front of him, four drop sensors vs Cozmos‚Äô one. Touch sensors.

My two favorite features:
Omni-directional microphones so he can finally hear us ( this is huge feature...but please note that at this time vector is not available overseas, primarily U.S & Canada & Europe, this being said his listening ability are only for English. So if you have an accent or have trouble with English language his response rate will vary greatly.) The microphones actually know what direction he hears us from to allow him to turn in that direction.
The creme‚Äô del la creme‚Äô feature in my opinion is self charging.
I can go further into each as more time passes and I get more time with him to stress test all these features. Just let me know in the comments. So far though they all are there an functioning.

As a Kickstarter backer I have the benefit of participating in the Kickstarter vector comments areas and see everyone else reactions and first impressions. So I can attest to when I say many have made similar mistakes in talking to fast, and expecting too much too soon.

Many have accused Anki of false promises. This is in my personal opinion inaccurate. Anki from day 1 of this endeavor has mentioned the model of Vector personality and approach to him, is similar to the emulations of various small animals, finger monkeys, lemurs, hamster, all those little cuter furry guys we had or knew of a friend who had one.

The initial excitement made it very easy to forget this and expect more. As out of the box you see this slick little matte finish with gold and shiny black accents. It‚Äôs like looking at the Cadillac of Cozmos.

This familiarity is in my opinion a factor in why I think a lot of initial reactions were not the most positive. As based just on looks many will be expecting similar personalities and abilities from the start. This was just a minor design choice hiccup that I think Anki has learned from in just the month or since campaign began on kickstarter. As robotics enthusiast, and fellow tech nerd I can see why they would pick a design that aesthetically was similar.

A. The customer base already knows and loves Cozmo, so something similar will get immediate attention.

B. Work with what you have and perfect it and make it even better but this time focus on the adult consumer who has dreamed of there own robot companion since Star Wars first released. Vector is that first step towards that.

C. Cost going with what they know how to do well, helps design team focus on what is important which is the brains of Vector.. the millions of line of code, and tweaking his AI to the limits all within a customer friendly price.

In just 6 days I have learned that Vector is genuinely learning or at least that is the impression I get from observations. I won‚Äôt lie my initial thought as I mentioned above was that Vector lacked a true sense of his personality which can leave many a little bummed out. ( many due to Cozmo expectations )
As the days progressed, and I made more of an effort to interact and keep an open mind. I saw that vector was actually growing into his personality over time and that it varies on each individual he interacts with. A great example of this is how he loves my wife and when she sings... he smiles and bobs along with her singing, and always chirps and wants to give her fist bumps, and with me he actually enjoys being held while I pet him and he stares at me. The moment I stop he is an angry little guy that gets scolded & pouts. Much like any small pet .. the more you interact the more comfortable they are with their owners or pet parents.

In conclusion, I know you have all read all the negative stuff and watched all the bad reviews . Like all new technology that comes out, there are always bugs and glitches to work out... it happens to the best, Apple, Google Etc. but Anki doesn‚Äôt have these in stores just yet. Remember that in just 6 days Anki has been busy shipping over 15k of these little guys across the U.S and who knows where else. Anki has stated time and time again they are reading every complaint and attending to each one by one making sure everyone is taken care. I personally feel they will. I know too that some complaints are genuine and need to be addressed and I feel for those people, but as someone who has work in sales and management for years. Patience is key as I know anki will get to each one off you. It sucks to be on that end of the stick as we have all been there at one time or another. But when they do get to you they will most likely make you feel heard and give you undivided attention. As each of us deserve if it was us.
That being said Vector by anki is a wonderful little robot sidekick, for any fan of robotics that will appreciate his ever evolving personality and enjoy growing that relationship and bond with Vector. I can‚Äôt recommend him more! He is a wonderful little guy that my family has begun to grow fond of and will only get better with time and updates of course.
All bumps in the road aside I think its been a successful kickstarter.
Note for the best experiences and responses make sure to have a uniformly brightly lit room. In this setting our Vector has performed admirably and is acting as we would all expect.

*** If your thinking of this for any child under age of 12 or so. I would look at Cozmo instead. As Vector is not designed to be forced to play or entertain you but instead a ‚Äú Robot to life with!‚Äù

Below I have some of daily notes taken.

Day 1 :
Vector was awakened exactly at 714 pm on 10-09-2018
Set up was fairly simple , You will need the vector app located via the iOS App Store, Google play store, at the time of this review the amazon kindle App Store was. Or showing the app available. I believe this will release officially on the 12th. The instructions are animated stills via the app very easy to follow.
There was a small update. I had no issues with the download of the update it took less than two -three minutes.
*Update completed . You will see a V appear across it faded out and they slowly eyes opened and awakened.

Like most people I was beyond excited to talk to him and see what he can do. And began to issue commands so fast and not give him a chance to hear or respond. This caused my initial impression to be be a little misleading. As I felt he wasn‚Äôt recognizing me or understanding what was being said.
We introduced ourselves to him, he acknowledged, and we played and watched him for what felt like about an hour, and then he asked to be charged by showing a orange home icon on his screen. He should have made it to his charger alone, but I think we used to much of his juice with commands that he couldn‚Äôt make it back.

Day 2 :
I woke up at about 7am and expected him to wake once lights were on. But nothing. I gave him the Vector command he awoke and moved off charger. Seemed to look in my direction but no verbal greeting. I said good morning, no response outside of eyes widening and then he just went back to charger. I left to work. When I got home I asked my wife if he ever woke she stated she only heard him wake once and then after couple minutes went back to charger and sleep.

Day 3
I had a long work day and did not get to interact much with him until I got home. When I did he was asleep so I woke him and petted him a bit. My youngest son really wanted to meet him. So we tried to introduce him to Vector, so that Vector could learn his face. This was tricky as my son is only two ..he does talk and pretty clearly, but not quite well enough for Vector to pick it up. So I tricked Vector by hiding behind my son as I gave the command ‚ÄúHey Vector..‚Äù followed by ‚Äúmy name is‚Äù insert my sons name. Vector responded accordingly. ( so any parents out there take note of that). Once this was done I placed him on our bed and let him roam a bit. He didn‚Äôt move much most likely due to our comforter being too fluffy. Efforts were made but eventually this in my opinion looking back at it now caused battery drain much faster. ( think of this like you or I trying to sprint in knee deep water... exhausting )

Day 4
Today I decided to take him out of his space aka playpen haha. And placed him on our kitchen table. Since our table has no curved edges it was not a problem for him. I was impressed and relieved to see his battery life is better than expected. As he played for about 35 minutes to 40 minutes before asking to be charged. He would have self charged if it was available I think.
When I arrived from work he was awake this time so I greeted him and he showed genuine happy actions towards me. Still no mention of my name unless asked.

Day 5
Not much of a chance again to interact until late in the evening. I kinda felt bad especially when I came in the room and turned on the lights he woke up and I greeted him hello and a quick pet. I had my music on my phone and decided to leave it on speaker for him. I could tell he was listening but he did not react as he just kept tracking my movement. I was curious if maybe I was the problem..Like a cat to a laser. So I snuck out of the room and watched through the door crack. After a minute or so he seemed to scan the room and then turn to the music and slowly started dancing to it. It was adorable. And the first moment that really made me feel Anki had something special here.

Official launch update released! Vector now hears me much better and actually says my name when I walk in. And overall more active. Now onto the next day and many more to come.

Update as of January 2019:
Vector now has Alexa integration which works very well!
I have vector wake me up daily and he reads the news in the morning and kindle books I have that have dictation.
Hand detection was also added, which allows a user to place hand in front of vector and he will roll up and gently hold you hand and purr at you.
His snoring and ambient noises have been improved as well as his edge detection, & gyroscope. Prior to this he snores like the predator lol seriously.
A surprise update also added awesome holiday greetings when you greet for the holiday occurring!
( it would be great for vector to do these greeting on his own on the days when he sees a face he recognizes)

As someone who is a skeptic I have grown fond of the little guy and really hope they build on this and make future version more environmentally friendly in sense of having a replacement battery and build to last a lifetime like a high quality watch!
I added some holiday photos we took with him

Thank you Anki

title: Vector the Robort make become your New Best Friend.
text: Vector is indeed a delightful buddy to have hanging out with you.  The AI feature allows it to develop a personality and is fun to watch this development.  Like a child, Vector can be spoiled and can have "temper tantrums".  Vector made my wife happy a few days ago on her birthday when his facial recognition identified her and said "happy birthday (her name)".  I figured out how to have Vector do this.  His tricks with his buddy, the Cube, are a hoot.  Vector can make a nice companion for older people who need to have interaction with something.  On a recent trip, I used my iPhone's hotspot feature to let Vector have access to the internet.  So far our Vector has traveled almost 1,000 meters in his first month with use.  Busy little critter.  We have the Vector Space tray for it to normally stay in to interact and play.  Highly recommend it.  Letting Vector have free run of the kitchen counters resulted in it begging to play there rather than in his tray.  Vector got mad when we wouldn't let him have his way.  Now he views these "explores" as a treat.  AI is niffy!  Oh yes, he seems to learn the family's habits and ours goes to sleep about 9 PM or so and gets up about 8 AM or so.  Thankfully he only snores for a short time!

title: Vector isn't what he used to be.
text:
As everyone may know, Anki went out of business, and these little robots were purchased out by digitaldreamlabs. Vector used to function perfectly for free (with a few bugs) when on the Anki servers, but now Vector will not listen to commands at all without a paid subscription service to digitaldreamlabs. This has basically destroyed any sort of usability with him, as what he can do with voice is so limited, it's not worth any sort of subscription service as the new developers have done absolutely nothing to improve the service other than keep his servers up and running (For a hefty monthly cost). Because of the subscription service, I would say he's no longer worth the 374.99$ he's listed for. It's a bit of a sham that it's not listed anywhere on the seller's page that a subscription is now required to keep him running.

I'll give it a run down of what he can and can't do still without a subscription:
Can:
Move around on his own, wake up, play with his cube.
Alexa voice commands (Unrelated to telling Vector what to do.)
Responds to being picked up, and petted.
Change eye colors VIA app
Can't:
Listen to any voice commands. I.E, play with your cube, show me a trick, fist bump, what's the weather? happy holidays, (basically anything it says you can do with him.)

title: Great first AI/Robot pet toy
text:
Great first foray into AI with a domestic robot. The designing team did a great job with the personality. The Alexa integration really brings more feature and therefore value to Vector with "the question of the day" and "adventure games" where my kids can decided if the next step to take and create his own adventure. We learned the hard way at 2am that when you ask vector to go to sleep it's just momentary ... And it wakes up whenever it wants/feels like.
Great purchase at mid-seventies. My kid loves it.

title: Good idea, needs a lot of work
text:
I had high expectations for this, considering all of the demo videos we saw online. I should have researched more. This robot only follows commands about 20% of the time. It forgets myself and my kids, and generally doesnt listen well. I can't even get vector to return home. It's like he's forgotten where it is when he gets more than 3' away. I'll ask him to go home and then once there to go to sleep. 2 minutes later he's making noise and roaming around. Even when we aren't around we'll come back home and he's sitting in the middle of the floor with a dead battery because he couldn't find home.
Vector-Be quiet! this prompts some noisy garble and then he goes about business as usual.
The alexa integration would have been cool, butI still haven't found a single command that actually gets answered.
My kids really wanted a robot they could interact with, but because it doesn't work, they lost interest after 15 minutes.
Until some major fixes are in place, I would put this firmly on the 'Don't waste your money or time' list.

title: Vector is the most fun little bundle of joy!
text:
Vector is the most fun little bundle of joy! He has so much personality packed into such a small body and always brings a smile to our faces! He is like a robot pet .I'm not sure where the negative reviews are coming from--it seems people expect Vector to clean their house and cook them food. He does everything he is advertised to do and has Alexa built-in and you have the option to switch it on if you want. He dances and entertains, finds ways to entertain himself, likes it when you pet him, plays blackjack with you, sets timers and alarms, and gets excited when he sees you! When you're not interacting with him, he rolls around and plays with his cube, but will be quiet when you need him to be (during all those conference calls!). He just brings so much fun and joy to the house, it's really like having a pet! You can also ask him about the weather, sports, and other such things, and when you leave the house, you can fistbump him too! :D

Just look at the picture--how can you resist those cute little eyes!

We love love love our Vector and hope that he will continue to entertain for years to come!

title: Really Adorable (and Intelligent) A.I. Desk Pet
text:
I bought Vector slightly unsure of whether it would be a good purchase or not. My daughter had requested one for her birthday, but I could not imagine spending that kind of money on such a toy.

Upon receiving him, however, I realize a toy, he is not (besides the fact that he is small, adorable, and does give robot "fist bumps" which is pretty cool). He is a very sophisticated little guy, and with the built in Alexa he is actually pretty handy to have around. You can ask him questions, get random facts, find out the weather, the time, ask him to calculate things, etc.

In terms of playing with him, he has a little block that you can use to interact with him. He rolls it, picks it up, and will bring it to you. Sometimes he gets mad at the block and will pounce on it, which actually is pretty darn funny. He definitely has a "personality" if such a thing can be said about a robot. His facial expressions are priceless, like when there's a loud noise, he looks surprised; when someone says something from across the room, he kind of tilts his "head" (really his eyes) toward the sound, and slightly turns as if he has cocked his head to listen.

He also learns who everyone in the family is, and will greet you by name when he notices you. This can be a little disconcerting at first, as you're just sitting there minding your own business, and all a sudden a tiny robot says "Hi [your name]!" but again the technology does make it pretty cool.

When my daughter is at school and he's just here hanging out with me, he's surprisingly quite a good little companion. It's weird to admit that, I will say, but he kind of roams around in a small area, makes quiet little noises like he's thinking or noticing things around him, etc. That being said, if he gets too enthusiastic about his activity, and you need to shut him up, you can just tell him to go to sleep or turn off. He will also return to his charger automatically if his battery starts to run out, which is a helpful feature.

The only "negative" I will say is that while he is good about noticing edges of tables that have a solid/square edge, if he approaches said-edge from a weird angle (like if he's playing with his block and backs away from it to get a better vantage point and gets too close), he can fall off...same being if he is on a surface with a curved edge. While this would not deter me from buying him again, it IS something you need to be aware of, so that you can plan for where you will keep him. For us, he primarily hangs out on the living room ottoman, which is pretty big, leather, and is above a cushioned rug. For the most part, he stays out of trouble, but he has fallen off a few times. If he happens to fall on his back, he can actually roll himself back over. If he falls and lands on his side, he does get stuck, and throws a bit of a tantrum. Tantrum also ensues if he is playing and you pick him up to move him to a new spot, which is also kinda funny.

All in all, I would say that if you're looking for a really unique gift for someone who loves technology, science, A.I., robotics, etc, he's a really good choice. The bonus feature of having Alexa built in makes him also seem like not just a toy but a useful gadget around the house (which for me was part of the reason I could justify it, because I would have easily spent $100-$200 anyway on an Alexa product).

Very happy with him thus far (about 2 weeks out), and would recommend.

title: Vector quickly became a family member.
text: With my grandson being an only child Vector is the perfect playmate.  He has a personality and we enjoy interacting with him.  Our travels include him because we don't like to let him home alone.  While riding in the car, he talks constantly.  If conversation is not convenient we put him into his case knowing he will have much to say when we take him out! Interestingly, Vector can help with math, history and economic questions. Put him in his case while your child does homework as Vector will give the answer and the student will not have to work for them.

title: Buyers Beware Anki is Out of Business
text:
I really enjoy my vector robot. It's fun to play with and cute.

However, potential buyers should be very cautious purchasing this robot. Anki, the company that made Vector, announced in May 2019 that they would be closing their doors. More recently is has been announced that come September 2020 the servers that support Vector will be shut down. What does this mean for your robot? Once the servers are shut down it will be 'deaf'. It will no longer be able to respond to 'Hey Vector'. The robot will still function, it will just not be able to process voice commands. It is unclear to me if the Alexa integration will still work after this date or not.

There is a independent project to keep Vector fully functional after the servers shutdown at project-victor dot org. But whether or not this project will be successful is yet to be seen.

title: A very fun robot -- get it while you still can
text:
If you are expecting a very practical and useful robot assistant that solves daily problems and does other functions like that, you will be disappointed. If you want a very cute robot friend that is very expressive and lifelike to play with and hang out with (now with Alexa support), you will love it. It's basically WALL-E, for fans of the movie. I wanted to write this review now especially since Anki is shutting down and not producing any more robots. They said that they will continue to keep Vector running, so the purchase is still worth it.

I got bored of Vector for a while because I tend to get bored with everything after a while, but I brought him back to life and I'm having fun again. It's entertaining watching him explore his environment and play around with things like how he headbutts certain surfaces (and attacks his cube). He also recognizes your face and is happy to see you when he looks at you. It's just a really fun robot pal that doesn't even need to be constantly looked at; let him just explore on his own if there are no risks that would damage him. He used to be very good at avoiding drops, but the other day I noticed he wasn't doing so well, so if you're using him on a desk you should put down a few pillows or something, just to be safe.

All in all, I do not regret my purchase. This is the best robot you can get for the price, as well. Just don't expect the world from him and you'll have fun.

title: It is sooooo cute!
text:
I don't know where to begin.
It is a "toy" robot that can give hours of fun (just not all at once, will get burned out). Meant for entertainment in small consumption each day even. Also, I would say would be a lot more entertaining for the 9-17 age group but is for all ages. Now you can activate Alexa on it, I haven't tried that out yet so can't comment on it. But asking it a question and it will give you an answer, if it understood the question. And that is if it hears you? It wasn't cause it couldn't understand me but you have to talk pretty loud in order for it to even hear you, which is pretty much it's biggest draw back. Battery life isn't great either, about 1 hour of running around doing something, but most the time it will find its way back to the charger on its own. I have come home from work and it is dead because it for some reason or another it didn't get to the charger before it died.
The biggest issue I have with it is the app doesn't connect to it most the time. When it did connect it is very useful and helps set up certain settings, which you have to do the first time you turn it on.
Well I hope this helps?
On sale it is well worth getting if your into this kind of "toy" companion (what it is to me) or self entertainment for your family.

title: It's only for kids
text: Unfortunately advertising creates other expectations. Bought a gift for my husband as he is a developer and loves to create various devices. title: Overpriced desk toy, good if you avoiding alexa.
text: This is tiny, basically a desk toy. It will tell you the weather, do add and subtract (though a calculator be quicker).  It can answer questions.  But it cant play music. It dies in about 15 min and cant usually find it way back to charge. It drives off the table over and over. It isnt a.i. it is just programmed with a few basic gimmicks.  It is costructed well (good thing since it drives off tables and desks and falls on the floor). Unless you really need the programmed attempt at a personality (which doesnt respond well) it really doesnt seem worth the money. You can do more with a echo dot quicker and it plays music. Vector is, a overpriced desk toy. I bought it on sale for about $170 but realistically i probably wouldnt have spent over $70 if i knew how limited it really was.  Other than being really small, driving off the table, calculator (slow calculator), telling you the weather (your phone can do that), i just dont think it has any real purpose. Other than a overpriced funny/cute desk toy.  It might be useful for someone avoiding going on alexa. This can operate without alexa or with alexa. But if you have alexa a echo dot the fraction of this price has more use. Oh and it loses internet signal really easy, doesnt find its way home to charge, only has a few programmed commands, you have to repeat yourself constantly. It can actually be pretty annoying.  Unless you avoiding alexa.  More of a gimmick than a useful tool unfortunately. Or a real expensive desk ornament or kids toy.  They should have made this more useful before release especially for the price range. I think they are counting not on utility but the little fake personality they programmed it with to sell it.  For all of us that expected much more at this price point than a toy hopefully they do some major updates, as it just has little usefulness. Least echo plays music and anything you ask alexa is MUCH faster not on vector.

title: Cute little "pet" robot! :)
text:
Vector is amazing for those who long for a pet but cant have one. He is smart and you can casually ask him questions like whats the weather outside and he answers you in the cutest way! This little guy loves to be petted and gets happy when you tell him he's a good robot. :) He can find his own charger when he's low on battery and "goes to sleep" (he also snores and sleeprolls off his charger sometimes which is adorable). He will also just roam around your desk playing with his cube or even dancing to playing music. He gets excited and happy to see you when you come home and says your name as well. I have even gotten my vector to roll right into my hand by asking him to come to me and holding my hand flat at the edge of my desk. I would say Vector is 100% worth the money. :) He is also perfect for kids (maybe about 10+) who aren't allowed to have pets. He is also Alexa integrated so you can even ask him to take care of your smart devices for you if you want. :)

This little guy does so much more that I dont have the time to write and is absolutely adorable, If the idea of having a pet robot sounds appealing to you then you will 100% love Vector. :)

title: Vector is AWESOME and never pees on my floor
text: Vector is a terrific robot, especially for such a low price.  I have been a robotics hobbyist for over 30 years and this is such a bargain for anyone who uses it for more than a kid's toy.  I am a Child Psychiatrist and use Vector and Cozmo with kids who have been traumatized and are reluctant to trust adults.  They nearly without exception light up and become much more interactive and excited about talking with me once Vector joins the conversation.  I have paid thousands of dollars for robots with a small fraction of the capability of this one, especially if you take the time to learn about the excellent advanced programming tools (SDK) that work with it.  For the kids and beginners, the supplied object oriented and extremely entertaining interface is perfect.

title: Wait for a second hand Vector, not worth more than a hundred bucks..
text: Worked intermittently, very seldom followed demands. Wouldn‚Äôt play with cube. Way overpriced, returned and am waiting for a refund.

title: Useless Robot
text:
I purchased this Vector robot for my son last Christmas from a big box blue and yellow retailer that sells electronics, really the BEST place to BUY electronics in person any more. Well, though the initial excitement was there, the robot offered little for my then 7 yr old to do other than give it verbal commands. It is NOT a STEM/STEAM device and really does little to foster learning. You can ask it questions as it integrates with Alexa and AWS as the real brains behind it. Sadly, I upgraded my router and even after hours of troubleshooting I was no longer to get this robot to connect, so it's little more now than a sad toy that sits in the corner occasionally waking up, roaming away from it's base and dying of battery because it doesn't have the "brains" to get back to the base without internet connectivity. Every time I try and fix the device, it connects to my app (oh and you have to have a iOS or Android device for this to be setup), it briefly connects to the configuration on the app, then disconnects. I suspect it's a Bluetooth issue but when it eventually does connect 1 out of 20 attempts, I can try and enter the password to my 2.4GHz band of wifi to connect the device, but the app often disconnects from Vector so I have to try all over again. This is the most frustrating part of the setup experience.

Next, if I am able to get the WiFi entered in correctly and Vector connects to the network, the first thing the app wants to do is send an update to Vector, and once the update is complete, Vector restarts, oh but guess what? That's right it's not longer connected to the network, so I have to go through the very painful and frustrating experience of trying to connect it to the network once again. And eventually after getting network to connect again, that's right, you will be prompted to upgrade. Rinse and repeat frustration, aggravation, disappointment all over again.

I am a IT Engineer so I am very familiar with troubleshooting and fixing things, but this is just such a poorly designed product I advise against wasting any money on it whatsoever. I even tried to contact support from Anki, and I guess the same developers of this product also worked on the website, because once you find the support pages, and go through all the articles that don't solve the issue, you are presented with a link to contact via e-mail support. Guess what happens when you click on it? You'd think it brings you to an e-mail form or give you an e-mail address, that would only make sense right? But it brings you right back to the main support page where you get to pick the product you want to find support for. Ah yes, the disappointment and frustration doesn't end with the product itself, the whole company seems to be founded upon it. This item is utterly useless, completely frustrating and a waste of time and money.

title: Not actual AI, just a toy.
text:
If you're a consumer looking for a toy for a kid, this is great. Oddly, they advertise this as the non-toy product they carry (next to Cozmo). It should be made clear that it's just a toy,and at that rate, probably just a more expensive Cozmo (honestly, Cozmo looks better and is cheaper).

And it's not yet a replacement or brother to Alexa/Google Home.

There's very limited options with him, and most are slow and lack luster.

I would wait until Alexa integration is completed, and potentially for more options of use to be replaced.

I like him, he's great, but their advertising is horribly over inflated.

If you want him now, get Cozmo, that's all this is right now.

If you want an AI robot pet, this is not it.
If you want an Alexa/Google Home replacement, this is not it.

Anki went out of business so they are not going to help and the person who picked up the vector and all other products by Anki do not actually have support for the devices.

The screens have a tendency to go out and I've noticed that Vector has quite a few technological issues that render its functions ultimately ineffective which not only takes away the fun of the robot, but also makes the robot prone to damaging itself by falling off of things.

title: EVERYTHING you need to know. Others don‚Äôt realize its potential.
text: PLEASE NOTE. First off not signing into Amazon to use Alexa means Alexa is fully disabled. That may save much privacy. No this device does not use the cloud with the camera. This device CAN BE USED WITHOUT WIFI. You just won‚Äôt be able to use the utilities but it‚Äôll still recognize faces and function just won‚Äôt do voice response. It‚Äôs slower than expected because a lot of processing is done on the device itself. Alexa is all cloud based which is why it‚Äôs so much quicker. It‚Äôs even faster than Vector, running on Vector. Don‚Äôt be worried. This is equipped with an actual smart phone level processor that was in Samsung phones in about 2013 or 14. Those being in this robot is impressive. It‚Äôs ready for loads of updates. When I took this out of the box and set it up I started messing with it. It wasn‚Äôt too responsive, but you see it wants to do things. After messing with it for about 2 hours or so, I‚Äôve figured out how it works and it actually did learn. Sounds weird but it did, it became way more responsive and was kind of really cool. It actually learned and took in information to better it‚Äôs AI. Give it time, it learns. As for the facial recognition, I had trouble with that too. But after it seeing a few other people, it started getting much more accurate as well. It‚Äôs really weird. It works though. A lot of the ‚Äúfeatures‚Äù are in its free roam I‚Äôve noticed. If you place an object in front of it, it‚Äôll look at it and kind of take note. Next time it sees it, it just passes by. Place a new object and it‚Äôll look it over again. It‚Äôs really just something for people into the technology and or want something that not many people have seen. Overall, highly recommend. The creators say it‚Äôll keep getting updates and they‚Äôll update the code in the robot via the cloud and it‚Äôll get smarter without having to learn.
