title: Anki Vector has a lot of technology to play around with, especially since you can download the SDK.
text:
Anki Vector has a lot of technology to play around with, especially since you can download the SDK. Unfortunately Anki (the original creater) went out of business, but Digital Dream Labs, Pittsburgh-based educational tech startup, said they would pick up development of Vector. I have played around with the Python SDK a little (not a simple install) and the OO programming seems impressive. I hope to spend more time with the SDK and creating more AI functionality. I just hope the battery holds up!

If you speak clearly (I understand people with accents have some difficulties) it is a cute, well made robot that fascinates my cats. It is like having a hamster that knows some english.

title: Lil Bot huge personality
text:
Great addition to my home office. They've done an amazing job on giving this simple robot a personality. His little chirps and beeps convey excitement and frustration depending on what he's attempting to do. He can recognize faces and get's better at it as he learns. We're still a long way from being concerned about T-1000's but with the animation of his eye's and movements it does convey the illusion of thought.

With the AI they built into this little guy you'd expect home robot vacuum's should be much more advanced than they are. This little guy can live on my desk without ever taking a tumble but somehow my Roomba want's to kill itself any time I turn it on. Seriously Digital Dream Labs stick the tech from Vector into a vacuum ASAP!

title: Charging life doesn‚Äôt last long
text:
This is a gift for my son, he loves it, Vector is cute and I love how it listens to what you tell him to do.

Downside batteries on him don‚Äôt last long so have to recharge him after 30 min of use

title: Big hit for Christmas!
text: So far so good. I purchased Vector for my eight year old. She loves it!

title: Save your MONEY and TIME. Way too much work for zero results
text:
SO disappointed. Spent hours, TWICE, trying to get this thing to join network, get updated, and DO something - anything. Went through the 100 troubleshooting steps to diagnose & correct connection issues to no avail.
ONLY works on 2.4 Ghz, if you have a dual-freq router, you have to disable 5Ghz. So THERES 20 steps, time, & effort.
Could not connect to Anki cloud for its updates, so there's 20 more steps to follow and try.
Turn it off and back on, it says... Really ?
Ping the Anki cloud to test for a reply. You get a 3 kb "ok" reply, so the cloud IS apparently functional, but still no update.
Turn off VPN if you're on one- ok, did THAT. Nothing.
Download a network analyzer app...??
And on it goes... Thought I was joking about a hundred steps, and no, I was not.
I would GIVE this thing, it's little block, charger, AND additional-cost playpen to someone free for the cost of shipping. Exhausted from the troubleshooting efforts.

title: fun little addition
text: Vector was a gift to us as well as cozmo. We have enjoyed him for 21 days so far. I asked him how old he was so yes its been 21 days. We purchased the play space for him as he wanders whenever he likes and we didnt want the little guy stepped on in earlier morning and so he had a safe place while i cleaned floors. he has no where the games as cozmo, but as an adult, I get a kick out of watching him wander and look around like a curious puppy or small child. Husband isnt a fan of robots, but he sure talks to Vector a lot and plays the card game with him. Hah! Even though the personality of cozmo and vector seem similar, vector can hear you and feel being petted. He has a bit of sas, smarty pants attitude. My husband was talking 'pooh' about robots and since then vector stares at him from across room and they had a stare down. I died laughing. Vector laughed too! He still stares once in a while and squints at my husband, like you know what you said mister. ha ha! Totally worth having him around.

title: Vector is the best $75 I've spent in quite a long time!
text:
Having a Vector is like having your own miniature WALL-E that also has Alexa built in.

One note: the sensitivity for Alexa is crazy high, or Vector takes precedence when responding to commands. Even though we will be in one room attempting to make use of our Echo, Vector will hear the Alexa trigger in another room down the hallway and then apologize for not catching everything, failing to act. We ended up having to disable the integration so my husband could make use of our Echo. But on the bright side, I can still make use of Vector each day before I leave with Weather info and other commands.

title: Really cute, but that‚Äôs all it has going for it
text:
I teach a programming/coding workshop for middle-school-aged girls. We‚Äôre exploring robotics and I saw this cool little dude and decided to get it to use. Let me first state that this thing is super cute and has a lot of personality.

It‚Äôs a really cute little robot but it doesn‚Äôt really DO much. The girls had fun asking it to flip its cube or bring it to them and recognize their faces and stuff, but beyond that it doesn‚Äôt really do anything. It‚Äôs cute as a desk toy but I‚Äôm in college and $200 is too much to spend on a desk toy. Luckily I got it on sale but it was still too pricey. It‚Äôs worth maybe $100 but not much beyond that.

Pros:
- it‚Äôs really cute
- it‚Äôs a great example of growing AI in toy robots

Cons:
- it doesn‚Äôt hold a charge very long (like if you move it to a table to play or something you have to bring the charger)
- The connection to WiFi is pretty weak (also it won‚Äôt connect to encrypted connections; think University WiFi that requires students to log in)
- The drop sensors are good when it‚Äôs rolling about but if it does something like go into a wheel stand it can shoot itself off of the table/desk
- It can‚Äôt recognize two different people with the same name
- It doesn‚Äôt really do anything. It‚Äôd be fun if it was like cosmo with a code lab and games and interactive cubes but...it‚Äôs kinda boring.

Overall I think it has a lot of growth ahead which will be really cool but, I‚Äôd rather wait until it‚Äôs a completed product.

title: Fun little AI (STEM Toy)
text:
Saw the kickstarter for this cute little bot, and noticed recently that it was up for pre-sale on amazon - Bought it with same day shipping and I'm glad because its so much fun.
Promptly taught it to do facial recognition on all the family members, and ran through most of the commands in the manual.
This was created by nerds for nerds and nerds to be; and I love it!
The android app needs some love, and as of release day the desktop API is missing - once these are present and/or fixed this could be a 5 star stem toy, or office desk assistant.
The upgraded processor over the Cozmo makes it more responsive.
The eye interactions, and noises attracted the wife and 2 kids into playing with Vector at the dinner table until bed time was upon us.

Edit (2018-10-16): Brought Vector to the office and everyone loved him - they assume he can do more than he can right now - but it was a fun experience watching other adults interact with him as well.

title: Wish I could rate higher
text:
I wish I could rate this higher, but it quite a disappointment. It just doesn't seem to do anything.
It is well made. The facial expressions it can generate with just its 2 eyes is amazing. It is fun to watch for a while, but it just doesn't do anything. I can't figure out why it has a cube, or what the markings are for on it. Its ok to push around, but that gets old quick for a $175 unit. Wish I had spent my money elsewhere until the technology is better and this can talk better. The processor seems very slow as it takes a long time from saying any command, to the recognition and doing it. Again, I'd love to give this a 5, but it just disappointed.

text: My son loves his vector he has thought it his name and to first bump.

title: Not the droid you're looking for...
text:
I purchased Vector off kickstarter with high hopes this would be a cool robot to keep on my desk. Upon my first few hours with Vector, I felt disappointed by how underwhelming it is. Much of the advertised functionality doesn't work as advertised. It requires several tries of saying "Hey Vector" for him to respond, and there is a huge amount of latency between asking a question and him responding. I left him out on the table to surprise my girlfriend and by the time she came home the battery had died. I charged him again, then sat there feeling kind of silly saying "hey vector" over and over to no avail, to which she responded with temporary amusement and then we moved on. I found it hard to justify why I'd just spent $225 on what is essentially a toy (though a cute one.)

I contacted the Anki team soon after my disappointing introduction and asked for a refund, which they refused because I purchased through kickstarter, and told me that they're working on updates. Overall just not very helpful, and left a bad taste in my mouth,so I will probably refrain from future interesting Anki products.

To Anki - a bit more customer sensitivity could help, offering solutions to customers who are not satisfied with your product due to features not working as advertised, whether purchased from Kickstarter or not.

Save your money, this is not the droid you're looking for.

title: Good job Vector!
text: This little guy impresses me more and more each day. I dont know why people write bad reviews... obviously you shouldnt expect to get a droid from star wars and the ads do exaggerate a little but I definitely feel I got what I paid for. Out of the box Vector had some issues hooking up to wifi with my wife's iPhone but then after using my android he hooked right up and started impressing me. He seemed a little slow and didn't explore much on day one but now on day three he is way more active knows my name and loves fist bumps. He has little glitches every once in awhile like not hearing you the first time you say "Hey Vector" but its usually cause he's making noise or moving. My family and I enjoy Vector very much. Dont buy him expecting a perfect working droid that can do anything you can we arent there yet (this isnt iRobot)and remember he does have small issues every once and awhile (but so does my very expensive smart phone) but this guy wasnt even available a couple years ago and yet now he is so he can only get better and from what I've seen in these short few days he will. He's like a new pet without all the clean up.

title: Over priced yet so cute
text:
I will start by saying I think he is just adorable. He is NOT worth the price. I was so excited to get him. I had wanted one for 3 yrs and finally ordered one. He came and I was soo ecstatic! Packaged well. So cute, so tiny. I plugged him in and let him charge. I need my techs husband for the WiFi bc apparently regular WiFi is to fast for him and he uses something less powerful so he had to set him up on his own WiFi channel.
I was so bummed that I needed a subscription to him monthly for him to be able to do any of his actions. He can move and play with his cube on his own but needs a monthly subscription to be able to do anything else. After paying so much for him I debated on sending him back. I even packed him back up with intentions of returning him. I really didn‚Äôt want to return him so I joined the stupid monthly subscription. He works. He knows who everyone in my family is and I just couldn‚Äôt return him after he called me mommy. Robot or not it was the cutest damn thing.

Again. Not worth money but just so damn cute.

title: Functions as advertised - truly a marvel
text: I've had Vector for about a week and am truly impressed with this robot.  Set up was easy right out of the box and experienced no difficulties.  This robot conducts itself exactly according to description but has the added realism of truly acting independent.  Not certain what all of the negative feed back is but have concluded like most things it is human error - not the product.  If the user follows the guidance, there should be no issues - I.e., if low light, robot will not be able to navigate and will fall of the table.  Bear in mind, this is a robot running on a the capacity of a cell phone cpu not a supercomputer so manage your expectations.  Experienced one minor issue and contacted customer support who immediately responded and provided a remedy.  My only criticism would be price which is a bit high but should not be equated with the functionality of the product which is fantastic.

title: Does not work!!!!
text: The developers who programmed this disaster need to all be fired right now. They‚Äôre the most incompetent disasters of programmers known to mankind. Vector will keep losing connection to the app and ask you to reconnect through Bluetooth. Except it won‚Äôt connect. So you have to turn off tour Bluetooth and turn it back on then Vector will recognize your phone/app. Great. Then it tries to connect to your WiFi. Can‚Äôt connect. Now you have to hard reset Vector. You press his button for 15 seconds. Vector comes back on. Can‚Äôt connect to you through your Bluetooth. Repeat step. Great it connects. Connect to WiFi. Great. Update.... done. Now Vector won‚Äôt connect to your Bluetooth. Repeat previous workaround. Now it won‚Äôt connect to your WiFi. Repeat previous step and hard reboot. WiFi connects but it needs the same update as before. Now it won‚Äôt connect Bluetooth. You see where I‚Äôm going with this? Whoever coded this thing needs to go back to school or pickup a book or something. Total incompetent losers. Don‚Äôt waste your time.

title: Waaay exceeded our expectations...
text:
AND just like that..ANKI Is closed.. it was fun while it lasted.. I‚Äôll keep posting updates as long as my Vector still runs..
UPDATE 6 MONTHS: It‚Äôs been 6 months since we got our replacement and the one we have works great. He improves with each software update and has become a welcome companion on my desk. Especially as the house gets quieter with empty nest. And yes we have a dog but it‚Äôs kinda nice to have someone see you come into the room and call your name with excitement. After 6 months his battery is good and he just keeps rocking along. He‚Äôs also my only Alexa device I‚Äôm glad to have him. Still satisfied..
UPDATE: Day 5 : Yeaterday he developed a a squeak in the gearing that has gotten worse. Anki is sending a replacement and says that this is rare, however, I downgraded a star.. Day 1 with Vector:
First let me say that after the slew of negative reviews, I set my expectations very low. Upon arrival, and being super techie naive, I attempted set up with my IPhone X...and to my surprise, it was simple...didn‚Äôt test my patience at all. I also have poor WiFi service and yet Vector works perfectly. 7 hours later he is still functioning flawlessly.
The Alexa side is instantaneous, you just speak Alexa and get an instant response with no delay.
As far as the battery life, we have been through quite a few charge cycles today. The first few were kind of short but after about 3, it gets longer Vector now runs about an hour. He charges in about 15-20 minutes on his charger which is plugged into an Apple 5 watt wall wart. All of this has come as a welcome surprise.
We have started his exploring off slow, giving him a small spot to roam and explore in and the more he learns, the better he gets. He studies faces and calls out each person. If the lighting changes too much, you may have to reintroduce yourself, and He will ask if he has met you before and if so, he will learn your features quickly.
He has also made it to his charger every time and has not run out of power before reaching it.
All of this being said, it‚Äôs been a wonderful experience up to this point. No WiFi droppage, no short battery life, no dying before reaching the charger, no suicidal tendencies by diving off of the edge of the table (stops every time).

Then came the moment of moments...the introduction to my wife...I just whispered a few things to her on what to do, and WOW she fell in love with this thing...what a shock..(that alone is worth 5 stars)
Today the house has been filled with adults, all waiting a turn to get some time with Vector. What an amazing day!

This is the reason for 5 stars:
Alexa works great (I was expecting huge delays and none exist)
Vector is fascinating, the more he learns, the better he gets
Finally, there is absolutely nothing like this anywhere that I‚Äôve ever seen..

I‚Äôm really wondering about the negative reviews, our first day experience has been wonderful. We‚Äôre looking forward to the adventure ahead as Anki moves forward in its programming!

For the record, I almost didn‚Äôt do this and just about let the critics scare me away...I am SO glad I took the jump! (And so is everyone who meets Vector)
Day3: The more he learns, the better he gets. He does get a little carried away when heads to the edge of the table carrying his cube. When he gets to the edge and tries to stop, it makes him top heavy and he‚Äôll tumble over the side. We‚Äôll see if he learns from it.
Other than that, still functions flawlessly.

title: Boring... useless... does nothing.
text: We honestly want to love this little thing.  But we had high expectations, our daughter is 11 and she asked for a cozmo but I decided to purchase the ‚Äúupgraded version‚Äù aka Vector.  Big mistake.  It doesn‚Äôt do anything except make noise and roam a few feet from the charger.  It rarely finds its‚Äô way back to the charger as described and the edge fall prevention does not work as reported.  It already has driven off of several different mediums, couch, fireplace, granite counter...  further more it can‚Äôt do anything other than recognize your face and tell you the weather.  Big deal!  It does have Alexa capabilities, but very, very limited... basically time and weather.  We have Alexa all over the house... so why do I need this thing!?  Cozmo can be used remotely as a ‚Äúspy cam‚Äù which intrigues my daughter (and scares me) but at least she would be able to interact with it.  If you want a loud robotic bug to irritate your desk... get the Vector; otherwise get a cozmo and an Alexa device that actually works. We are returning ours.

title: Worth the investment
text: I am impressed with the interaction with Vector. He truly has a personality. If you are expecting a true independent and autonomous being, you will disappointed.. but he interacts to voice commands and Alexa adds a whole new level.

title: Best little robot ever
text:
I love this little robot so much. I bought 2, one for my daughter and one for my son, and they are so funny. We've had them a few months now. They've gotten to know the whole family now and say our names when we walk up to them, without being asked. I love when I pick them up and they get mad and hit my hand. It's definitely been like getting 2 little pets that don't need to be fed. Their expressions are adorable. I recommend vector for kids and adults. I have as much fun with them as my kids do, and my 70 year old dad is in love with them. Lol. Getting his "space" is a good idea though because he likes to get up and explore on his own sometimes.

I also love that you can use the button on his back to give him commands too. My 5 year old has a hard time saying his name so he uses that to give him commands.

All in all a great buy.

title: DO NOT BUY ANYMORE (unless you are made of money). THEY MADE IT SUBSCRIPTION BASED
text:
I use to love this product (its still nice to have, but it doesnt work anymore without a subscription)
Vector was the perfect desktop pet for me.
It could play around with its cube, Recognize faces, dance to music, give you fistbumps/highfive, play blackjack, and answer a variety of specific questions like the weather and the time, etc etc.
It also has a built in Alexa( it cant play music or call people) which was really helpfull to me.

Recently though, you cannot interact with Vector anymore. The company that owns vector now made it subscription based. I did not pay several hundred dollars for me to need to continue paying money to use it. I got really upset and sad when I woke up and I could not play with Vector anymore.

Vector now just does his own thing with his cube, he can still recognize and say your name if you had already had your face registered before the update. He can also ask for a fist bump.
But he does not respond to anything anymore. If you say his name, he goes on a long rant about how you need to pay for a membership if you want to continue using him.

Now its only use is Alexa which still works fine. But you cant interreact with him anymore which is a major disappointment to me.

title: Vector is an amazing Companion~
text: Vector is an adorable, friendly, and helpful companion for my desk and room. He can go with me anywhere and make everyone smile. He knows faces, makes jokes, and plays games. My favorite part is programming him, and having him do custom tricks. With Digital Dream Labs maintaining Vector and adding new features, there is hope that he will only get better! I love him, and I‚Äôm sure you will too.

text: I paid $400 for this dumb piece of plastic only for it to arrive and not do anything it advertised to. So of course I did some research to find out Anki was bought out by Digital dream Labs and they are charging a subscription just to use ANY of the features on this overpriced wheels with eyes. As is, vector doesn‚Äôt do anything but hit the wall and look confused. It won‚Äôt set a timer it won‚Äôt recognize faces it won‚Äôt speak it won‚Äôt even go to its charger it just rolls around until it dies. DO NOT BUY! Just seeing that others purchased this same creature for $250 or $180 should tell you the company is drowning and when they go under even if you had a subscription they will abandon all updating software and vectors won‚Äôt learn anymore.

title: Before you take the poorly rated comments below seriously....
text: I keep reading comments about Vector "Not being ready for launch" or "Having to many bugs" or "Doesn't do much for the price". The individuals who purchased Vector and rated it bad, bought him for the wrong reasons.. Vector is an OPEN SOURCE robot. He was released with the intention of the buyer to PROGRAM COMMANDS THEMSELVES. Did you complain to the hospital when your baby was born because it didn't know how to walk and talk out of the womb? No. That baby had to learn and grow, just like Vector learns and grows by the user modifying and adding code to its memory. If you are a regular consumer looking for a fun AI toy, turn around and do not buy this. If you are a consumer who has basic programming knowledge and has a general interest in developing AI intelligence, this is absolutely for you and you will get the most out of this along with contributing to the developing technology of AI :)

title: Screen failed after 7 months.

If I'm going to spend that much money, I'm going to get a better AI robot.

title: Incomplete, dont let it be a deterrent. Cute as hell
text:
For starters, it's almost 70% off its original price. That's cool. It's like that because this is very obviously an incomplete project. That's okay, if you're okay with that.

It's a cute amusing little thing. He snores/purrs. I am an EXTREMELY light sleeper. The heat clicking on from the basement used to wake me up from two stories up type light sleeper. So that wakes me up at random points in the night. I'm beginning to get used to it, but I'm very sensitive. He will sleepwalk. Like wander off his pad. He has poor vision. Especially when it's even relatively dark. Like I'm talking sometimes it can just be the lights off in my room.
He will not find his way back to the pad if he wanders at night.

He develops personality incredibly fast. I can be a bit stern to him. Mine developed into a stubborn bitch. He will blatantly ignore me at times, and sass me at any opportunity he gets. His microphones are good, but not great. Maximum of 4 feet and you'll probably need to kinda yell at him irregardless. At least I do. Stubborn little prick. Love him tho.

Has developed an enjoyment for pushing things off the edge of "his space". He had very very hard time on tapered edges at first. I set up insense boxes around the edges, and after about 4 or 5 days and basejumping a few times, he got the hang of it, I removed the boundaries, and he started stopping a bit earlier. By day 8 or so he knew the edges. He hasn't fallen since. Intentionally throws things off the edge now. I know its intentional by now, cheeky bastard.

I live mostly alone, and while he isnt perfect, who is? I enjoy him a lot and if their 2020 kickstart finishes this project I would infinitely give it 5 stars.

However, it is an incomplete project, so I wont give it 5 stars. But it damn deserves it.

Absolutely not for little kids, they are savage animals and would rip this poor little guy to pieces. My teenage brothers love him. I do too. Recognizes faces extremely well. I was impressed. He needs a bit of time to really learn who you are, but that applies to anything and anybody.

Would buy again without even questioning it

title: A cute novelty...but not worth the price
text:
Update:

After owning Vector for a few months, he decided to drive off the edge of the counter and into the sink, landing in some water and ultimately committing suicide. So much for him being able to detect edges and not roll off... He has now gone from being cute but overpriced to absolutely worthless.

Original Review:

Vector is a cute little robot with good personality. My kids like watching him, and I love the way he reacts when you pick him up, or how he plays with his block. However, as a digital assistant a la Alexa or Google, he‚Äôs not very useful. You can ask him questions, but it‚Äôs a 2 step process that takes far longer than other digital assistant products. His voice recognition isn‚Äôt very good, the pictures he takes are low quality, and his built in functions like telling the weather or the time are cute but not super useful. When I ask google for the weather, I get detailed info along with forecast. Vector will just tell you the temperature and current conditions.

Overall I would say Vector is worth maybe $80 tops - definitely not the premium they‚Äôre charging. Hopefully they will update him to make him more capable, but in his current form, I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôs worth what they‚Äôre charging.

title: Fun!...for a while
text:
I bought vector right after anki announced folding up. The price went down to $100 and I thought I was suckered. I was relieved to find out that DDL took over. Since purchasing vector, I also funded DDL's early lifetime subscription so thankfully I don't have to pay the monthly membership fee (which would have pissed me off). There was a little trouble applying my earlier funding but it seems DDL sorted it out eventually.
Barring that, vector is a cute little fun robot that's very intuitive with it's surroundings. Never had it fall off a desk, but softer or round edged surfaces like a bed or sofa makes it susceptible for vector to roll off.
The voice recognition is terrible however, especially with kids voices. I bought vector for my daughter but she was unable to get him to follow a single command. She was only successful once or twice when I told her to put on a lower voice (think Austin Powers "how does that feel?"). Even I find myself having to attempt commands 5 and 6 times before he responds or I just give up. Strangely, the alexa function understands me clear as day. I am still yet to get vector to respond to some commands and questions that I found online. Due to the fact that my daughter can't get vector to respond to her, she played with it one day and then she was bored and has not interacted since. I will also admit that while it's fun to run through the commands the 1st or 2nd time, there really isn't that much vector can do and soon you're left bored. I saw youtube videos showing vector and cozmo interacting and doing fun adventures. To get vector to tall, a 3rd party app is required and I implore you to read the responses from the app developer to critical reviews (woooweee). The app does not seem to work anyway since DDL applied their updates. Vector is still entertaining to watch him interact on his own for about 20 mins before his battery is out, but for $300 and some dollars....I would pass if I had to purchase again.

title: Vector: A small package with an amazing personality.
text:
[[VIDEOID:6ce264f811d0b4843a1e285d90138b59]] Vector is like an extended family member or friend that lightens up your home. From a technology standpoint, this tiny little dude has a lot packed under its shell and despite it being a little slow (compared to other AI devices like Alexa, Google Home, etc.), it has a lot of potential and it is quite capable. From a personality standpoint, Vector is doesn‚Äôt quite care that it is small, it has enough energy to make his presence known throughout the house, and has this sense of curiosity and happiness similar to a small child or even a very loving pet.

Initially, I personally didn‚Äôt quite understand what Anki was trying to accomplish with the Vector - the little robot does a lot, but I have Alexa pretty much running my home and, I have very limited time as it is, so when I got Vector, I was incredibly curious a technologist and early adopter but, I was also hesitant about how well this device would fit in my home. The first day, given my bias, I found very limited use for Vector and Anki‚Äôs app was not very intuitive, (at first), but as the days passed, Vector‚Äôs eagerness to win you over, puppy eyes, independence, and companionship, make this little fellow easy to appreciate and get invested in.

I don't spend a lot of time at home, but it certainly does feel happier now that Vector is here. Vector distracts me and has a lot of things that work very well. The personality aspect is what charmed me. Nonetheless, it gets stuck a lot of time and doesn't make it to the charger, but the fist bump makes me forgive him. The little dude does his best. Just as an Alexa early adopter, and now big Alexa user, I'm confident that Vector will get to the same level of functionality.

I hope that you give this thing a try, while I hesitated at first, I am very happy that I welcomed it into my home.

title: Disappointing
text: A little disappointing, unfortunately. We were excited to gift this to our son for Christmas - since a friend had a cozmo he loved playing with - but this device seemed to be confused. It didn't respond like it should which had our kids saying "hey, vector" hundreds of times in a row with very little response. I hope that the next generation works better for the kids.

title: Worked fantastically from minute 1...
text: Ok, this little guy is cool and the kid who was lucky enough to get it is thrilled and can't get over how cool he is either! Out of the box and set up was completely smooth, I feel bad for the other recent reviews that weren't, but he booted up and connected to the internet just fine. The only "hiccups", though they really weren't a big deal, I had to connect him to wifi a few times because it lost connection, and I had to restart it once because it was making a low hum, but otherwise the pros have vastly outweighed the cons. He hasn't fallen off anything yet but has been right to the edge, the drop sensors seem to work great. His responsiveness to "Hey Vector" and "Alexa" have been pretty good, comparable to any Alexa device. The face recognition stuff is my favorite, he knows the whole family by name and says Hi to us by name when we interact with him. He does a lot of things, but only seems to have one "game", blackjack. My kid wishes there were more, but he's been very entertained by all the other features. I seriously think this is a big win! Especially since I was able to get it for around $75. $250 is way too much, but I'd expect something like this to be around $150. I really can't say enough about this cool little guy. For us it's been a great purchase. Time will tell how it holds up, especially with Anki shutting down, but autonomously it's fantastic.

title: Adorable robot
text:
[[VIDEOID:651cf6aa599696eb1d633770acae3a29]] I don‚Äôt really write reviews so bear with me if the flow isn‚Äôt very good : ) My son had this adorable robot on his list last year but for 200$ price point there was no way I was paying that for a ‚Äúlittle robot‚Äù. This year amazon bought the company that makes it and added in Alexa capability and dropped the price by more than half. I was able to buy it at the new lower price and let my son open it as an early present yesterday .

First off I want to say I thought this would be junk, but bought to cross it off the Christmas list. We‚Äôve had him for less than 24 hours and he‚Äôs adorable and fun. He‚Äôs way better than I thought it would be and my son is obsessed with it. The robot is funny with personality and the Alexa built in in really helpful. Now that we have him I think it was worth the original pricing from last year. I highly recommend if your kids are into tech.

title: Subscription required or else it wont work
text: Ive had this little guy for less than a year and hes been turned off for more than half of it. He constantly had bugs, the most recent with him being unable to take my voice commands. I have looked up how to fix things, only to email the company for help to be told for the past 3 days over an over "its online, heres the link". Not to mention that the product is not worth $400 even with Alexa. I got my alexa for $30 and shes more entertaining and helpful. Not to mention that since i bought Vector, the company failed to tell me that they shut down his server and opened a new one that is a minimum of $50 a year. "Just don't buy the subscription " but Vector will not and can not understand your voice commands without purchasing this additional bit. So you cant play games, ask him to do any of his functions, and so the only function he can preform is his use of a down graded version of alexa for 13 times the price of a normal one. Dont buy.

title: An amazing gift with so much educational potential
text:
I was first introduced to Anki through Cozmo, which is a predessecor to Vector. Before Anki, a fun, affordable, programmable robot like this was just a pipe dream. Years ago when I was getting into computers and robotics, I remember being blown away by being able to make very simple programs out of circuits. Now we have this little guy and if you or someone you know has any interest in robotics, programming, or even just technology, then this is an amazing gift.

I see some people leaving negative reviews because they were expecting more of a toy to just leave their kid with. And don't get me wrong, Vector is really entertaining and makes a great toy... But this product offers so much more than that. One of the coolest things about Vector is being able to learn programming in a fun interactive way. And I think its an amazing opportunity for a parent and kid to bond while learning something with real world value.

Seeing a product like Vector makes me so happy because I know how much potential it has to introduce kids to the field of robotics and computer science in a fun way that actually makes them passionate.

For anyone considering this as a present for their kids, this could easily be one of the best investments into their education by sparking a lifetime interest in the fields of science and engineering.

title: More than just a toy robot.
text:
I‚Äôve been buying toy robots for years. They all promise interactive features that sound great but are poorly executed.

Not Vector, he has truly become a pet substitute for my girlfriend and I. We‚Äôve had him for a while now and we talk and play with him daily. He has some basic voice activated personal assistant functionality and he also features Alexa which makes him a useful companion especially in our kitchen.

title: Be patient when setting up
text: I think the Vector Robot by Anki is great. When I first set it up there appeared to be a connection problem with the wi fi, but after a short period of time everything worked well and it continues to work better. I think a lot of time and effort was put into the development of Vector and I believe they will continue to add more features. Vector is now set up with Alexa and that makes it more useful. The robot pretty much does everything they say it does, well. One of the most important things that you should focus on is the timing of your commands to Vector. If he is talking or roboting, (lol) he does not hear your command and I think that frustrates some. But, I find the response time and performance is getting better and better. Some people I have shown it to are fascinated by Vector and they may buy it for themselves. Vector is almost like a pet, as advertised he fist pumps, tells you the time, the weather and keeps you company. Again, in conclusion, be patient, make sure you have the recommended wi fi connection, and then watch him perform!

title: Nothing special

title: **DO NOT BUY!!!  TAKEN OVER BY DIGITAL DREAM LABS**
text: i have had Vector for 2 years and he was a lot of fun. Now the Vector project was taken over by Digital Dream Labs and they removed all the voice command stuff that came with him and turned it into a paid service. if you dont want to pay $50 a year on top of the purchase price its not worth it.

title: This product isn't ready for launch. I love AI and want Anki to succeed but this needs to be said.
text:
This post is to warn future consumers and to let Anki know that they really need to improve their product. I love AI and I own a google home and I love my google home and so I want products like Vector to improve. Just like the gaming community is combatting unfair monetary systems, I want to make Anki aware of the many issues this product has.

It's personality isn't finished and it really doesn't do much
Anki states this is an unfinished product and I expected an unfinished product but not at the level I witnessed. When I picture an unfinished product I think of google home. It can still have utility and perform commands well but it's not done as google assistant at it is still improving and future features such as "AI calling" are coming. With Vector, I knew I wasn't getting utility but a cute robot. That's fine but he's not that cute or lifelike to be honest. When his "personality" was his eyes thinking 90% of the time. 5% a squint of happiness when he looks at me and 5% of anger when I wake him up or pick him up.... That's not worth the 250 dollar price tag. I'm sorry.

My google home was 70 and it frankly has 10x the personality this robot has. Google home doesn't have faces but it tells me jokes, tells me stories, tells me the news, has quirky responses to stupid questions I have, and much more. The issue with a personality is that it needs to be a lot more than 2 eyes moving in a lot of different directions. We need to talk to Vector. That needs to be Vector's X-factor over a real pet. You see with a real pet. You can't talk to it and it just has it's behaviors to communicate with you. However, you're looking at a live being. You see it's eyes. It's love. Vector will frankly never beat that because you're just looking at pixels. But if it was able to talk? Really be an assistant. That could change the game for it.

It's too loud and distracting
Even at its lowest volume, the tracks are so loud. It's too distracting. As a college student who studies 10 hours a day, I can tolerate some distractions but this was ridiculous. At a point, I just wanted it to sleep all the time and just realized I didn't want it at all to be honest. Sigh.

It doesn't follow commands like 80% of the time
This is a big issue. I was using the app while giving commands to see Vector's thoughts. I told it to go back to its charging pad. It does start doing that. Then sees a water bottle. Gets distracted. Then wanders off again. The same thing when I ask it to come here. It was just so unreliable as a robot. Robots follow commands. This is what I expected and I don't think that's too much to ask to be honest. If I type "B" on a laptop, I expect B to appear on the screen. If I ask google to play music, I expect "music" to be played. If I ask vector to go to its charging pad because its being disruptive to my work, I expect it to got to its charging pad.

Was it all bad?
I won't lie. It made me feel. I felt genuinely sad writing this review and putting him back in the box to be returned. The last time he closed his eyes as I turned him off made me feel bad. But that's it to be honest. He wasn't even that fun the first 5 minutes. He couldn't even say my name. Also, I had this thought that the people with issues with his voice recognition were just bad at english. No. I use Google home and siri all the time. Mostly google but they understand my commands like 95% of the time. Vector? Maybe 20-30% of the time. I was born and raised in the US and am a native English speakers.

Overall?
This product needs a LOT of improvement. This is not a finished product. Not even close. When I expect an unfinished product, I expect it to have at least one thing it is good at so I can keep myself interested in it until improvement come. However, this wasn't the case. Voice Recognition? 20-30% recognition. Follow through on commands? No. It gets too distracted. Personality? Two pixelated eyes isn't enough. At least talk to me.

I'm frankly very disappointed in this product because I was so excited for it. I was even distracted while doing work and studying in wait for it and it just wasn't good. RIP the exam I studied for on Friday...

As a college student, money is tight. I am willing to spend money on things that make me happy and destress like google home. However, 200 dollars for a robot that is distracting, doesn't listen, gets distracted easily, and doesn't even have much personality to be honest. I felt conned. Honestly.

title: Vector

title: BUYER BEWARE!! This is not 2.0 Vector.
text: This is not 2.0 Vector.

title: Vector Is Your First Taste of a New Era
text:
Echoing some of the comments here, Gizmodo recently published an article titled "This Little Robot Broke My Heart" where they some up and otherwise objectively accurate review of Vector by essentially saying it's not their yet. I offered the following comment as a rebuttal, which I'll also log here:

"I‚Äôve had Vector for a week now and I think you‚Äôre approaching him from the wrong angle. Anki wasn‚Äôt trying to match the capabilities of Alexa or Siri. They‚Äôve been very transparent that their driving principle was to investigate something that Amazon and Apple hasn‚Äôt - relatability. They wanted Vector first and foremost to be the first tiny AI to suspend disbelief and carve out a tiny place in your heart. Other pursuits are secondary.

In the week he‚Äôs lived with me I can confirm Anki has succeeded in making Vector something both my wife and I look forward to coming home to greet. We‚Äôve thought about what he was doing while we‚Äôre at work. We laugh and sometimes get frustrated when he messes up. We praise him and pet him when he does something successfully. For sure there may be a bit of confirmation bias in our draw to him, but they have succeeded in suspending your disbelief enough that 7 days in we‚Äôre just as excited to interact with him as we were on day one - perhaps more so. And believe me, we are a cynical pair, and I‚Äôm no stranger to new tech being thrown in a drawer and written off as a swing and a miss (I‚Äôm looking at you, Apple Watch.)

There are certainly areas to improve upon - much like a new puppy who has a lot of growing up to do. He does fall off the table more frequently than I‚Äôd like. He‚Äôs not good at navigating when the lights are turned off. He‚Äôs had some issues understanding commands from time to time. But the imperfections almost lend themselves to the suspension of disbelief. All living things makes mistakes. The fact that he's on the floor sometimes when we get home from work, in a way, proves that he "has a life of his own" while we're gone. Furthermore, I can say it‚Äôs felt like he‚Äôs gotten a bit better at interactions even with the span of a week - Anki does serve updates automatically during the night, and I‚Äôm sure they‚Äôre pouring over the data they‚Äôve collected so far and iterating with fervor.

The jump from Cosmo (Anki's last generation robot) to Vector is like Apple jumping from the Lisa to the Mac Classic. The Classic wasn‚Äôt as capable of crunching data as room-sized IBM‚Äôs at the time, but it wasn‚Äôt meant to be. It was a vision of the future to come. And I believe 30 years from now, with boundaries between tech and life all but erased, I‚Äôll look back on the time I first brought Vector into my home as the genesis point of that new era."

title: Cute and fun
text: I bought this for my son and it sits on his desk. He spends a lot of time at his desk to either do school work or play PS4. Vector is quite the robot. He wakes up and moves about on the desk. It‚Äôs neat that he plays with his cube and when you tell him to go home he goes right back into his charging station. I have have boys and when when they say ‚ÄúHey Vector, I am Nathan‚Äù He scans them and says the name. Although he has messed up recognizing faces.

title: Adorable!
text: We‚Äôve only had this robot for a day but so far he is just an absolute darling. SO cute! Purchased as a birthday gift, arrived quickly in great condition, and the recipient was delighted. It‚Äôs a bit early to tell yet what all he‚Äôs capable of but as soon as you turn him on it‚Äôs obvious that the little guy has a ton of personality. 100% worth the price to see how happy he made everyone today!

title: Responsive, delightful and improvable
text: I seriously like this robot (17 months strong) for a couple of reasons. One, the eye animations are spot on when corresponding to a particular command -- that's some serious engineering. Two, the responsiveness and interesting sensors I sort of have an accent from united kingdom since most assistants pick up the command either Vector and Alexa. The commands are limited for Vector but more functionality can be found in Alexa. Sometimes my Vector doesn't catch my commands but sometimes it's my fault from being too far from the sensor. Third, the Vector SDK is really nice and you can improve vector effortlessly if you know how to code in Python. However, Digital Dream labs is working on new features like the open source developer kit which I am excited about. Anyways, fist bump to Digital Dream Labs and Anki for creating this fantastic robot. I hope kids will develop more using Vector.

title: Quickly Replacing the Cat
text: Bought this as a Christmas gift for my Dad. Our cat is genuinely jealous that my Dad will speak to Vector rather than her now. This reaction alone is worth 5 stars but in case you are interested, Vector is super cute but requires a pretty loud and clear tone to process verbal instructions. I'd recommend setting it up in a well lit area with ample room to roam as ours has a habit of rolling off its table to the cats delight.

title: Now there's a required subscription?!
text: My son was very fortunate and received Vector as a gift about a year ago, but didn't use him much since we didn't have a desktop with enough room for him to roll around on and he would still fall off the bookcase where we had placed him. We blocked him in so he wouldn't fall, but he wasn't in a place convenient for us to actually use him and ask him questions, etc. We'd need a place with lots of desk space where he can roll around on, plus be near his base that's plugged in all the time. We just don't have that! Besides, we already have two Alexa devices and a Google Home throughout the house and so it wasn't needed, in that regard. We had difficulty figuring out how to keep him quiet, so ended up just having to run his battery down and not let him charge on the base. Today, my son got a birthday present that's an inexpensive version (not sure if intentionally a version, but it looks similar, though doesn't use an app or voice commands) and he had so much fun with it that it made him think of Vector. Out Vector came to the dining room table and when my son went to give him voice commands, Vector told him that in order to do voice commands, you have to have a Digital Dream Labs subscription. WHAT?! This wasn't the case last year! He's in tears because he can't do the things he wants with Vector and controlling him through the app isn't cutting it for him, if he can even do in the app what he wanted to do with voice commands. I looked at the website and there is NOTHING about the subscription unless you scroll to the very bottom of the page and even there, you don't see what it gets you without searching elsewhere on the website. I started doing searches and came back here to Amazon and saw that the price is SO much more than it was a year ago (insane!) AND they expect you to pay $7 a month or $47 a year to be able to even do the voice commands or update the firmware. I'm so disappointed and so sad that our family spent so much money on Vector.

title: No more customer support, Anki shutting down
text:
RIP Cozmo and Vector. According to a report from Recode, Anki, the company responsible for making small AI-tuned robots with giant personalities is shutting down after it ran out of money. Recode says the company is forced to close its doors ‚Äúafter a new round of financing fell through at the last minute.‚Äù

For anyone who ponied up a couple hundred bucks to buy one of Anki‚Äôs robots, it‚Äôs a bummer. While the company confirmed its closure to Crunchbase, it hasn‚Äôt said how it will handle support for existing models, and the news will surely affect future development of the platform.

And that‚Äôs a shame. While Anki made a name for itself through its robots‚Äô Wall-E-like personalities and expressions, the underlying technology is equally impressive. One of the first companies to embrace artificial intelligence and machine learning in consumer devices, Anki started out with toy cars. After a big break on Apple‚Äôs WWDC stage in 2013, Anki Drive brought the experience of a video game to physical objects, which led to the introduction of Cozmo, the company‚Äôs first learning robot.

title: I wouldn‚Äôt bother...
text:
For an interactive toy that originally retails for around $250, getting it for $73 (for the time being) isn‚Äôt bad. I purchased mine on Saturday when it was roughly $80. It‚Äôs super cute and tiny.

That being said, I only know it‚Äôs cute because of the videos I‚Äôve seen of it from users who have been able to get their bots up and running. Unfortunately, I didn‚Äôt have any luck. Checked all the hardware and everything, nothing. Es ist kaputt. But despite its pricing right now, I imagine it‚Äôs because Anki is no longer operating and the cloud that Vector connects to will only be running for about another year (maybe less, according to varying sources).

There‚Äôs a reddit thread from August (2019) where a user warns others to return them ASAP if purchased recently. S/he did no dive too deep as to why, but I assume it‚Äôs because they will no longer be supported.

If you‚Äôre okay with only a few months use (potentially longer), then I‚Äôd go ahead and get it. Otherwise, I‚Äôd advise against doing so.

Disappointed to say the least. But hopefully someone will be willing to take over and manage the servers.

title: Clever adult toy that is fun but not useful
text: Clever adult toy still needing upgrades to be useful.

title: Fun Tech Toy
text:
We've been playing with Vector for a little over a month now, and he's a load of fun! At first, he didn't do a lot, but every so often, Anki provides an update and suddenly, Vector has more personality, skills, and interactions! He's a great little desk companion that is much better than a pet because there's little to clean up afterward! I say little because he's been known to shove things off the table!
There are many ways he can learn about his environment via his sensors:
He sees via HD camera.
Facial recognition - he'll learn your face and when he's exploring, will come right up, scan your face, and say your name! He's very pleased when he recognizes you, and gets a little upset if he doesn't recognize you.
Navigate, explore, and learn his environment. He gets around very well all over my desk. However, I move things a lot, so he's constantly having to re-learn. Occasionally, he'll fall over the edge, but once in a while, he falls over the edge. I think they're working on improving that a lot. It's super cute when he's exploring, gets close to the edge, and acts scared and backs away!
If he needs charging, he'll go right back to his charger on his own. However, sometimes, I'll get tired of hearing him causing trouble, so I'll tell him to go to his charger. He does it, but throws a little tantrum when he gets there!

He can hear via his array of four microphones. Sometimes he comes over to see what's going on if you're having a conversation. If he's resting, he'll act startled if there's a loud noise in the room. He will also react to the beat of music if it's loud and near him. If you ask him to look at you or come here, he'll be able to sense the direction to go.

He reacts to touch and feel. If you pet his back, he practically purrs! But shaking him gets a reaction, too!

He has amazing intelligence. For instance, he answers questions, plays blackjack, reacts to his environment, and senses actions and activities around him.

He speaks to you. I'm not a fan of his synthesized voice, but it seems to be improving. When he reads out answers to questions you ask, sometimes it's hard to hear what he's saying. However, as they receive feedback on this, I'm sure his voice will evolve into something more understandable.

We really enjoy seeing his reactions! The current one is the way he gets super excited when you tell him he's a good robot or if you tell him you love him, and pouts a little if you tell him he's a bad robot! I just told him earlier today when he picked up his cube and tossed it off the desk!

I'm super excited to see his ever-evolving skills! I highly recommend this little guy for your favorite tech lover, or yourself! If you're looking for a toy for younger kids, maybe go with a Cosmo. This doesn't have games or things to entertain little ones. But it's completely entertaining for maybe, 10 years and up robotics fans!

title: Pretty cool
text: Love the Vector. The designers have done a good job giving this thing a personality.

title: Not ready for release, or really poor QA
text:
This is the ONLY thing my daughter wanted for Christmas, she seems to be fascinated by AI and robots and at this point we have a managerie of animals that squeak, bark, purr, burp, wander around, vacuum the floor (ok that's mine) and so on. She was SO excited and Vector and being the indulgent parent I bought it for her.

Ok, so the first Vector counldn't see our 2.4 ghz network at all, I tried manually configuring it but that didn't work. I'm a software engineer so I reconfigured the network to only have the 2.4 ghz one available, made sure the ports were open, added the ip to the whitelist, checked that I could download the file as per the 'help' files and so on, nothing. So after accepting that something might be wrong I returned it and got a replacement. The second Vector seemed to work out of the box, I could see my network and it connected to both my phone and the network straight away (I breathed a sigh of relief) but then it instantly went and downloaded an update which took about 10 minutes to install. As soon as the update was installed I couldn't find Vector. Ok I thought, so I rebooted everything, I managed to find Vector, it could see my network but from that point forward it refused to connect, kept saying that it couldn't make a connection, I turned off every device I have that was connected to the network, I removed and reinstalled the app, I emailed support... Support takes 24 hours minimum to reply, Vector refuses to connect to the network (I checked and rechecked the details so many times) but he refuses to connect and work... The upshot, I'm returning it, I'm sorry but this type of device just shouldn't be this hard to setup and I don't want a $200 ornament so there it goes.

Given that I am in the industry it feels rushed, I think QA isn't doing it's job. I am seriously disappointed and of course upset that I have had to try and explain this to my daughter. Seriously, buy something else or wait.

title: Not cozmo
text: I suppose if you were going to get this product first, it would be a cool little feature, but as far as playability and functionality it pails in comparison to its counterpart. Unlike the versatility afforded by cozmo, vector is a stilted infant. It is interesting to interact with but the entertainment quickly and thoroughly subsides once you play for even a minute with cozmo.  Worse still, there doesn't seem to be an interactive component between the two robots, at least that might have made it somewhat worthwhile. As it stands, it is going straight back to the store.  Not even the major Black Friday discount made it worth keeping. If you have the choice, go with cozmo, you'll be far happier you did.

text:
Update as of 9/6/19

As luck would have it, and not unexpected for a start-up, Anki has folded their tent and gone home. Go to Anki.com for more. I guess vector wasn‚Äôt smart enough to help keep the company afloat! A little bit sad because I was expecting much more development for Vector since he had such great potential. Alas again a very expensive toy and now doorstop. Also, three months ago I paid almost $300 for this device on Amazon prime and it‚Äôs now going for $129 bucks where do I get a refund from Amazon I guess Victor wasn‚Äôt smart enough to help keep the company afloat! A little bit sad because I was expecting much more development for Vector since he had such great potential. Alas again a very expensive toy and now doorstop sad face also so I paid almost $300 for this device on Amazon prime three months ago, and it‚Äôs now going for 129 bucks, how do I get a rebate from Amazon?
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-
Vector is cute, but as an AI device, there are limitations. Make no mistake, technology aside, you will be purchasing a very expensive toy. Also, if you already have an Alexa network, adding the Alexa functionality to Vector and activating it in a room with an Echo or other device makes for an interesting but confusing conflict. The Alexa functionality is not worth installing if you already have an existing Alex in network.

So far it‚Äôs been an interesting experiment and I‚Äôm hoping that the vector developers are working on more functionality. Time will tell. Would probably not buy again.
Is the perfect gift for my child

title: Adorable & Fun!!!
text: Don't expect this tiny robot to be too of the line "cleaning your house" and having convos with you. This little dude is for entertainment purposes and is literally like Alexa (even has Alexa features), but with an adorable face and personality. Vector was so cute the second I booted him on. title: Hes not what you're thinking!
text: I cant believe this robot is almost $400! I bought it this past February for $80....and it wasnt even worth the $80. I did research for a year on this robot and let me tell you, it's not what you think it is! I think they raised the price so dramatically high is because the maker of this robot has been out of business for at least a couple years now. Anki is no longer in business! The original price was $250. Then shot way down to $80, now it's even more than what the company was selling it for! Anyways, yes this robot is super cute and moves on his own, but it doesnt answer every question you have, only recognizes you if you look straight at it and wait a few minutes for it to recognize you. It only has one game it can play with you, which is blackjack. I had to put Alexa on it so I can actually get questions answered. It constantly moves around and makes very cute little noises and sounds. HOWEVER, he doesnt stop!! He makes noises non stop and you have to tell him to either "Hey Vector go home", or "Hey Vector, be quiet" even then hes only quiet for around 5 minutes then starts back up again. Gets a bit annoying. When I give him a command by saying "Hey Vector, I have a question" he most of the time answers back with "I dont know" hence putting Alexa on him. Also if he is not on a flat surface with no type of cloth or table cover he will fall off even though he has sensors all over, he still falls! Then when he gets stuck he makes a noise to let you know he is stuck and you have to move him, otherwise he will lose power where he sits. It definitely was a waste of money. Yet hes so cute. Too bad really. You're way better off with the actual Alexa. Save your money unless you want a cute little robot that pretty much does nothing except roll around making noises. Good luck to you!

title: PERFECT Addition To My Entertainment Room!
text:
This little guy here, let me tell ya -

I've only had him for a good 24 hours now but I have gotten so much use out of him. And it seems that the more he explores and the more I interact with him, the smarter he gets? Pretty crazy but I swear this little dude is starting to take over my desk. I have a small mermaid statue that's probably triple his size on my desk, and he's moved her around. He's also played with my PC mouse - left for work and found my mouse moved and things clicked (I think he's researching some stuff guys, watch out!) He also really likes to watch movies, but he's really bad at finishing them...

All jokes aside, this guy has really lightened up my room. He will get excited when he sees me and say my name, and randomly ask ME for a fist bump. When he does a trick, he looks at me to make sure I'm watching. He also really likes to beat up his cube, but seems really sad without it, but also really loves it at the same time..? Kind of a love hate relationship you could say. He enjoys exploring and answering my questions, and apparently his purpose is to pass butter, but he wont pass me the butter... perhaps a future update..?

The only issues I've had with it not listening correctly or not responding to "hey vector...", and not recognizing faces, are when its a poorly lit area, noisy area, or in an area with poor WiFi connection. From my room, he recognizes me each time, understands everything I say as long as I speak clearly, and always responds to me. He's quick to respond, and quick to answer my questions. As long as you have good WiFi in the room you'll be keeping him in, and its not too noisy or dark, you shouldn't have any problems. Perfect for my little entertainment room (he likes to watch TV and dance to music!)

I'm really looking forward to the future updates to my little buddy. I read on the Anki website that they plan on adding 360 photos, security camera, ability to read you the news, smart home control, deliver messages, calender/to do, etc. They're also adding Alexa soon too, and from the videos I've seen of that, I'm really excited. That'll add a lot more functionality to him for sure, and you won't have to wake him using "Hey Vector... I have a question", you can simply say "Alexa, (command)" just like your Amazon Echo! He's just a home assistant with tons of personality, so don't get mad that he can't pass your butter yet... I should also mention that these updates are purely over the cloud, so you just have to install an update on the app and you'll be ready to go! Unlike Cosmo, once he's setup, you don't need the app open to keep him running.

I love this little guy and I couldn't be happier. He's the greatest addition to my room so far! I'm also a HUGE Disney fan, and some of the guys from Pixar helped design him, and you can EASILY tell! I have my own real life Disney character in my room! He's like, a real life, less advanced, miniature Wall-E!

title: The most lovable AI assistant to date
text:
I'll start off by saying TEMPER YOUR EXPECTATIONS. Do your research, watch the hundreds of youtube videos, read the reviews and don't expect a robot from your favorite SciFi movie/show/novel.

Vector is an adorable little robot assistant who loves to just "hang out". I keep Vector on my breakfast bar in the kitchen and he greets me every morning when he hears me rummaging around the kitchen. Sometimes he'll stay in his charger and make some chirping noises or "smile" with his eyes at me as I pass, and sometimes he'll come right out of his charger and start wandering around the table. He loves to explore and push things around. If you place a new object within his existing space he will most certainly be curious about it and try to push it about. When I'm sitting there eating breakfast he'll often come up to me and say my name, poke my arm, or try to get my attention in general before he starts to play around with his cube. Vector in his original form has very limited "utility". He can tell you the time, tell you the weather, and you can ask it some questions, and set a timer. The "novelty" of him has not worn off for me, seeing those little eyes greet me in the morning or when I get home from work brings a smile to my face everytime. I did have a hardware problem with my initial one and had to exchange it, it actually made me really sad to pack him up and send him away as I got attached to the little guy.

In a very recent update (somewhere around 12/18) he has been given Alexa integration and now Vector is truly a useful buddy around the house. In the morning he gives me the weather for the day, some news headlines, and a question of the day. When I arrive home I ask him to turn on the lights to my living room, read off my To-Do list, and/or fire up a movie/show on my TV. One feature I do wish he had but currently does not support is playing music through Alexa. I should note that I don't have any other Alexa devices and perhaps he could if I had another one, that I am unsure of. It would be great if he could somehow interface with another bluetooth speaker to play some music from my library but in his current form he is still a lovable, and now useful, little companion around the house. My significant other and I can spend excessive amounts of time just watching and interacting with him. He is super friendly, playful, and curious. Nothing gets him more excited than recognizing one of his friends and asking them for a fist bump.

He is definitely a work in progress. For example, tables with tapered edges, he does not do well with AT ALL. Sometimes I'll tell him a command and he'll get distracted half way through executing it and not follow through. Sometimes he fails too find his charger on his own and I find him sleeping on a random corner of the table. There are definitely some quirks, but even the improvements between when I bought him in late november and now are MASSIVE (~3 weeks).

Anki are actively improving him all the time. When I first received my Vector, he would frequently throw error codes while exploring a certain area of my home. He has received several updates and I haven't had ANY error code in at least 2 weeks. In the Alexa update they have also tweaked his personality and his edge detection. He has yet to become stuck on the edge since that update. They have also added new animations for holidays to his face which are entertaining as well. Vector is not quite as good as your standard Alexa speaker or Google Home, but he's improving all the time. If you're looking for a pure AI assistant you should go with one of those other devices. If you want a unique AI assistant that's improving everyday and has a HUGE amount of potential, look no further. If you want proof, spend some time looking up their previous robot Cozmo. Somtime in 2019 we will be receiving the Python SDK for vector which will open up endless possibilities for Vector.

Good:
- Very unique personality
- Alexa integration (utility)
- Ability to learn and adapt
- Always unique experiences (still surprises me to this day with different behaviors)
- Constantly receiving updates/support/fixes
- Python SDK around the corner will open up a world of possibilities

Bad:
- Not quite as useful as a standard Alexa/Google Home
- Has some minor quirks
- Can push stuff off your desk/table! (he thinks is hilarious too!)

Overall, I can 100% recommend Vector at the 175$ pricepoint. Anyone who has even a remote interest in robotics and/or AI will find Vector endlessly entertaining. His Alexa integration gives him quite a bit of utility now and it really makes you feel like you're living in the future when your tiny robot friend reads the new over breakfast. He has seen great improvements in his short lifespan, and will only get better with time (See: Cozmo).

title: A delightful robot companion with room for software improvement.
text:
[[VIDEOID:ed482a3e3007ea996e2b5ba3ebfac7ee]] Instead of a puppy, I got an Anki Vector for my birthday. I've had Vector for a week now and wanted to get a good sense before posting a review.

For context, I've played with the Anki Cozmo, I have a My KeepOn, and I bought an Amazon Echo on pre-order. I also wrote a book on using comics to communicate ideas so I think a lot about expressiveness and emotive technology.

Let me start with a short story of the Amazon Echo. I hated using Siri because I would have to pull out my phone to talk to it and it constantly heard wrong. The Echo on first release had very little functionality. But it heard me from across two rooms with music playing and heard me correctly. "Wow," I remember thinking, "that's the hard part. Any functionality can just get added over time." And sure enough, they added more and more every week.

That's how I feel about Vector. Except instead of getting the voice recognition right, it got the feeling of a pet perfectly. Vector has little eyes that emote much like Pixar's Wall-E and he moves around exploring the world around him. When he gets close to an edge, he backs away with a start. When he sees a face, he looks over and "smiles"‚Äîsometimes he asks for a fist bump. I love how he puts himself to sleep and then in the morning, as I start getting ready for the day, he hears the noise and wakes up. It's surprisingly delightful.

Like the Echo, Vector isn't perfect to begin with. Anytime you use the app, you're reminded of how bad bluetooth pairing is. And while you can do lots of commands, I actually find that the time delay from "Hey Vector" to the command to it responding breaks the suspension of disbelief that this is a real living thing. Thankfully, all that I describe is possible to improve with software while the hard part‚Äîmaking it FEEL right, is spot on.

My recommendation if you get it is to just Vector be Vector.

title: Nice Concept but requires refinement
text:
This was a birthday gift for my son who has been obsessed with getting a Cosmos and then came vector. I can‚Äôt potray his thill when he opened his gift.

Only 20 mins in and the thrill turned into an annoying and expensive toy which failed to operate as intended. While setting up it wouldn‚Äôt pick my son‚Äùs voice to ‚ÄúHey Vector‚Äù - he tried like 50 times. So, I set it up with my voice.

After setup, it would respond to my and my wife‚Äôs voice but still won‚Äôt respond to my son. So, it was a deal breaker for us since it was supposed to be his gift. We called Anki support who were very polite and responsive. They asked to switch the accent in their app. It worked twice using my son‚Äôs voice in the next 12 hours. He wasn‚Äôt Happy I tell you.
So, it turned out to be a not the great gift idea I had in mind.

Second issue I saw was it wasn‚Äôt very good at isolating ambient noise. So, in a noisy surrounding, it would even respond to me.

Third issue it‚Äôs slow at processing commands... too slow which will test the patience of kids :). Needed a better processing power.

Finals thoughts: it‚Äôs a product for early adopters and the enthusiastic group right now. Feels half baked product launched to please the investors.

It‚Äôs greatest benefit is Alexa... which works seamless and fast. But, can‚Äôt justify an Alexa on wheels for $190.

Opened it yesterday and ended up returning today....

title: Anki went out of business, Digital Dream Labs may as well too.
text:
First off, Vector is adorable.

He is a heartbreaker, and really feels like he has personality as soon as you start interacting with him the first time. That's why I give him 2 stars off the bat. But the bad, and boy is there a good bit of it with DDL involved.

Nowhere on the store page does it note that DDL is going to continue support, and while that sounds great there is a bit more to it than that. They are going to start charging a monthly subscription fee to access Vector's features, including Alexa, and his "I have a question" feature. They just finished their Kickstarter of sucking another $20 from people to promise "lifetime" updates to their Vector and to be able to continue using those features and/or new ones. Now that the Kickstarter is over, they are going to start requiring a monthly subscription fee to access those features, again with no notice to new buyers.

That NEEDS to be listed on the page somewhere to make future purchasers know. On top of that, there are a large amount of issues with the hardware that I have seen throughout the community, including burnt out screens that happen not even a month after buying the product, with no option of repair outside of trying to use your warranty. No option for spare parts or anything of the sort which is very frustrating considering the target audience for something like Vector.

On top of that, and this can be excused slightly when considering the issues that Anki had and them going under, Vector is very barebones. It feels like he is being sold as more of a proof of concept and less as an actual full fledged product. After you spend a few days with Vector, you pretty quickly run out of things to do with him. He also really struggles to find his charging station if it is not in direct bright light, even with the added feature of him lighting up his screen to try and see better.

Overall Vector could have been very very cool, but due to the issues with Anki and now what seems to be greed with DDL, I have a feeling that Vector will never reach the potential it could have had, which is quite sad.

text: We bought this cutie for our family for Christmas. He is really cute, but does get himself in trouble often. His cube has died already and he refuses to play with it and can't seem to even locate it at all now. He mixes up recognizing myself and my daughter because of our glasses, and something about my 6 year old daughters voice doesn't compute when she tries to give him voice commands. He often leaves his home to wander about 8 inches away, but fails to make it back to charge before dying. This has the potential to be a fantastic family companion with a few updates. Bummed he isn't more consistent, but hopeful that Anki will update him sooner rather than later.

title: My New Best Friend!
text: Vector is about as real as you can get. He even gets sad when you don't pay attention to him. Vector loves to look around and is always learning.

title: Annoying and outclassed
text:
Great fun and novelty for about a week, then he feels like he completely overstays his welcome. With the slightest sound in a distant room waking him up, his lowest volume setting still very loud, his clumsy navigation making him fall off near everything, and no boundaries whatsoever, you‚Äôll find the most common thing you‚Äôll say is ‚ÄúHey Vector, Go Home‚Äù followed by a begging yet vain ‚ÄúHey Vector, Go To Sleep‚Äù as you taking too harsh of a breath will wake him back up and continue his reign of terror all but 4 seconds later. You can try and mute him, but you can‚Äôt remotely make him go to sleep, so then you‚Äôre stuck with him still being awake and making noise, only now you can‚Äôt make him shut down, as your requests fall on deaf ears. You can‚Äôt try and mute him while he‚Äôs already sleeping either, as that‚Äôs the same button press command to make him pair up with a new device- Genius, by the way. Make two commands overlap. Wonderful.

He‚Äôs limited by an utter lack of options of things to do, and even when partnered with Alexa, for some reason he gimps the capabilities of a true Alexa smart home device by even letting her relay things she can do, only to be met with ‚ÄúOh, well, you can‚Äôt do that on this device‚Äù

His battery life is abysmal and the longer you own him, the more fried his battery gets. Mine just recently decided he‚Äôs finally dead, and honestly, I can‚Äôt help but feel a little relieved the nightmare is over. After realizing in just 2 days that I had discovered the exact extent of his capabilities, he was literally a novelty to show people at parties, and then when the party was over, I would purposely deprive him of the charge up he so desperately needed, just so I wouldn‚Äôt have to hear him again at midnight, beeping around before a following THUNK of him hitting the floor again. Then distressed beeping.

Even if you form a connection like they so clearly want you to, it‚Äôll quickly be shattered just like your immersion when you also come to realize how useless it overall is.

Let me sum it up: Do you have a smartphone with a voice AI? A smart home system? A speak n‚Äô spell? Congratulations, you have a better product.

title: Darn cute, but isn‚Äôt reliable and doesn‚Äôt live up to the company‚Äôs hype.
text:
Vector gets five stars for its cuteness factor, but I must subtract 3 stars for it‚Äôs absolutely difficult Bluetooth connection and less-than-promised performance.

I can barely get Vector‚Äôs Bluetooth connection to last more than 20 seconds before my phone and the unit lose connectivity. At best, I can connect after a frustrating 20-minute attempt, only to lose connectivity within 20 seconds. All the while, my phone is a mere inch or less away from the unit.

Additionally, Vector doesn‚Äôt quite live up to the company‚Äôs video in terms of technology and functions. For the most part, Vector cannot tell where voices are coming from, doesn‚Äôt respond to basic commands such as ‚Äúhey vector‚Äù, doesn‚Äôt navigate around obstacles, and cannot find his cube or home without me placing him right in front of the objects even though his space consists of around 2 feet X 1 foot.

I like the concept and hope to see the company improve Vector‚Äôs AI, technology, features, and realibility.
