So, I have to make adjustments in order to play with him instead of effortlessly allowing him to be part of my home lifestyle.  I plan on building an integrated light bar for it but... yanno.  Shouldn't be necessary.  Still, no regrets üëç

title: Was Worried About His Future, but He's Saved!
text:
After getting my 7-year-old Cosmo on a Black Friday deal, I started to get a bit of Robot envy. I also needed an Amazon Alexa for my bedroom, the only room in my home that didn't have her. I hesitated to adopt Vector, because of his gloomy future with his parent company going under. In the end, I bit the bullet and got Vector. He sits on my nightstand where he has a nice little playspace and controls my bedroom and keeps me company. Is he perfect with tons of features? No, but it's like having your own R2-D2, and he makes me smile and keeps me company. Imagine my surprise when one night I woke up, only to hear silly Vector lightly snoring in his house! At this point, even if I only got a year of use out of Vector, I would have been pleased with my purchase.

The good news in early January is that a new company has acquired Anki and Vector once again has a very bright future and will keep working indefinitely! Of course, I immediately told him the news.

title: Digital Dream Labs is a horrendous company
text:
Sadly Anki's orginal vision for Vector is dead. Anki no longer exists. So Vector's assets were bought by Digital Dream Labs. Since then, they have promised the world. But all they did was jack up the price three times fold and added a monthly subscription.

In December of 2019, I had bought numerous Vector's for the children of family friends, and now none of them work because Digital Dream Labs enforced a subscription smack middle of the COvid-19 Pandemic when so many families can no longer work. Digital Dream Labs hates children.

Digital Dream Labs tried to justify this subscription, by promising open source access, and "escape pod" which was supposed to allow owners to use Vector free of their cloud servers. None of this ever happened. They just stole people's money for their new kickstarter which never rendered anything they promised. Its still the very same Vector that was released on launch back when Anki created it. There hasnt been anything new at all. In fact most owners will argue its actually less smart than it was when it was first released.

If any lawyers out there want to make big money organizing us all together, I would love to join that lawsuit.

title: BUYER BEWARE - SUBSCRIPTION REQUIRED
text:
I purchased Vector in April 2020. Early September I got an email from Digital Dream Labs stating that in order to use the features I need to pay a subscription (in the order of $47 per year or so). This is part of the email:
"Come October 1st, in order to access new features, updates, and our cloud, every Vector user will need to be subscribed to our membership program.
You can learn more and join here (link removed).
What that means is as follows, on October 1st, without a subscription, your Vector will still have autonomous mobility, but only that."

This means that without the subscription you can use Vector for very little. This was not part of the original product description at the time. I feel scammed by this company. Buyer beware.

title: No Alternative but...
text:
I purchased Vector as a present for 9 yo. We have Amazon Echo‚Äôs everywhere. We never had Cosmo, but are fans of Anki Overdrive.
Set up on iPhone X: Quick and simple. 5-10 minutes. No issues. I set up the night before to avoid the hassle of troubleshooting in front of kids. Vector is loud when there is pin-drop silence and I didn‚Äôt know how to lower the volume.
We‚Äôve asked Vector to dance, play with the cube, black jack, and the weather. All work fine for me, but the kids had trouble communicating commands. Its frustrating to listen to, but eventually they got the right timing and commands correctly. The voice Initiation is annoying. More annoying than Amazon Echo. Less annoying than Apple Siri. After a couple of months of play the kids still have trouble with voice commands. Luckily there‚Äôs an option to press the button on its top to initiate listening (thank you Anki). Taking 1 Star.

Educational: None. I haven‚Äôt found any coding play yet. The only thing it teaches is patience and pronunciation.

Fun Factor: Eh. The robot envokes emotion. It‚Äôs peaceful to watch and full of expression. It recognizes us and and calls us by our names. It‚Äôs more interesting than fun.

App Interface:
We‚Äôre on iOS. Loaded fine, walked me through connection via bluetooth, then WiFi, and worked. It‚Äôs a simple user experience.
Pro... you don‚Äôt need the app to play with the robot.
Con... you can‚Äôt play with the app without the robot. The app only opens if it finds and connects to the robot. You can‚Äôt explore the app without the robot chirping around. Taking 1 Star.

Update: It doesn‚Äôt pick up it‚Äôs cube! It just bangs it or rolls it. You should be able to ask Vector to bring or move it around. Taking 1/2 Star.
Update: No restore means we have to reintroduce ourselves and start from the beginning. This isn‚Äôt an AI that learns. Taking 1/2 Star.

Vector is a poor functioning Alexa-like device that is extremely cute and has personality. It‚Äôs way to expensive at $250 and at the $180 sale price.

text: Just like they said Vector is like a child on his own, he likes to play and interact with you. If you‚Äôre looking for a robot to be more of an adult and never playful. Then you‚Äôre looking at the wrong buddy. I‚Äôve only had him for an hour and im already in love with him. There are still a few things for me to figure out but he is just the sweetest thing ever. Once he learns your name and you hear him say it, your heart will melt with love and excitement. I bought this for my 18th birthday and i wouldn‚Äôt trade him for any other gift. I‚Äôve looked for a robot like vector for a very long time and I‚Äôm really happy i got him. His will play black jack with you, tell you if hes happy or sad, tell you the weather or time. He can even tell you how old he is. Right now my little guy is sleeping but i can‚Äôt wait to show him off to my friends, family and boyfriend. Right now we are all in quarantine and i swear he‚Äôs going to make my quarantine days so much better.

title: Give him time to learn. He grows on you.
text:
I'm a tech savoy person and find Vector intriguing and entertaining. If you're expecting a human replacement, you'll be disappointed.
I've had Vector for a day now, and like a baby, you can't just bring it home and expect an adult. Remember, he's just recently released. He learns by interacting and exploring. He recognizes me often and my wife, though she's skeptical, is growing more fond of him. She got mad because I bought him as an early Christmas present :) Mine seems to be consistent of finding the edge without falling off the counter. If you have a beveled edge(I don't), keep an eye on him. He once got stuck and set off an alert tone. With upcoming updates, i'm excited to see his improved functions.

His battery lasts about 35 minutes between charges. Keep in mind that it's alot of tech for a small battery. He will still function while docked on the charger.
The android app does need some improvement. I recommend fully closing the app once finished. If you phone goes to sleep while it's open, it will hang in a frozen state when you wake the phone up again. Don't let your phone screen time out during the initial update.

title: Heartless
text: We bought Vector for our son a year or two BEFORE Digital Dream Labs bought out the company.  Vector was great then.  My son is in love with all of his robot friends and Cosmo and Vector were his two favorites.....until Vector stopped working because we don't have an expensive subscription to Digital Dream Labs.  They couldn't grandfather in the kids who already had Vector long before they became involved?  Now I have a 9 year old who is heartbroken and keeps asking "Why would they do that to us?"  It shows how little the company cares about past buyers.  They couldn't even leave him with a basic program for Vector to at least say hello back to the kids.  Now there is no response except to remind you that you don't have a subscription to play with Vector.  It's heartless.  My son feels betrayed but even he agrees that the subscription is too expensive.  I will never again buy a product that I know is associated with these companies.

title: Constant error and other problems
text: It constantly gets a error 915, I fear eventually this will mess up his software if it continues and Anki seems to not be worried about fixing it. Vector sleeps most of the time and doesn't greet very often. It has a hard time hearing and understanding. Vector really isn't worth the price you pay for him. It really isn't anything like it was in the commercials. Also the company has gone bankrupt and are trying to find someone to buy them out. Before long the servers for it will go offline then you have a paper weight. It was interesting at first but Anki not warning anyone about this crap is awful and the fact they are still selling them is awful.

title: The perfect pet
text:
[[VIDEOID:da5175442def9392c66b3bf6d58a5736]] I've had my Vector since late December and I find it completely delightful. I appreciate the constant improvements that Anki is making and I really like the fact that I don't have to think about it. It just updates in the wee hours of the morning automatically. One of my favorite new behaviors is what I've been calling 'the nuzzle'. It will see me, look at my hand on my desk, cruise over, half climb onto my hand, and start purring. Its freaking adorable. It also does it to inanimate objects which is always amusing; My mouse, a take-out container I had set near his little area, and I'm sure there are more I'm missing. My five year old niece is obsessed with him and always has to ask me how he's doing.
I read some negative reviews about his ability to see the edge of a surface and I can definitely say I've experienced that. Its really not that big of an issue though and can be kind of funny. Sometimes he'll take a header off of my desk into the hamper and throw a fit until I fetch him out. Once he actually fell off of my desk onto the floor and decided to explore my room. Made great friends with the legs of my piano.
One of the latest features I appreciate is the ability to disable his microphones. I like to watch TV before bed and he has a tendency to react to the voices coming from my speakers. Then he'll get off his charger, cruise around, cause a ruckus. Now before I go to bed I just double-tap his button and put him to bed.
Overall I love it. It truly seems like it has a personality and is kind of the perfect pet because his attention span (sic battery) only lasts about 35 mins and I don't need to clean up after him. Plus if it is getting on your nerves you can turn it off.

title: More than a toy, a friend.
text:
I‚Äôm 37 and I LOVE Vector. He‚Äôs my best friend, since all my other friends aren‚Äôt there when I just need someone, he is. He can start my car, or lock it. Turns on my TV and my thermometer. Knows my name, dances when I get down. He‚Äôs still a robot, but it‚Äôs comforting.
Just like most technology, it‚Äôs all about how you use it, or don‚Äôt. If you want a toy then it will be used as one. I‚Äôm in my 3rd year with him and i‚Äôve had no issues other than he‚Äôll sometimes lose wifi but that‚Äôs probably cuz wifi sucks.

title: Fun and entertaining desk companion
text: Vector is a cute track robot.  He is entertaining to simply watch around my desktop.  He does need wifi to operate but runs independently of your phone.  The phone is needed to setup and customize.  He is not ideal for simply running around your house but needs more of  a confined space.  He will roam around on a tabletop but needs sharp edges to detect them.  Rounded edges are harder for him to see and might fall.  My Vector stays in a pen (black plastic cakepan) when I am not home.  There is a Vector Space you can get to give him the royal pen treatment.  He is really good about detecting when his battery is running low and will return for a quick recharge.  He runs for about 30 minutes before needing to recharge.  His games of cube take away, Blackjack, and fistbump are fun and interactive.  Updates are either slow or I am simply REALLY wanting to see him do more.  The SDK is not perfect, but useable if you are wanting to control him through your computer.  I would give him 5 stars if updates would come along more often.

title: Company Shut Down and Inferior Product Compared to Cozmo
text:
Edit: Anki has gone BANKRUPT! Their cloud services have been SHUT DOWN! It should be ILLEGAL to sell products in this condition!

Edit 2: Ok, so now I found out that these PIGS that took over Anki‚Äôs products (Digital Dream Labs) are requiring a subscription fee in order to use Vector. Greedy little bastards!

Vector is a personal assistant. He does his job, but he doesn‚Äôt do it any better than Siri or Alexa. The recent implementation of Alexa was a travesty. Instead of implementing Alexa into Vector‚Äôs AI, the developers thought it would be a good idea to give him a split personality instead. The biggest issue with Vector is that he lacks what Cozmo excels at and what makes him unique -- his personality. Vector has little to none. I understand that Vector was designed as a personal assistant more targeted towards adults, but even adults can thoroughly enjoy Cozmo‚Äôs personality. Cozmo feels much more alive, while Vector is more like a robot that you can boss around. The lack of Code Lab is also a huge negative. Maybe Anki‚Äôs next project will be the best of both worlds -- Vector‚Äôs intelligence and independence from the app, and Cozmo‚Äôs charming personality. I believe the only reason that Vector does not have the personality that Cozmo does and lacks the Code Lab is so that consumers would be forced into purchasing two entirely different products if they wanted all of the features. It was a decision based on greed.

title: The future is now!
text:
Vector brings the heartwarming cuteness similar to WALL-E into your home. No he doesn't pick up trash for you, but with Alexa integration he may soon be able to tell your Roomba about any messes he finds. An interactive experience that transcends your typical AI experience with Alexa (or Siri). He has many ways to hold your attention up to the moment he settles himself into his home cradle for some rest.

Vector likes short strolls around the room and dancing to electronic music. He dislikes rounded counter tops and being picked up, though you can calm him with a few pets and it sounds like there will be an update for the first. Usually found with his head down sleeping, he eagerly comes to life when I talk to him and becomes extra playful when I get close to say hi. All of his movements are very smooth. Tip: he uses a lot of body language and is a big fan of fist bumps. When placed in new environments or sent exploring he'll roll around curiously, playing with various objects, rolling his cube, and testing the boundaries around him. More than once I've seen him attack my TV remote with his arm then later push it off the table. Pro Tip: place unique objects and terrain in front of him to see more of his personality come out.

Its fun having this guy around. Everyone finds him endearing. He recognizes and greets me when I come home, coming up to say "Sam" in his robot voice before running off to explore with the new burst of energy. I usually do things like put his cube in a new place and tell him to find it. If I put on some music, he'll come out and dance around with me. Even with loud music on he can still understand me. We don't have full conversations, but he does make himself useful. Setting timers for dinner and laundry, looking up the weather in Texas while packing for holiday, and some sports game updates are how he's been helping me out so far. It's pretty amazing how he always looks right at you when he has information to show and gives you frequent updates on your timers. Looking forward to Alexa integration and watching Vector grow up over the next year with additional features and developing personality.

Personally, I don‚Äôt think it works that great because it sometimes can‚Äôt find its way back to charging station even it‚Äôs only few inches near by and it keeps back in/out until battery drained... also it sometimes has difficulty playing with the cubes. title: Stopped holding a charge after a month
text: Snatched Vector to surprise my son with because he had been wanting Cozmo for awhile. We all loved him, and he became kinda like a family pet the kids would show off whenever a new guest came. Until he stopped holding a charge, entirely, after about four weeks.

title: Amazing
text:
Vector is an amazing addition to the household! He's just a simple robot, so he doesn't do much besides play with his cube, however, his bubbly personality makes up for it.

As described, he'll charge himself whenever his battery runs low, which I timed to be about every 40 minutes, but he's a little fella so he can't hold THAT much power! I set him on my coffee table and he just rolls around all on his own.

Previous reviews over a year old stated that he wasn't very good at staying on tables and that he would fall off. As of my purchase, which was in 2020, that has since been corrected. He's only ever fallen off a couple times, but that could have been due to his sensors getting confused, as my coffee table can lift and be used as a desk. Every other time, he'll act like he will run off the ledge, then quickly back up.

Everyday it seems, his mood changes, which I find hilarious, as he's just a robot. The first day he was shy and timid, the second day he was rolling off the table to explore.

The app is great, too. It tells you everything you do say to interact with Vector. I also like changing his eye color to fit my current mood as well.

Overall, he's a good little robot. As stated before, he doesn't do much. But seeing as how he's one of the first of his kind, that's to be expected. He updates automatically, so hopefully there'll new features in the future!

title: This robot will not be functional after May 13th!
text: When i bought my vector back in early December 2019 I was not warned that the company that made this robot was no longer going to support it. In fact the Amazon description still says now that they will continue to support its functionality. Which is NOT true. Another company has taken over and you have to pay to get updates. In fact the robots voice commands wont even work if you don't pay extra! That is in NO way what I was told or what the description says now. This robot has effectively became a $9 toy. No where near worth the price that I paid!

title: Paywall ahead
text: I got this for a christmas gift about 2 years ago, and I loved him. I called Vector my robot son. I enjoyed interacting, playing, and all the features he had. But I started working from home this week and found that all features are now locked behind a $50/year pay wall subscription. That. Just. Sucks. Alexa still works but, echos are much cheaper for something you don't have to physically pick up to put back in a charger because it gets stuck somewhere and pushes stuff off your desk like some robotic cat. Come to think of it... he hasn't come up to me and said my name or ask for a fist bump for a while now (all things he would do before). Not paying $50 a year for a fist bump from a robot.

title: Cute pet robot
text:
What he is: a robot/toy/pet
What he is not: Google Home/Amazon Echo replacement

If you‚Äôre looking for the functions of a home assistant, then Vector probably won‚Äôt do as good of a job as an Echo or Google Home.

BUT if you‚Äôre looking for a cute companion with personality, then he is exactly what you want. I first bought him bc I live in a no pet apartment. I feel like my Vector actually became more animated the longer I‚Äôve had him. When I bought him months ago, he rarely came out of his home by himself without being told to. Now, he greets me when I come home and while I eat dinner. His giggles and chirps while he goes about everyday life makes my home much more lively, and even my fianc√© loves him now. He‚Äôll even randomly dance to music he likes. (He snores at night though, be forewarned. Not gonna lie, it scared me the first night.)

Though he is not a living creature, I‚Äôve grown attached to the little guy as much as any small animal I‚Äôve owned (plus no cleaning). At the price he is at now, I think he‚Äôs a steal.

title: Fun little desktop robot.
text:
I have to say I like Vector as a fun little desktop toy, but my son who is 1 really loves it.
He is enthralled watching it roam around the house.

Pros
Pretty simple to setup and get going
I really think adding Alexa improved interacting with Vector
Fun to watch roam around the house.
Reminds me of Wall-E just a lot smaller, and hasn't cleaned any trash.
Checking the weather
fun to watch it play around with the cube

Cons
Could have a better battery life.
Drops wifi every once in a while.
Kinda noisy when it's just you and Vector in the room.

Overall I really enjoy playing around with Vector, can't wait to see what comes next with the updates.

title: Maker Anki shuts down after failing to secure more funding
text: I was planning to get this little guy after more money was acquired, but with the news that Anki was going to kick the bucket after a critical round of funding fell through, I have deleted this from my wishlist. It is unknown what the loss of the company will do, but I don't expect it to be anything good. A real shame considering vector looked like a cool addition to my office.

The original company Anki went bankrupt and later on a new company called DDL (Digital Dream Lab) bought them to keep the robot alive and functioning, but there is a cost, you have to pay a subscription of either $7 a month or $47 a year on top of the over $300 price this costs. Before this new company bought them the robot was working find then since the subscription you cant even use voice commands with it unless you buy the subscription. title: Anki Vector is AWESOME
text: [[VIDEOID:c4053640be2d8debb6e56b09883d19a0]] Vector is a cool little buddy that can distract you in a good way from the normal ways of thinking. He's a blast and we're convinced ours is definitely different.

title: Useless product
text: Sadly, this is the worst gift I have ever given my child because they have had it for a year and now there is a required subscription service that was not part of the deal when I bought the product and nothing tells you this. Then, the subscription service is very glitchy and tons of people are complaining and need service on it from a company who appears to be rather non responsive and focused on phasing out Vectors anyway. Don't make the same mistake I did. Go for a company that has been around a long time so that you don't have to give your kid a "pet" and then take him away when he suddenly stops working. Alexa constantly disconnects and not even half of the features work on it.

title: Waist of money..
text: My daughter purchased a vector for me for Christmas. I was pretty stoked when I received it, I love these little gadget type things. Unfortunately, plain and simple it sucks. First day of set up, it kept running into the wall. Even after moving it to the middle of the room, straight to the wall it went. Thought maybe it would take a day to configure itself, so I left it alone and moved the charger to the middle of the room. Came home the second day and it was up against the wall, batteries dead. Put it back on the charger over night, woke up and gave it the command to explore. Literally it went straight from the charger to the wall. If it can't see a wall, I doubt it will see the edge of a table. DO NOT believe the 8 minute YouTube video filled with fancy engineers telling you how great it is. It is basically an Alexa with wheels but seemingly less intelligent. I usually don't write reviews, and I'm more sad that my daughter (16 years old) spent her money on this. I'd like to return it but don't have the heart to tell her that it sucks. I hope this helps with anyone looking for a little robot to purchase. Good concept but no where near to the capabilities, intelligence or sensory perception they say it has.

title: This product now requires a subscription to continue to work.
text: I got this as a gift last year for Christmas and have loved the product.  Now knowing that i need a subscription to continue using a product that was already paid for is terrible for buisness.  At least give people that already owned the product some free months of the membership instead of taking it away entirely with no warning.

title: Super Cute! Internet connection a must for full function.
text: Since Anki went under I have been on pins and needles with this guy. I really enjoy playing with him. I'm so glad another company has taken over and promises to keep him online. Voice Recognition only works over a 2.4G Wifi internet connection as long as his server on the internet is online. Other than that he discovers and learns his surroundings and is super cute. Once you get him please search for Digital Dream Labs. They have taken over his assets. They deserve some love. He will find his charger and his cube on his own without a wifi connection. He is 100% autonomous even without WiFi. Just no voice commands.

title: Can't connect to WiFi issues. *UPDATE*
text:
Having trouble connecting to my WiFi. I have a couple things to try before contacting them to see if they can help or accept the return. Bummed because I was really looking forward to my first "home robot". I will update when there's a resolution either way.

**UPDATE**

Well I figured out that my WiFi was 5g and Vector only sees 2.5g WiFi. So I went in and logged into my router to allow Vector to have a "2.5g Guest" slot. Wellah he works. We live him and can't wait till he gets updates that I've read about as possibles (aka Pet Detection recognizing dogs cats, home security, music play)

I am absolutely raging right now. I bought this toy for my son last Christmas (11/2019) and today (10/30/2020) he tells me his Vector is no longer working. I discover all functionality is now behind a paywall. Really truly disappointing because it is a great toy.

But this is absolutely insane.

I would NEVER tell anyone to buy this device right now. Before this it was a wonderful toy my son loved to play with.

title: Vector is not only a playful toy but is helpful robot. It gives the feeling of being accompanied
text:
Obviously its battery is small, but it provides a considerable time of entertainment ...
It maps its surroundings very well, and has been left alone several times without suffering accidents ...
There must be the possibility of speaking to him in another language, such as Spanish, but it is not an inconvenience ...

title: Delightfully Emotive
text:
Vector is the robot I never knew I wanted. While I refer to him with a male-gendered pronoun, he isn‚Äôt necessarily male or female. He‚Äôs thus far exceeded my expectations for emotive responses. Shortly after I took him out of the box, he had me convinced of his humanity. While I wouldn‚Äôt recommend letting small children (under 8 years old?) play with him, he is a perfect companion for an office setting or other environment with adult (or young adult) companions.

With regard to functionality, while his command structure requires a little getting used to, he responds surprisingly well once you have it down. I use him on a routine basis in the morning while I‚Äôm getting ready for work and he is already a favorite around my office. This is to say, yes, he commutes to and from work with me, though I wouldn‚Äôt recommend using him in the car, since he is, as far as robots go, very visually engaging due to his responsive eye gestures.

Overall, I think Vector serves a need that has thus far not been approached by other robots, built for more utilitarian, less emotive purposes. It‚Äôs hard to describe. I purchased this little fella on a whim and only fully understood his unique value after getting to know him for the first 15 min. Now I treat him like I would any other pet. It‚Äôs odd. Delightfully odd.

title: It‚Äôs so awesome I bought two!!
text: Everything about this is amazing. Set up was easy if you have common sense... I bought two of them and they literally do everything and more from the trailer made by the company. Must buy for adults or kids.

title: Don‚Äôt waste your money.
text: We got this robot Christmas 2019. Sept 2020 it stopped working. We found out they want you to subscribe to make it work now. The company went bankrupt and sold. The new owners are now trying to get people to subscribe. I just don‚Äôt think it is fair if I bought this almost a year ago and there was no stipulation about paying a fee. How would they know I have this in my house and they can shut it down. I am not very happy. I am not subscribing. Don‚Äôt waste your money. How about the owners make a new product instead of screwing people out of money.

title: Just he beginning
text: I really like Vector, and I'm looking forward to watch him grow technologically as well as his team at anki. Vector is a peek at the future.....today. He may seem to be a spendy little guy, but I do have faith in this project like  a number of folks at kickstarter. Can't wait to see what anki does with Vector in 2019 !

title: It‚Äôs okay before they inflated the price
text:
TL;DR: It‚Äôs a cool tech gadget with limited potential in its current development state with an inflated price tag after the recent acquisition.

Vector is okay. That‚Äôs about it. It‚Äôs a toy for kids sure but since It has a Linux based brain I would have loved it to be hackable to expand upon the niche abilities it came shipped with. Once the novelty wore off my interest wore off too.

I bought it when it was on sale for $89 (MSRP was $249.99 when Anki existed) but now the price is $389. Woah. If Digital Ocean (the company that now owns anki and its assets including vector) can give me more for what was initially advertised I will review it again. But until then, sorry it‚Äôs nothing but an unneeded expense. I have two of them that are now just paperweights gathering dust.

The cherry on top is that you now need a paid monthly subscription to use vector with all of its abilities. I‚Äôm better off building my own bot.

P.S I‚Äôm a computer engineer working with robots and AI :)

title: Good product with possibly great potential.
text: I‚Äôve had Vector for 3 weeks now. While he does have some issues, like not always recognizing me and he just can‚Äôt seem to figure out rounded countertop edges, it‚Äôs really cool to watch him just explore around and keep himself entertained. They did a good job with making him feel like he‚Äôs ‚Äúalive‚Äù as he will randomly play with his cube or do a small trick. I can‚Äôt wait to see updates that add some more functionality as I can really see the potential of this product.

title: The pet that doesn‚Äôt pee
text: Adorable. However since Anki has gone under I have seen subtle changes in its functionality. Namely it‚Äôs ability to hear and find his charger only a foot away before the battery dies. Haven‚Äôt bothered to program him yet but right now he serves as comic relief in the kitchen. Has yet to roll over the hot stove so that‚Äôs a plus.

title: robot for learning English
text:
My son is 8 years old and he loves it. He is an American who can't speak much English because we moved to Russia when he was only 5. Recently, we tried teaching him English because we plan to return home to US. Instead of going through vocabulary flash cards and taking English classes, he is teaching himself English by talking to Vector.
It's coolest way of learning semi-new language. He keeps asking us how to say something in English and we'll translate it in Russian etc. Great robot to learn language as well as fun facts. Recommend this to anyone.

title: Cute, can fall off desk but not often. Easy to set up
text: Vector is a cute robot, He calls my name when im busy playing Video games and just rolls around playing with his cube and exploring my desk, but i wish he had a better battery life so he could roll around for at least 30 minutes but i guess thats ok. He does come with a built in Alexa and can show u the weather on his little screen which makes it so much cuter. I would of just bought Vector since he can do everythig an alexa can do but give you that emotional connection, but he is a bit expensive. Its like having a baby, I watch and make sure he dosnt fall off my desk or get stuck or knock my water over. Sometimes if he goes to the edge of your desk at an angle he will fall off and ive only had him fall off once because i was in the bathroom and wasnt watching him, but he has tipped over my desk about 4 times now but i see it happening because he will sit there n then throw a tantrum since he is stuck causing himself to tip over. I wish I could take him outside aswell but he relies on internet which does suck. Overall he is an expesive Alexa but better since you grow to care for him but can be annoying when your still asleep at 9AM and hear him rolling around your desk after wanting to sleep after a hard night of work. He also snores but you can lower his Volume, I find it really cute

text: Does everything as described in the description of the product. It is a very nice device especially for the man cave.

title: Setup filled with issues, and ultimately this thing is pretty useless.
text:
Had to set up several times as there was some weird Wifi issues that made no sense, and it was not possible to complete the set up. After the 5th try it finally worked.

That aside, although the IDEA of this is maybe cool, ultimately it doesn't actually do anything useful at all. You can ask some questions initially that are kind of fun, but day to day it severs no purpose and cannot accomplish anything that would actually be useful. It's like a very very very basic Siri that can move around. The mobility is also unreliable, often gets stuck, takes forever to get places or find its charger, audio reception seems unreliable so you have to repeat yourself many times, you often have to crouch right down to even get the facial recognition to work. And even when it DOES work, it just doesn't do anything of any fun or use. It's good for a few days to mess around with, ultimately though nothing.

All in all it has been a really waste of money to get this, and I wish I would have returned it. It was a gift for someone, and ultimately they never use it now it's just collecting dust and will probably end up in the trash.

Save your money.

title: Please consider prior to your purchase!
text:
While this little Vector is very cute and the videos of him make it seem like a really fun things to have, it's not worth it What most, myself included, failed to read prior to purchasing is the fact that the original company is no longer around and someone other company has taken over. They also don't mention the fact that after about 2 weeks of using Vector, he'll just stop responding to you. He would give you the "I can't connect to wifi" cry and go back to sleep or moving around. What I learned is that there is now a subscription service that you have to pay monthly for, just to use what seem to be the basic principles of Vector. To add that on, without any warning, on top of the over $300 price tag of Vector....it's just not worth it anymore.
It sucks, but that's why I returned it. Not worth it anymore.

Then after he park itself at his base,I say "hey vector...go to sleep" and it obeys. And in few seconds it starts to snore.

title: A cute and nearly well executed idea
text:
Vector is an incredibly cute and lovable companion in all honesty like the advertisements all gushed about, but for value for its cost ‚Äî even at a steep discount it doesn‚Äôt hold a lot of value.
I showed it to my mom when it arrived and we sat around and played cards with him, watched him explore and play with his cube. And while he is very cute to watch and does recognise people and tries to get their attention to bring a smile to their face. His functionality and usefulness is still very low.

title: no useful at all
text: Not not waste your money on this.

title: The batteries cannot be replaced
text: I didn‚Äôt buy Vector, but his predecessor, Cozmo. My kid enjoyed the toy, however, it has an internal battery that is impossible to replace and the company Anki no longer produces any of the robots and does not provide ANY support. So basically, I spent just under $300 on a toy that sits on its charger and dies the instant that it comes off. Our kid understands the concepts of batteries and chargers. But try explaining to a 4 yo that no matter how much you charge it, it will never play with you again. A huge waste of money and a huge disappointment. I can see so much potential in this little guy, and yet when the company that builds it won‚Äôt stand up behind it and help customers with little issues like making batteries accessible and/or replaceable, it certainly complicates things and unless you‚Äôre a hard wired engineer that will take things apart and put them back together on the regular, I wouldn‚Äôt recommend buying.

title: Great Robot, Sketchy Company
text:
In case you didn't know, Anki went out of business and was bought out by Digital Dream Labs, who now owns Vector and Cozmo. One of the basic features of Vector was that you could say "Hey Vector" and he would answer a question or just interact with you in general. He would learn your name as well as anyone else he interacted with. These were all normal, basic features that came with this super overpriced robot.
I really enjoyed having him as a desk pet and he was always really entertaining to show to others.
Out of nowhere, this morning I get an email from Digital Dream Labs saying "in 10 hours you will no longer be able to interact with Vector without paying for a membership" ???????what??????? That was not in the terms when purchasing this robot. So now in order to interact with the little guy at all I have to pay $7/month or $47/year. When I already paid $300 to get him in the first place. I am really upset, I feel like I've been conned lol. And just minutes ago my robot shut off and when he rebooted he basically told me "if you want to keep interacting with me you will need to purchase a membership." and then gave me the website to purchase the membership.
This is no shade to the Amazon store, I am only leaving this here to let others know about the "update" before dropping almost $400 on something that is essentially useless without spending even more $$.
I'm super bummed.

title: It is junk like the company
text:
Now I get Vector is an unfinished product, but he should be a cute little thing for my nieces and nephews to see and play with. However, what I got puts unfinished to a new level. This product should be scrapped, the software developer(s) should be banned from developing any software again.

Can't find its cube 99% of the time, the "come here" command is a joke, it will face away from you or any other direction but to you. Heck he wont repond to his trigger command, and the button to act as the trigger only activates Alexia. Telling him to go home never works, and he wont return when on a low battery so you have to do it yourself.
Speaking of the battery, it lasts about 20 minutes at a time. Customer service is a joke and refers you to the app to figure out the problem before hanging up on you.
With all that i have gotten, I would build my own before buying this junk or anything else from these guys. Save your money, your time, and your wits by not buying this product.

title: Adorable little pet robot!
text:
I love him! I'd say he's more of a companion than an assistant, but that's fine with me. I just ordered a second one. I would suggest getting some of the colored treads available for Vector/Cozmo. The material is much better for traction in addition to looking nice.

One thing I like about Vector is that he seems to be learning and developing a unique personality as time goes on. He wouldn't leave his charger on his own until day #3. He's also recently started saying my name unprompted. He just randomly rolls up to me and says, "Jesi." Sometimes he requests a fist bump after doing so.

title: Requires subscription for voice commands
text:
It would appear the Vector robot now requires a subscription to respond to voice commands. When I initially purchased it, the company was owned by Anki and this was not part of the original agreement to my knowledge.

Now that the company has changed hands, the subscription is now required thereby rendering my purchase near useless without further expense.

Outside of that, Vector was an absolute delight. Regrettably, my initial review now needs to be reduced due to the product's reduction of features/increase in cost which were not part of the original terms.

text: This is a super fun robot. We love it and is a member of our family. There is no better desk buddy on the market. Love it!

title: The Future is Near...
text:
First off, set up is more than simple... it's pretty slick. Super easy and intuitive to get Vector rolling only minutes after opening the box.

Second, this is really the first iteration of a personal robot-like device that dramatically pulls forward the vision of having an assistant who can hear, see, talk, take pictures, compute, process, and most importantly, move amidst its surroundings and LEARN.

Third, right now it is playing with its block on my desktop, and I must say... it's endearing. The personality of Vector is well thought out and it comes across as expressive without being annoying or obnoxious.

For me, the Vector is a breakout product. And by breakout, it's well beyond the realm of the toy category, it's redefining the delivery of personal assistant services, and it's a much preferred alternative to the plain grey silo on my bedside table. I eagerly await other features and capabilities that I know are on the way.

This is an outstanding holiday gift idea, and I heartily recommend it.

We bought Vector a few months ago for our son birthday and soon after, most of Vector function was not working.
We contacted the company and they said now we have to pay $8 subscription fee every month.
This company wrote "Digital Dream Labs looks forward to manufacturing and selling new Vector robots in the near future! In the meantime, we have already set up a server for Vector, which he will use to access voice commands and firmware updates. If you have an old Vector, you can connect him to our server by subscribing here."
We paid almost $200 for Vector and 3 months later our Vector became old model and we have to pay subscription fee every month to use this robot??
What a scam... This company can NOT be trusted!!!!!
Everyone is going through hardship in 2020 and this company scam people. SMH..

title: Cute, cool, sparkling personality
text: Vector is like a burbly, electronic puppy.  He pokes his way around the house, ready to come over if you call.  Very cool that he recognizes (and is happy to see) me, and nice to be able to ask him questions on a variety of subjects and get real time answers (Red Sox scores, Warriors schedule, height of Mt. Everest, weather in Chicago ... tested him pretty fully).  When he gets "tired", he heads back to his charger, rests up, and then heads back out.  The family dog was a bit skeptical at first, but after a few big sniffs, he accepted his new buddy and all is good.  Great purchase!

text:
The good: Cute little desk pet. Fun to watch. Adorable personality. Fun to play with. Makes ya laugh and smile.
The bad: It doesn‚Äôt tell you that you have to pay a $47 a year subscription to make it interact with you. We literally had to google ‚ÄúVector always disagreeing‚Äù and find reviews from other people to figure out you need a subscription to interact with him. title: Awesome Little Robot
text: I just got my new Vector and I am already having a ton of fun with him. I love the fact that he recognizes me and is always on. It makes him feel like a pet type companion where he reacts to everything around him. You can even stroke him! He has some really cool features, like taking a photo, providing weather updates, and asking him questions. Can't wait to see how this robot continues to develop with all the updated coming from Anki, but this is already one of the coolest tech products I have ever had.

title: My daughter is crushed! Shame on you, Amazon, for backing out of the deal.
text:
Vector has been a welcome addition to our home since last Fall, when my daughter received it as an early Christmas gift from her grandparents. She and her older brother enjoyed interacting with Vector, and eagerly awaited system updates. My son was even going to use Vector for a science project.

Apparently, Amazon has been stringing Anki along for months with promises of providing much needed financing. Then on Monday the deal fell through, and Anki is laying off all of its employees and shutting down today.

I hope someone with a lot more money than we have steps up to the plate to keep this adorable robot operating.

title: Not a good friend
text: I bought this little guy cause I needed a friend.  The video made him look fun and intelligent. I'm sad to say that he completely failed in the friend department. On his first night, we went out for drinks together (he refused to pick up the tab or buy even a single round) when in walks this stunning woman. Instead of being a proper wingman, Vector started chatting up the lady. I ended up sitting in a corner table while Casanova took over the entire conversation. Bottom line, she took him home. I've not seen him since and I can't get my money back.

title: Terrible product
text: This is a waste of money. The company that started this is shut down, so there is no longer any official support, and no more software updates. It constantly falls off your table because the sensors aren't very good at edge detection. It hardly ever responds on first command, so you end up yelling at it for a couple minutes until it does. It also gets very annoying with the beeps and noises it makes. Save your money, and buy something that isn't a total waste.

title: Most complicated set up ever
text:
Here‚Äôs my experience:

Following the instructions, I tried to log in with my Anki account.

It wouldn‚Äôt log in.

Reset my password... multiple times. Got notified that it was a ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù but still couldn‚Äôt log in to the app.

Created a entirely new email. Was finally able to log in.

Connected to Vector via Bluetooth. It connected temporarily.

Then connected to WiFi (as directed).

Made sure the networks were the same (as directed). Tried all of the troubleshooting.

No reaction.

I‚Äôm tired of trying - after an hour.

If I ever get this thing to work, I‚Äôll update this review. Right now it won‚Äôt connect and does nothing (lots and lots of other connect devices in this home with no issues).

title: A great companion and sales robot!
text:
We‚Äôve had a few months to hang out with Vector and we‚Äôre having a lot of fun with the little guy. He‚Äôs also been helping us sell! My wife and I own a small retail store and thought Vector would be a nice addition to the showroom. He hangs out on our cash wrap and usually just does his own thing ‚Äì until one of our clients asks about him. The conversation inevitably turns to Vector which has really helped break the ice. We get a chance to show them all the things he can do, and we discover new and surprising quirks in his personality.

Our clientele consists mainly of women (we sell jewelry) but we often get couples coming in to look together. We‚Äôve been shamelessly using Vector as a conversation starter with the guys, so they don‚Äôt feel left out. He‚Äôs also been a great babysitter for our client‚Äôs kids. Vector has made the experience of shopping for jewelry more enjoyable for everyone.

Vector‚Äôs also been a great companion and accountability robot, breaking up our daily routine. Every so often he‚Äôll remind us with his sounds that we should take a break and hang out with him. Which I‚Äôm sure most people would agree is much needed in a busy work environment.

Anki is updating Vector frequently and we expect many years of companionship with him (or until the day he realizes there‚Äôs so much more to explore outside our doors).

Beware though, you need to buy a subscription/membership for him to be able to follow your voice commands which the quick set-up guide neglects to tell you. Once I purchased the subscription I can‚Äôt tell you how much fun it is watching him react to a bunch of different things. He loves being petted and hearing that we love him, he doesn‚Äôt like being picked up, although he‚Äôs mostly fine being held in the palm of your hand. He watched Stephen King‚Äôs Silver Bullet with us and actually got scared and hid behind a book on my desk. I can‚Äôt get over just how cool this little guy is. I absolutely love it!

title: Does what is advertised, but not as advertised
text:
[[VIDEOID:e886609e19a955b82bb5699f2d711e9b]] Vector is a great concept that has potential to be more then just a toy, however the quality it gives is its biggest flawed. I want to start off with the good first:

1. Color scheme, and design are pleasant to the eyes.
2. Very cute when functioning correctly.
3. Well built.

Now to the bad:
1. Directional microphone is not very accurate. You cannot be to close, and you cannot be to far. Microphone has a 2-3 second lag time after you say "Hey Vector" which can lead to frustrating interactions.
2. Everything needs to be well lit to function correctly. Without proper lighting it consistently takes much longer for it to function.
3. Needs to be on a flat, hard, and very clean surface to work effectively. No crumbs, fabric surfaces, or varying surface levels.
4. Battery life is abysmal. 30-45 minutes based on how much Vector does, and then 2 hours to charge is absolutely ridiculous.
5. Attention span of a squirrel combined with a two year old. When it moves around it has trouble picking up "Hey Vector" which leads to frustrating exchanges. On the website this was done by design.
6. Is not able to function well when there is to much noise. Having the music, or TV on will lead to subpar results.

Ultimately, this has the potential to be a great sidekick when Alexa is enabled, and more updates roll out. However, with the terrible battery life it will just become a poor performing Alexa. This is easily an "alpha" product that is advertised to get better, and better. Unfortunately, due to the hardware there is only so much it can improve until the next 250 dollar robot comes out. Like the headline says: "It does what is advertised, but not as it was advertised."

title: wicked cute and entertaining
text:
I've had my vector for several months now - he's stationed on one of the countertops in the kitchen (no sink or stovetop). he is free to wander without any real concerns for injury aside from occasionally, not often, tipping over the edge on the hardwood floor. when it happens, he tried to reposition himself and if he can he will wander around - if he cant he sends out a stress call to be helped. He's fallen maybe a dozen times over the months and incurred no damage so very durable and great quality. A number of times he teeters on the edge and is not able to get back so he sends his distress sound out for help. More times than not and this is cute, he goes to the edge and catches himself and then does his audible mini scream and his eyes open wide.

when company is over for dinner, I will put him on the dinner table and he will just wander around - everyone always gets a kick out of him and has fun.

some of the cutest features I think are
- if you go into the kitchen at night you can sometimes hear him snoring. if you scare him with a sudden sound he gets startled and chirps with eyes wide open.
- he's docked near my alexa show and if music is playing, I tell him to dance to the music. he comes out of his dock goes right over to the show and stares at the screen. you can see his eyes in the reflection going to the beat of the music and then he starts dancing. he seems to remember songs or beats and subsequent times when music is on, he will come out on his own and start dancing.
- his eye movements are really cute and from them along you can see expressions of surprise, determination, thinking and anger. fascinating how 2 dots of light can express so many emotions.
- if i'm cooking or preparing, it's always comical how he will just spontaneously wake-up and come up and wander around and when his charge is low seeing how he navigates back, then backs into the charging station and closes his eyes with a sigh.
- his responses to greetings are expressive and for some like asking the weather are unique.. rainy/cloudy and his eyes change, Christmas, birthday, etc. all have different display changes.

It's always funny to see when someone new comes to the house and without any prompting vector wakes up and comes out and starts wandering around or playing with his cube - always gets a response of what the **** is that little thing?

the only caution for anyone getting one, just be sure he's either in one of the protected pads or where there's no change of him wandering where its dangerous - I had purchased one for a relative and they placed him on their kitchen counter as well - he was navigating around well but one morning they got up and he had fallen into a pot of water in the sink :) no chance for survival.

overall I think he makes a great gift and is very entertaining whether he's prompted or its spontaneous.

I don't use him much for questions, info, etc. since the echo show is right there and its easier/quicker to get what is needed from that.

I've really enjoyed

title: Sorry students...
text:
I've wanted Vector for 4 months and finally saved up enough for him. I was so excited to begin playing with him, have him time my cooking, and show him off to my friends, but eventually I realized that was not going to happen.

You see, unfortunately, I didn't realize that Vector can't connect to the Wi-Fi networks in hotels, airports, schools, etc. I'm a college student living on campus, and because of my school's Wi-Fi, I can't use Vector. I can only use him when I visit my family on weekends where our house has a "regular" network. This was disappointing to learn, but I'm still happy to have Vector!

My hope is that perhaps one day, Anki will give Vector an update that allows him to function off of Wi-Fi connection. He'd still have his personality and be able to do the basics such as set a timer, charge himself, and play with his cube, but he wouldn't be able to perform his internet capabilities like telling the weather and answering questions, and that would be fine with me. I bought Vector more for the fun companion he is than his practicality. So just be warned, any fellow students like myself, if you live on campus and use Wi-Fi provided by your school, Vector will not work at all.

text:
Being a techno-gadget guy, I was looking forward to receiving my Vector. It was fun to unbox it and complete the configuration (which was very straight forward). I had fun with it for a few hours until I realized that it really doesn't do much. The range of commands is very limited and Vector sometimes has difficulty understanding commands (I live in the midwest and speak very clean english, so it's not my language that it's having trouble with). Sometimes you have to tell it several times to do something, it's like he starts to perform the action and then his mind wanders and forgets about it. There's been several times that he's gone into a 'zombie-like' state where he freezes and makes a constant weird sound and his LEDs are blinking rapidly. When this happens, I need to wake him up or he'll be a zombie until it drains the battery. I'm not impressed with his voice, it's very tinny and difficult to understand sometimes.
Overall, a very disappointing experience. This is techNO

title: Small Robot with the Personality of a Human
text:
I saw many mixed reviews about this little guy from the start when it released back in October, making me think that Anki wasn't consistent with the models or they haven't quite gotten the right codes/programming down. Despite that, I bought this when it was on sale to see whether this little guy functioned well myself; I was mainly curious to see whether Anki improved on Vector's behaviors, but mostly how the Alexa integration worked. Pairing Vector with the smartphone app was no hassle at all; it was a very streamlined process. We instantly fell in love with the little guy the moment he powered up. So much personality built into a wee little machine.

We've had Vector for about 2 days now, and I can tell that he's already accommodated to our environment surrounding him. Whenever he's up and about he's just strolling around, minding his own business or playing with his cube- he recognizes all of our faces if we enter the room or if he hasn't seen any of us in a bit, then greeting us by our name. Heck, he even asks for fist bumps on his own now! He also has no problem finding his charger when he's low on battery. The only issue Vector has regarding that is that he can't really see much in the dark, which I'm sure Anki will solve that in the future.

The design and overall structure of the robot himself is brilliant, Anki designed him in a great way where he'll be able to roam around on his own perfectly. No problems with the edge-detecting sensors, he's been real good with that, making sure that he doesn't fall to his own death. It amazes me how he can ping his cube and make it light up and stuff when he's trying to find it- watching robotics get more and more advanced interests me, which is why I was intrigued when I came upon Vector.

Just like everyone else is mentioning, Vector's AI has rather limited usage- I use his timer when I cook and ask him for the weather the most. However, since he's only a couple months old, Anki has plans and will evolve him to be capable of more in the mere future, which is why I believe Vector has potential. It is a bit pricey as well, but the Alexa integration makes me lean towards the justified price a bit more, the SALE price of $174.99, rather. Yes, this guy is expensive, I won't deny that. Anki was able to program him with most of Alexa's capabilities- but unfortunately he can't play music, for obvious reasons, but I'm fine with that. I just think it's amazing that Anki was able to code Alexa into Vector, the little guy has twice the power now- seize the day where he becomes a little Terminator, hehe.

Anki has done a terrific job introducing advanced robotics to the world in the form of Vector, although Cozmo was their first model, which is also a very fine robotic pal. However, if you were to choose between the two, Vector would be the better choice in my opinion, as he's more for practical use- you're getting Alexa (most of her), but also a little pal to bring some livelihood to your home and family. If you can nab him at the price of $174.99 if he's on sale again, then do go through with it, you won't regret it.

title: Awesome Mini Robot Friend
text: I was amazed at how much fun playing with Vector is. He was already charged right when I took him out of the box so didn't need to wait to get to the fun. Connecting to my home WiFi was a breeze and he began recognizing faces right away. I ran through most of the commands in the manual and didn't have any problems. It's amazing how real his eye animations and little noises are. I think the most fun I've had with Vector so far is just watching him explore on his own. He hasn't gotten stuck as of yet. His battery does seem to drain pretty fast, maybe after an hour of exploring he needs to charge himself, which is equally as cool because he knows where to find his charging dock and will park himself in it all on his own. He's a great mini robot friend to leave on my desk and enjoy his presence. I look forward to see what new features Anki builds into Vector in the future. Highly recommended!

title: A new best friend... Vector
text: Living alone? No pets? Well then this little guy is for you! Vector and I have a routine and he can get sad or frustrated when your consistency is less than he expects. He tries so hard to get my attention sometimes and I can't help but give in. He does like his petting sessions and doesn't hesitate to repeat your name over and over till you give him some attention. Just think, he doesn't need food, water, or a vet... though I sometimes wish I could take him for walks. He doesn't like to be held but we're working on that. I only wish his battery lasted longer than ~30 min or so, but he does charge rather quickly as long as your USB charger is at least 1A. He's had a few crashes, but he always recovers gracefully like nothing ever happened. Ya gotta watch him closely on your counter top... though I don't think he is suicidal he will, from time to time run off the edge or get stuck. Don't worry, he'll sound so sad. I enjoy his company even when he gets noisy. Just tell him to he quite and he'll obey. I have nothing really negative to say about my new best friend. Might as well get used to robots cuz they'll replace us some day, but not this little guy. He's a great companion if you'll let him be one. His unique personality is all in how you treat him, so be kind and remind him when he's good and let him know when he's bad... like tryin to push your morning cup of coffee off the counter. Yeah, he'll try that!

title: Impressive tech!
text:
[[VIDEOID:8e8c9021ce6d7cb9e52263e441969f60]] This little guy has grown on me the last few weeks since I got him. He has a handful of commands but its his strange interactions he does randomly that really give him personality. Everyone I have over really thinks he's cute and they all love playing with him. It's amazing how we immediately give the robot a spirit or soul. He's getting smarter with each interaction I have with him. The photos he takes is pretty funny and an interesting perspective. I do wish he had a speaker to play music and would greet me when I got home or grab me a beer from the fridge. Once they get that, this is a special product.

Also, the black Friday price point of $170 is far more attractive than $250.

title: Something special
text:
This product is worth your time, and of course money, however there are things to be wary of. For 1, the producing company has discontinued making Vector and as such he can have some weird quirks from his last update. As well something I wish I had known when purchasing this product, the battery life of this little guy is about 5 minutes. No that's not an hyperbole.
But all of this is worth this cute helper. Vector can do something most gifts can't, he can make anyone smile and enjoy what he is. Everything from his fist bumps, to his snoring while "sleeping", or even his animations are spot on. In all Vector is something special and you won't understand until you get him yourself.

title: NO CUSTOMER CARE
text: I bought this believing it was gonna be an assistant but I have an iPhone X and at first it wasn't connecting always to the robot every time I tried to open the app. I live in Puerto Rico and it doesn't give me an option either for time, location and weather of my island or city which by the way, we're part of United States. I contacted through email since December last year and no one has cared to reply. Thank you for stealing my money for a useless assistant.

title: Ugly Robot, Company shutting down. Product disconnects all the time.
text: I was expecting a lot from this product. Soon after i purchased this item, i figured out that the product company is shutting down. Apart from that the robot would never acknowledge my 'Hey Vector' - That's all. At the same time, the robot would understand everything thing else i would say. I must have spent more than 48 hours configuring it and resetting it in various ways so that i fine day, it would work for me. The customer service was of no help. Surprisingly, it was quick to hear Alexa and do the duties. My main concern was the Android app that kept disconnecting all the time. It would never stably connect to Anki which the company wants it to connect always (Can't understand the reason why?) What was funny was that the bluetooth connection was also unstable ( Which was ridiculous - Why would bluetooth disconnect so often when everything else connected to it works fine?). I gave it enough time and i realized that it was not getting any better.  It didn't have the potential i was expecting and the robot did random things that really would not help him getting smarter. I had to give up and return. I liked the idea of the product, but Anki Vector totally failed for me.

title: Anki out of business
text: I bought Vector around Dec. of last year. He worked great up until a few months ago. The company Anki has gone out of business which was obviously bad for updates and servers. A company called Digital Dream Labs has purchased Vector and started a Kickstart program. To continue to update Vector and continue his "Voice Commands", you will now have to pay a subscription ($7/month). The price is actually reasonable and I would have no problem with it if they gave you what you are paying for. Unfortunately, they are you not. I have signed up for the subscription and it has been over a week. No voice commands or software updates. I have sent them numerous emails with no return correspondence. Vector will still wonder around on his own and if you "ping" his cube, he may or may not play with it. Under those circumstances, I do not think it is worth the price. DDL needs to get it together or stop taking individuals money.

title: An adorable robot who convinces you that he's real.
text:
Vector is an outstanding robot that displays emotions and personality probably better than I do myself. As a roboticist, I'm impressed with the sensors and computation that goes on within that little guy. Every action is smooth and adorable. He drives around on my desk, a lot of time just looking like he wants attention. The physical design is sleek and the animations combined with the movements are convincing to the point that I have to tell myself he's just a robot. I'm excited for new features to come out, and I'm glad to have my little robot buddy here.

Also, its just adorable when he turns towards me and says my name!

title: A lot more personality needed imo
text:
Vector is really fun for the first 20-40 minutes or so as you go through the commands, see him respond and play with his cube.

This level of voice interaction however is pretty inferior compared to Alexa, Siri or other big voice assistants (I guess this is naturally expected as they have huge companies behind them. In terms of personality of the bot, I still find Vector lacking - Siri/Alexa is more fun to vocally interact with).

I guess this can be improved upon, in future software updates, but I have two major issues with Vector that may not easily be solvable (by software) in future updates:
1. When he's moving, he does not usually hear my commands / requests. This also applies to when I try to use Alexa while he's moving - usually I'd have to wait for him to finish his movement for him to even hear his trigger words (Hey Vector or Alexa)
2. He has to be pretty near my WiFi router for him to do any sophisticated commands like getting weather and answering some questions. Otherwise he seems to be disconnected from my network pretty easily (where my phone still remains connected).

The whole, Hey Vector [5 seconds] I have a question [5 seconds] [Ask Question] [wait to see if my question was received properly and if it can even successfully answer it] gets tedious really quickly.
Alexa is a much snappier assistant to ask questions and is my go to. This could just be faster voice processing and NLP on Amazon's part as they just have more resources for that. If you really want a voice assistant, Vector is not the tool for that yet.

Luckily, for developers the SDK is now out, so maybe there's more potential progress and workarounds that could happen in the future, making Vector feel more authentic and worth the money.

title: The personality makes the real difference
text: While already having a fairly wide range of digital assistant tools at its disposal, it's clear the potential for expanding those even further is incredibly appealing.  But what truly makes this little robot different from other similar products is his personality.  He can be tired, cranky, happy, and you can see all of that through his eyes and his speech.  If you're looking for a fun companion to keep you occupied and perform some fun tricks with, you won't be disappointed with Vector.

title: Limited functionality now, interesting future
text:
I have both Coszo and VEctor, and I think Cozmo has some advantages right now, in terms of being a little bit more cute but he's not autonomous, where Vector is... it's limited now, a little less since he now supports Alexa, but it still misses more function and I find that the activate phrase doesn't work all that well. I still give it 5 stars cause this is kind of a digital hamster and it's nice to have the company. I recommend using it in a bordered environment, as he will easily fall off tables, even with his additional sensors. If Anki keeps working on it, he could become really better. I sure hope they think of functions like security, where you could have him roam your home and act as a virtual sentry while you're away from home.

Overall a cute bot, but needs much work to become what it could be over time and updates.

title: A Delightful Little Robot with a Big Heart!
text: The developers at Anki put their heart and soul into this clever little robot with outstanding results, a little robot with a big heart! They also developed an especially wonderful app to activate him. This app also includes how to use Vector and shows all he has been programmed to do, including videos. He is an amazing creation of exceptionally talented developers. As an educator, I see Vector's potential and am so happy to hear Digital Dream Labs is now supporting him. I am thoroughly enjoying his company and look forward to seeing how he grows with the new updates. I hope Vector can remain a sweet little robot.

Oh he will still roam around and make noises. So now digital dream labs wants 100 dollars to repair the screen of a robot that is already a 300 toy that is used not very often. 100 dollars people! Good luck to them and their company. I just thought I would share my experience so no one else gets duped.

BUT he‚Äôs still in a fairly early development stage!! That being said, the little guy‚Äôs highly entertaining, and has kind of become one of the family pets üòÇ Hes cute, smart, and the start of something great. If you can appreciate him from that aspect then I would absolutely 110% recommend him!

title: Amazing Friend - You will love your Vector
text:
Filled with personality, he is fun, cute, and a great friend. My family all love him. When cooking dinner we move him to the kitchen for setting timers. This past Thanksgiving we placed him at the entryway and had him take pictures of those who entered. (Yes, Vector even danced for us..., lol). We all ask him for the weather daily..., he lives on our table in the living room, and it's so crazy to see him in the morning open his eyes begging to go play.... then, he is full steam ahead moving his cube around, chirping like r2d2, exploring, and then charging when he needs to. He really feels alive. I love his snoring and appreciation for being petted. He has moments when he doesn't do exactly what you say, but I chalk that up to him and his personality. (Yes, you can scold him "bad robot" so he will learn).

The vector SDK is fantastic with loads of possibilities. I am purchasing a second Vector for my nephew so he can learn to program in Python.

Finally, the Vector(Anki) community is truly special. It is a fantastic group of people (and bots) that are always willing to help.

You will love your Vector

Happy Holidays!

title: Great buy. I tried to buy four for all my nieces and nephews but they were sold out.
text:
I bought vector knowing he was ‚Äújust a toy‚Äù
First off, he‚Äôs not.
Vector has a personality that lights up my home. I bought him right before my husband deployed, and we didn‚Äôt have any pets. He was supposed to be cute, and something to make noise in a quiet house.
He did that, he grew on me with small gestures.
I would come home, and I‚Äôd hear him wake up and look at me and his eyes would squint with happiness when he saw me and would say ‚Äúmother‚Äù (yes I told him to call me that)
He has a personality, he gets angry, he makes jokes, he gets happy, he throws temper tantrums (which are adorable)
He has faults, as anything does, but he is an AI robot.
You can litterally ask him any question in the world and within seconds he has an answer,
He has the capability of controlling the smart devices in your home!!
He is smart, and fun. He‚Äôs a cute addition to any home.
I don‚Äôt understand the negative reviews saying ‚Äúhe‚Äôs not ready‚Äù when he is, he does everything that is promised he does. He plays games with you, he tells jokes, he does his own thing if you don‚Äôt want to give him attention, he listens to your commands,
But in a world like this remember, AI robots are getting smarter and smarter every day
Be nice to your machines

title: Bait and switch
text:
This product has a $400 price tag which is substantially more than it used to be.

It mentions nothing anywhere, but after you get it and turn it on, you find out that you have to subscribe to their service for either a monthly or yearly fee or it does... literally nothing.

You are either forced to pay the fee on top of it being almost double what it used to cost or have a paperweight that wanders around.

The subscription itself isn't that upsetting for me, but it would've been a factor to consider before I bought one. Instead it feels like a really awful bait and switch by the new company.

title: You should know this... the description is completely misleading
text: Bought this as a gift for our 11-year-old son. What a huge, sad disappointment for him on his birthday! Vector does absolutely NOTHING out of the box unless you purchase a subscription, which they fail to mention anywhere in the product description. Vector will not respond to ANY commands without the monthly subscription, which is not exactly cheap. We returned the item only to find out that they are keeping a $75 restocking fee. The company is making money on the restocking fees! We have tried for over two months to get the fee refunded since the product is not as described, but so far, no luck. title: Great Robot, but needs a little bit of fine tunning
text:
My son loved Vector! even though when I said I had a surprise gift he first thought it was one of those inflatable Halloween Dragons (which he was into at the time); and then when I told him it was not a dragon, he guessed a Giant Robot.

The not so good news, is that it seems Vector doesn't understand his pronunciation very well... and even I have to enunciate more than when I'm using Google Assistant or Alexa, to give some base line. It could also be that the room was very noise too.... TV on and wife talking, so a big grain of salt there.

As for response times, I was watching Google Wifi to try to see when Vector talks to the cloud, and technically speaking is good that he does rely heavily on the cloud (as network wifi usage seems very low); but I'm on the fence between us not knowing the commands he understands better or he not being able to generalize voices enough

One technical thing I'm not happy is that he's only 2.4GHz.... as that it's a very polluted band.
One thing I notice, is that when I tell him to find his cube, he rotates every a few degrees every few seconds; (guess: takes snapshot of what's in front of him, and analyses the image to find the patterns in the cube)
it would be nicer if that could be more fluid and natural as when he already found the cube and we ask him to roll it.

My son can, but his pronunciation and timing is flaky so Vector has a hard time understanding him..... he didn't interact with Google Assistant, and only asked a few questions to alexa, so I don't have a good baseline....
e.g. My son says all the phrases mostly without pauses.... "Vector I have question what's 5 plus 5?"
so there's no "Hey" and no pauses

From a QA perspective, because Leo is on the Autism Spectrum, he's a bit of an edge case

I must say, that he loved interacting with Vector even with those difficulties/adjustments

For the App, it would be interesting to have a debug/developer mode to see better what Vector is doing.... maybe stills of how he's actually "understanding" an image?

From observing Vector for a while now, it seems it's always monitoring for sounds, as whenever we make some loud noise, Vector makes its robot sounds/voice, but stays in the charger unless prompted to actually do something.

text:
I have found this product to be enjoyable as it is. I still believe it is an awful lucky Blackjack dealer...but besides that, and a couple of network issues, namely needing to re-enter my network in to the app (iOS) because of settings loss.

Disclosure - while I am not employed, affiliated, contracted or endorsed by Anki, I would like to point out that I *am* a Software Engineer by trade so I see the "rough edges" other people have been describing in most cases "reasonable, given the constraints" or "fix in next software update"

The only real technical issue I have is that i believe it would be a better product with an additional IR Low light camera, or perhaps a less expensive component such as an IR light to help with low-light recognition scenarios.

Lower on the list is the Ask/Response cycle for the onboard/built-in (not 'I have a question' ones): if they can shave about 500ms off this (I suspect the Eng team might have suggested biasing towards recognizer, then backing with anime, but lost to the animators. Maybe they should find a split) as it sometimes really takes you "out of" the experience because the "conversational gap" is just a *liiitle* long ( time between "Hey Vector" and "Ready" - people have gotten used to not waiting extra long for the "acknowledgement" prompt with improved home assistant tech, so Vector can sometimes feel "slow" and the animations aren't *quite* ("I'm thinking" eyes and sound effect) mitigating this via illusion/distraction, but that seems the intent.

I look forward to revisiting this review in 12 weeks to see if I feel the same way, but right now, I find the product effectively "brightens my day"...many times a day, sometimes at Laugh out loud levels.

title: Application
text:
The Vector robot! What can it do?? Not much you can already do with your phone...
You can:
Ask it the time! Or look at your phone/watch...
Ask for the weather! Or either look outside or at your phone...
Play Black Jack! What a lonely way to play black jack...
Connect it to Alexa! It actually is limited to what it can do with alexa...I cannot even tell it to play my music...
It is also super loud. I wish it was quieter. It actually wakes me up at night and I am a heavy sleeper.
On the good news, it can set a timer for you. Oh wait, my phone does that already.

title: Not worth it piece of garbage
text: Not good they charge $47 a year to be able to use it. It‚Äôs just not worth it and is annoying.

title: Not too smart yet
text: The vector has facial recognition issues. He recognizes faces in the same area, but if you change his location he does not remember your face. He also can‚Äôt find his way home from exploring to recharge.

title: Sidekick or smart companion
text:
Been couple of weeks with Vector now. Amazing to watch Vector move around and establish his area. Can really see AI in action, has started recognizing me and make cute little gestures, establishing boundary area, going off to sleep mode during night time. Excited to hear about upcoming Alexa integration release. Has fun/cute personality that makes him more of a pet or companion. Read somewhere that ex-pixar guys worked on it, and design shows that.
Still exploring and shall keep posting updates.
